story:
What is WIPP?

We are Work In Progress Productions (WIPP, for short) we are a non-profit theatre group orginating from Middle Island (Middle Island Presbyterian Church) and we're asking for your help to fund our upcoming Spring show "Working Title!" It is the 10th anniversary of our group, which is why to kick off our upcoming season, our group decided to do something that is completely new to us... this will be our first self-written show! It is a script completely put together by the creative thoughts and styles of our very own cast members. You can imagine how much hard work and effort our cast put into such a show, which is why we'd want more than anything to see their thoughts come to life AND to be seen by all that can... Which is another new addition to our tenth year, our group is looking to tour to different venues for the first time in our ten year run! You can imagine how much effort our kids put into all of this, which is why we could really use any help we can get from all of our lovely supporters (THATS YOU!)

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need rental money for new spaces, new venues, all around our neighboring towns on Long Island.
  • We also need money for sets, costumes, props, and whatever else it is that brings the magic to the stage.
  • The more exposure we get, the more our group can grow, and the more we can entertain people like you for many more years to come!
  • If you donate, there can be wonderful gifts and prizes in it FOR YOU, right from the actors/producers/directors themselves! (MORE PERKS WILL BE ADDED TO THIS CAMPAIGN AS TIME PROGRESSES, it's still early, but the cast is currently thinking up ideas to please our funders who push the extra mile for us. So please donate all you can.)

If we don't reach our goal, the money will go into the organizations that allowed us to perform in their venues and into the merchandising we provide for both the cast/crew and the supporters that do fund us(posters, tshirts, etc.)

The Impact

WIPP was built by the theatre kids that never got the chance to show their truest potential on stage or behind the curtain, we have always allowed the kids that join our group to express themselves in ways they never could through a theatrical experience that allows them both to better themselves in what they love to do and to have a fun and memorable experience in the presence of people they can both look up to and call on as close friends. We have become more of a family-based organization over the years and we plan on staying that way.

  • For theatrically interested kids from ages 14+ there aren't many ways to be this expressive in theatrical arts. I mean, what theatre group allows you to write your own show?!
  • This is a fun, lovable, talented group of people that only look to improve themselves even more each year.
  • If allowed to expand throughout the Island(or even further than that perhaps, in years to come) we would have such an impact on kids who don't have a strong support group of friends, have an undiscovered talent, and want to make a difference in their community but don't know how to be heard. WIPP does that for our kids.

In the last ten years, WIPP has become a family filled with traditions and support from all who associate with us. We have had a very strong impact on those involved with us and left those who have come to see us with something they will always remember. Our only goal is to continue our ongoing success. But we need your help to do it.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, don't worry! There are other ways you can help us!:

  • Tell your friends about our upcoming show! And join us yourself, we're always looking for new faces in our audiences!
  • Check out our Facebook page, give us a like, follow us, give us suggestions for our future shows if you got them!
  • Go to our Youtube Channel and show us some love! Like our videos, leave a comment, tell us what you'd like to see next time!

(Links for Facebook and Youtube are located at the bottom of this page.)

Thanks for hearing us out and contributing to our cause in anyway you can, hopefully we'll see you at our next show!

story:
Short Summary

LOOP Theatre endeavours to make the arts open and accessible to those with learning disabilities and to invest in their contribution to the wider artistic community.

We are a mixed ability company from Glasgow who create inspirational theatre together.

We run free workshops for people with learning disabilities that give them opportunities to collaborate with practicing professional artists.

Our syllabus is informed by physical theatre practice which is, in essence, open and accessible to all. Our skill set is rich and diverse, informed by our collective years of experience in a range of art forms including contemporary dance, theatre, physical practice, music, acro-balance, aerial skills, butoh and visual art.

Our Theatre is discovered and created through collective collaboration and a passionate, joyful process.

What We Need

The £1,000 we are hoping to raise will allow us to: 

  • Cover our start up fees to formally register as a Community Interest Company - which will mean we are able to apply for project based funding.
  • Acquire materials and resources to offer more diverse stimuli to participants e.g. advanced tactile resources for participants with sensory impairment
  • Hire space to run our workshops far more regularly than just once a month. 

What You Get

  • The knowledge that you are supporting and advancing a unique service that encourages and empowers creativity in an often overlooked and undervalued community. 

  • By way of thanks we will give you a custom LOOP gift or an invaluable LOOP Theatre experience!

  • In the event that we do not reach our goal, the money raised will go a long way to ensuring that we can register as a company and continue to provide free, high quality workshops. 

The Impact

LOOP Theatre is excited by the opportunity to provide our participants with a platform to express themselves, have fun and be professionally trained in physical theatre. As well as building confidence and self-esteem, we provide a unique opportunity for people to come and play without judgement, to learn about themselves and each other towards positive personal growth by means of the performance making process.

Over the last year LOOP Theatre has enabled participants to attend free workshops that run every 4th Saturday, Summer School projects and create devised performances.

Our Summer School Show involved 20 participants, 4 support staff and 10 artists. Over the space of a week we explored spacial awareness, movement and performance skills allowing the participants to develop their own material in a safe and encouraging environment giving them ownership and pride in both the process and the final performance. 

"I didn't know what to expect. I was genuinely impressed with the progress you made in a week. I could tell that the participants really loved it and had gained confidence. We look forward to doing it all again."

Eleanor, Riddrie Learning Centre

 

The training and experience that LOOP offer is hugely rewarding for both the participants and the tutors. We are proud to be able to provide such a creative, people centred project that is invaluable to the community and with your help we can continue to reach out to even more people that may not otherwise have opportunities like this.

Our tutors have been working in this area for a number of years and have found that using physical theatre, visual art and music is an extremely effective vehicle for enabling self expression in everyone.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Your contribution need not be financial. You can help in a variety of ways:

  • We are always looking for volunteers to help with things like costume design, scenic painting, props, make up and more.
  • Share the Loop Theatre website on Facebook and Twitter and use the Indiegogo share tools to promote our cause.

story:
Short Summary

In 1996, the Greater Rochester Repertory Companies (GRRC) was founded to provide an environment for actors, musicians, and all theatre practitioners to teach and learn. Along with that mission, we vowed to give a voice and venue to local and regional authors.

For 17 years we have produced original works by many aspiring playwrights. The most recent of these is "The Life of Leo Wool," a play by Rochester native Nina Alvarez.

Some of you may know Nina, some may not. For the uninitiated, her play's staged reading for the 2012 Fringe Festival received an excellent reception and enthusiastic audience feedback.

"The Life of Leo Wool" leaves people talking, debating, and exploring their judgments, desires, and personal relationships. Some responses have been:

“Leo Wool addresses the timeless truths of the written word's relationship to the human condition, made genuinely interesting and broadly accessible by Ms. Alvarez." -Jeremy Sniatecki

“The author, Nina Alvarez, a most talented, Virgilian tour guide, shines light upon the dark memories consigned to the corners of its closets. She empties out the repressed contents of its locked cabinets. And, finally, she exhumes, with reverence, the faded remains of a love, long hidden beneath carefully forgotten floorboards. If, within your own house, you have ever struggled, even for a moment, to find the balance point between HONESTY and COMPASSION, this tour (de force) is one you ought to take!” - Michael Haugh

 

"The Life of Leo Wool" will be directed by Chair of the SUNY Brockport Theatre Department, P Gibson Ralph, and will feature the well-known local talents of Jack Simel, Diane Chevron, Jessica Drew-Cates, Jason Alexander Holmes, as well as a  debut performance by Nancy Berg.

To read more about how "Leo" came to be, check out this article in Her Rochester.

What We Need & What You Get

The GRRC is a nonprofit organization and we run on support from people like you who donate, come to shows, and help get the word out. Our goal is to raise $1,500 by May 19 to cover the theatre rental expenses for six performances of "The Life of Leo Wool."

We have some great perks for contributors, including free tickets to upcoming shows and personal recognition before performances.

 

The Impact

"The Life of Leo Wool" is about an aging, eminent literary critic who doesn't have time for "new" work. But we know better than Leo. New writers can't become the great writers of tomorrow without support. Nina is one of Rochester's most exciting emerging playwrights and we want to give her show the best possible step forward. Your contributions will help up with stage rentals, thereby allowing every aspect of the show to run more smoothly.

 

About the GRRC

Nina's dedication to working with the actors and board to develop and promote this show reflects the collective sensibility of the GRRC. Our actors, board, and director all donate a lot of time, energy, and talent to making this show a hit. Please help us by contributing to this campaign, coming to a show, or even just spreading the word. You can easily do that online by use this page's tools to spread the word on: Facebook, Twitter, and Email.

And nothing beats word of mouth!

 

About Nina Alvarez

Nina Alvarez is a published short ficition writer and award-winning poet, as well as a writing coach, editor, and award-winning teacher. 

Show times: Performances are May 10*, 11, 17, & 18 at 7:30 pm and May 18* & 19 at 2:00 pm.

*Discussion with the author immediately following performance.

 

Location: The East End Theatre 727 E Main St. Rochester

 

Pricing: Tickets are $20 General Admission and $15 Seniors and Students, and are available at all area Wegmans stores or by calling the East End Theatre box office at (585) 325-3366. 

Special Discounts Available! 

For Everyone: In the literary spirit of the play, GRRC is offering $5.00 off the regular ticket price if you bring to the Box Office an appropriate book to be donated in GRRC’s name to the Rochester City School District libraries. Please call the Box Office for details.

For Members of Writers & Books: Friday, May 17, Writers and Books Night.  Members/students, etc. of Writers & Books get $5 off regular ticket price.

 

Show Synopsis

Literature is dying, and so is Leo Wool, the last American superstar literary critic. When he is visited in his study by the ghost of his dead wife portending the visit of three writers with bones to pick, Leo must confront the real life he has led and what he may have sacrificed in search of the sublime.

story:
We've been accepted! Now...

...we need your help to get us there! 

Orbiting Astral Bodies brings the audience into a magical world where the Moon speaks, dreams converge with reality, and space objects can be chained to the Earth. When the Moon decides to leave Earth in search of something better, the lives of four people are upended as they struggle to seek their own meaning, reality, and purpose. The play presents characters struggling with their isolation, abandonment, addiction, and fear of the unknown in exciting theatrical ways. 

This new play (written by Nathan Gregorski) will be directed by Kevin O'Callaghan, Executive Artistic Director of Mad Dog Theatre Company, a company dedicated to the production of new works and winner of the 2012 New York Innovative Theatre Award for Best Original Short Play for This Is Not The Play written by Chisa Hutchinson.

With your help we can give life to this exciting new play and be part of the prestigous and world-renowned festival, FringeNYC.

What We Need & What You Get

FringeNYC is unique in that they provide accepted shows a performace venue for the festival, however this is only a fraction of the cost of what it takes to produce a full scale production in New York City. Your dollars will go to cover the costs of...

  • FringeNYC Entry Fee 
  • Rehersal Space Rent
  • Costumes, Sets, Props, Lights
  • Marketing Materials 
  • Artist Stipends

We, of course, don't expect you to do this for nothing!

SO, we're offering many exciting perks to our generous donors...

  • VIP Opening Night Seating, 2 Complimentary Tickets and a Champagne Toast with the  Cast, Director, and Playwright.
  • An Autographed Show Poster from the Cast and Crew.
  • 2 Complimentary Tickets to any Orbiting Astral Bodies Performance.
  • A Special Shout Out in our Program and on Facebook!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contirbute financially. That's OK!

We ask you to please spread the word about our show! Tell your friends. Share this page on Facebook and Twitter, or tell someone about it over a beer. Every little bit helps and we are grateful to each and every one of you!

If you'd like to help us out by handing out postcards or striking the set,

please contact Kevin @ kevin@maddogbarks.com

Thank you so much for your support!

-Kevin and Nathan

story:
BE A HERO

We are on a quest to Save the Webster.  HERO (Help Entertain and Restore Organization) is a nonprofit group formed to save the movie theater in Webster City.  It's a cornerstone building in a downtown that is coming back to life.  Dining, Shopping, Entertainment -- and the movie theater must be a part of it!  

We raised $24,500 to buy the building - simply by asking for help.  Now we're in Phase 2 and we need to purchase the digital equipment, sound system and do some repairs to the building.  That will cost $80,000.  We've got half of that raised already.

Now it's time to take it to the people.  We believe you'll be the real heroes - and give the rest of the fund.  

What We Need & What You Get

Phase 2 is $80,000.  This buys:

  • Digital equipment to show the movies -- its the only equipment that will work for the movies the studios send.  The days of film died in 2013.  
  • A sound system that provides clarity, quality and kick butt sound.
  • The floor in women's bathroom repaired.
  • Some repairs to the roof (nothing major, but some flashing needs fixed). 

We've already raised half of that --- you can make a difference and be a HERO. 

We've got some perks for those of you who give: 

$10  - Movie Pass (Not to be used on opening night)

$35  - SuperHero T-shirt*

$50  - Bottom-less Popcorn Bucket for a Year

$75  - 2 Tickets to Opening Night - A "Red Carpet Affair"

$100 - Movie Pass a Month for a Year

$300 - Adopt a Theater Seat with Inscribed Plaque*

$5     - A just because donation that gets our undying gratitude! 
*We will contact you (via email) to get any necessary details as it relates to the perk you choose - such as what t-shirt size you would like and what inscription you want on the plaque.  


The Impact

You can help give our kids a place to go in the evenings and weekends.  You can help keep Webster City alive by supporting the downtown merchants and movie theater.  You will be a real hero.  

Help Entertain and Restore Organization (HERO) is committed to opening the Webster City Movie Theater once again.  The closing of small-town theaters is rumored to be not so uncommon in the industry.  With the advent of Redbox and Netflix, going out to the movies is perceived to be declining in popularity.  Yet … yet, there is still a vibrant market that wants to go to the movies.  It’s more than just seeing a movie.  It’s going out to dinner first, then to the movies, then for a drink.  It’s taking the family to the movies and enjoying the popcorn and having the conversation with your kids after the movie – a special treat for everyone.  Going out to a movie will always be a staple of entertainment for the American public.  According to Entertainment Weekly, “Americans spent many of their hard-earned dollars at the movies —

Movie theaters sold an estimated $10.84 billion worth of tickets domestically in 2012, beating the previous record of $10.59 billion set in 2009, and marking a new record in terms of revenue earned in a single calendar year. All told, the 2012 box office finished 6.6 percent ahead of 2011′s $10.17 billion take and 2.5 percent of 2010′s $10.57 billion.”

The movie theater is a cornerstone building in town, and comes with many memories for most of the people who live here.  Reopening a small town movie theater is not a new or novel idea.  The primary challenge right now for small-town theaters is not the lack of market or community support in patronizing the theater; it is in fact the financial resources needed to obtain digital equipment necessary to show movies.  The national film exhibition industry is rapidly converting exclusively to digital projection, by mid-2014, new movies will cease being released on 35mm film.  This forces a theatre- if it is going to remain open- to convert to digital equipment, an approximate $80,000 investment.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this page on your social networks!  
  • Volunteer to be on the crew to clean up the seats, the carpets and the walls.  Stop by the Chamber office and sign up.  
  • Encourage your graduating class to get together and raise $300 to buy a seat. 
  • Talk about this over coffee, after church and with your friends.  We need all the word of mouth we can get.  
  • Not from here? It doesn't matter!  Help make this small town greater than it is - and you'll be a hero too.  Share this page with your friends and family as well.
  • Come to the movies when we get open! 

Debbie Jaycox said "So many, many memories.. I remember my Grand Parents taking me to The Ten Commandments!!...Now that was a while ago.. My husband & I always waited for the latest movie to come to WC... to support our local Theater!!!! Lets all get on board!!!! WC can do it!!!!"
story_txt:
BE A HEROWe are on a quest to Save the Webster.  HERO (Help Entertain and Restore Organization) is a nonprofit group formed to save the movie theater in Webster City.  It's a cornerstone building in a downtown that is coming back to life.  Dining, Shopping, Entertainment -- and the movie theater must be a part of it!  We raised $24,500 to buy the building - simply by asking for help.  Now we're in Phase 2 and we need to purchase the digital equipment, sound system and do some repairs to the building.  That will cost $80,000.  We've got half of that raised already.Now it's time to take it to the people.  We believe you'll be the real heroes - and give the rest of the fund.  What We Need & What You GetPhase 2 is $80,000.  This buys:
Digital equipment to show the movies -- its the only equipment that will work for the movies the studios send.  The days of film died in 2013.  

A sound system that provides clarity, quality and kick butt sound.

The floor in women's bathroom repaired.

Some repairs to the roof (nothing major, but some flashing needs fixed). 

We've already raised half of that --- you can make a difference and be a HERO. We've got some perks for those of you who give: 



$10  - Movie Pass (Not to be used on opening night)




$35  - SuperHero T-shirt*




$50  - Bottom-less Popcorn Bucket for a Year




$75  - 2 Tickets to Opening Night - A "Red Carpet Affair"




$100 - Movie Pass a Month for a Year




$300 - Adopt a Theater Seat with Inscribed Plaque*
$5     - A just because donation that gets our undying gratitude! 


*We will contact you (via email) to get any necessary details as it relates to the perk you choose - such as what t-shirt size you would like and what inscription you want on the plaque.  The ImpactYou can help give our kids a place to go in the evenings and weekends.  You can help keep Webster City alive by supporting the downtown merchants and movie theater.  You will be a real hero.  
Help
Entertain and Restore Organization (HERO) is committed to opening the Webster
City Movie Theater once again.  The
closing of small-town theaters is rumored to be not so uncommon in the
industry.  With the advent of Redbox and
Netflix, going out to the movies is perceived to be declining in
popularity.  Yet … yet, there is still a
vibrant market that wants to go to the movies. 
It’s more than just seeing a movie. 
It’s going out to dinner first, then to the movies, then for a
drink.  It’s taking the family to the
movies and enjoying the popcorn and having the conversation with your kids
after the movie – a special treat for everyone.  Going out to a movie will always be a staple
of entertainment for the American public. 
According to Entertainment Weekly, “Americans spent many of their
hard-earned dollars at the movies — 
Movie
theaters sold an estimated $10.84 billion worth of tickets domestically in
2012, beating the previous record of $10.59 billion set in 2009, and marking a
new record in terms of revenue earned in a single calendar year. All told, the
2012 box office finished 6.6 percent ahead of 2011′s $10.17 billion take and
2.5 percent of 2010′s $10.57 billion.” 
The
movie theater is a cornerstone building in town, and comes with many memories
for most of the people who live here.  Reopening a small town movie theater is not a
new or novel idea.  The
primary challenge right now for small-town theaters is not the lack of market
or community support in patronizing the theater; it is in fact the financial
resources needed to obtain digital equipment necessary to show movies.  The national film exhibition industry is
rapidly converting exclusively to digital projection, by mid-2014, new movies
will cease being released on 35mm film. 
This forces a theatre- if it is going to remain open- to convert to
digital equipment, an approximate $80,000 investment.
Other Ways You Can Help
Share this page on your social networks!  
Volunteer to be on the crew to clean up the seats, the carpets and the walls.  Stop by the Chamber office and sign up.  
Encourage your graduating class to get together and raise $300 to buy a seat. 
Talk about this over coffee, after church and with your friends.  We need all the word of mouth we can get.  
Not from here? It doesn't matter!  Help make this small town greater than it is - and you'll be a hero too.  Share this page with your friends and family as well.
Come to the movies when we get open! 
Debbie Jaycox said "So many, many memories.. I remember my Grand Parents taking me to The Ten Commandments!!...Now that was a while ago.. My husband & I always waited for the latest movie to come to WC... to support our local Theater!!!! Lets all get on board!!!! WC can do it!!!!"

story:
Each year, the Suzuki Company of Toga, Japan, hosts a summer training program for select actors from around the world. We are honored to say we have been identified as candidates for the program among hundreds of applicants, and now we just have to find a way to get there!

Suzuki’s original method of actor training, concerned with the actor’s use of body and voice and the creation of theatrical ensemble, has been taught throughout the world, including at The Julliard School in New York and Moscow Art Theatre in Russia. For both of us, this training will be of exponential benefit to our artistic development at this juncture. Studying amidst masters in our field from all over the world, we will find a philosophy and theater-making tools we can share with our community at home, and we hope to inspire and set a precedent for others to pursue the work.

We look to the Suzuki Company of Toga as a model theatre community - one that continues to make astonishing work, invests in its international ensemble, and generates artistic dialogue globally. 

 

Why we need your help:

The glass is half full. We have raised fifty percent of our goal - enough money to pay for our tuition and part of our flights! Thanks to generous support from the CalArts Theater School Travel Fund and The CalArts office of the President, we're off to a great start!

The glass is half empty. with only a few weeks to go, we are only half-way to raising the funds we need to embark on this endeavour! We need to raise $3000 to cover our collective travel costs and supplies, and we are looking to our community to invest in us as artists. We hope to give back a thousand-fold what we recieve.

You know and we know we won't stop here - but that your gifts will help us maintain the forward momentum this opportunity offers without our hands tied by crippling bills.

With full funding of our goal, we will be poised at our return to immediately begin implementing our new training.

 

Kestrel:

"Our skills and intentions both must be consciously cultivated and fed with knowledge and inspiration, and we must grow more humble for what we do not know the more we learn.

I was first introduced to Suzuki’s methodology in 2009, when I began working with a collective of Suzuki-trained performers from Naropa University. The work was supported and enriched by the discipline, respect, and effortless generosity between company members inspired by SCOT’s ensemble model, and I found myself raised to a new level of collaborative art-making.

I wish to deepen my understanding of the method in the only way one really can - in an intensive and sustained experience, and immersion in its cultural context."

www.kestrelleah.com

 

Alexander:

"With the great honor of performance comes a great duty to serve and enlighten the audience. So little of the work being produced today holds up it's end of the bargain. Tadashi Suzuki and his method have for decades offered a beacon of promise for stages filled with tremendous presence and liveness. The vitality of live performance available through training like this is fundamental to my artistic vision."

I was first exposed to the Method under Will Bond of the SITI company during my time at Skidmore College. SMAT's ability to deepen not just my imagination, but also my connection to and understanding of my own imagination has opened doors for me on and off stage.

It' is a great honor to have been selected to participate in this years summer training program, I anticipate wonderful hard work and many wonderful conversations.

http://www.circletheaterny.org

 

Video: Kestrel Leah

Video credits: Natalia Sookias; Kestrel Leah
Photo credits: Amanda Shank; Cristina Fernandez; Marcin Mroz; Tatyana Kim; Kestrel Leah

story:
The Play

A Klingon Christmas Carol is out of this world!  This is the traditional Dickens holiday tale with Scrooge, ghosts, and Tiny Tim, but with a major twist: it's in Klingon (the language from the Star Trek television shows and movies.

The official blurb that we use to promote the show goes like this: 
"Scrooge has no honor, nor any courage. Can three ghosts help him to become the true warrior he ought to be in time to save Tiny Tim from a horrible fate? Performed in the Original Klingon with English Supertitles, and narrative analysis from The Vulcan Institute of Cultural Anthropology... The Dickens classic tale of ghosts and redemption adapted to reflect the Warrior Code of Honor and then translated into tlhIngan Hol  (That's the Klingon Language)."

Written by Christopher Kidder-Mostrom and Sasha Walloch, A Klingon Christmas Carol was first performed in Saint Paul, MN in 2007.  This year (2013) marks the 8th time that Commedia Beauregard has produced the play (4 times in MN, 4 times in Chicago... 2010 had shows in both cities). 

In every production prior to this year, the show has looked basically the same.  The show was done on a bare stage with a table, 4 chairs, and a coat rack.  The costumes were reminiscent of ancient warriors from Earth's middle ages and before... with a hint of Klingon flair. 

The goal this year is to make the show unlike it has ever been before:  A new multi-level set, new costumes that blend Victorian England with Klingon aesthetics (think steam-punk-Klingon), a new much smaller venue that creates an up-close intimate experience, new fights, new sound-scape... everything is being redone from the ground up.

The Need

Because we're reinventing the whole production from the ground up, we're adding things like a set!  We've never had a set before!  And we're creating completely reimagined costumes.  New heads and wigs are on the table, too!  Let's break it down numbers-wise:

  • Costumes = $2,500 --  We have an awesome Costume designer named kClare Kemock.  She designed our costumes for "Bard Fiction" which combined Jacobian England and 1990's Movie style in each outfit.  Now she's doing a similar thing with mashing-up Victorian era clothing with a sense of Klingon style!
  • Sets = $1,000 --  Set designer Ian Mostrom is building a multi-level set with a gritty space-used feel.  We'll be able to climb and leap and create new worlds unlike ever before.  And it'll feel a bit like Firefly meets 11th Doctor TARDIS meets Andromeda meets Mad Max!  Awesome!
  • Wigs & Prosthetic Foreheads = $750 -- A completely new cast (including a new Scrooge!) means new forehead appliances and the wigs that go along with them. 

This campaign is only for the major parts of the production that are being overhauled.  Most of our expenses are covered by ticket sales (Please buy tickets!).  We are not asking for money to pay for actor stipends, designer stipends, venue rent, rehearsal space, new weapons, publicity and advertising, tech staff, printing, lighting equipment, sound and music, etc.


The Company

Commedia Beauregard is a small professional theatre company that recently became a resident company of the West Stage of the Raven Theatre Complex in Chicago, Illinois.

We have been around since 1999 (starting in Minneapolis/Saint Paul) and have put up 30 productions over the last 14 years.  Since 2011 we have been HQ'd in Chicago.

Here's our mission statement:
"Our mission is to translate the universal human experience to the stage: to expand our horizons and share knowledge of all cultures, translating between languages and between arts to create theater that is beautiful in expression."

What does that mean?  Well, normally we do plays that are translated from foreign languages into English.  Sometimes we experiment with what it means to translate, and we end up with a play based on a painting, or a ballet based on an essay.  And then, once a year, we do a play that is translated into tlhIngan Hol (the Klingon language).

The Impact

As mentioned above, we are a small theatre company.  Really small.  The press that this play gets every year can make it look like we're a ridiculously successful group.  And in one way we are: we get to create wonderful theatre and awesome projects that people seem to enjoy when they attend.  That being said, while we are committed to paying the artists, actors, and designers with whom we work, we're not making money at this.  So we need your help.

Including this year's cast, over 90 people have learned to act in Klingon through this production since 2007.  It's safe to say it is unlike any other production they've been in.  It is demanding and challenging, and makes lifelong friends out of the people who have gone through the process.

And it does special things to the audience, too.  Our goal is to affect people, and while it may seem like a play that is essentially a parody has little chance to change the world, we aim to do just that.  The people who come to see this show get a live theatrical experience that cannot be replicated.  There are audience members who come back year after year.  We're now part of a holiday tradition for some families.

We'd like to be a tradition to more people than ever before, and we're hoping that with your help we can bring a new vision of this play to new people as well as returning audience members.

story:
Who we are:          

          Sad Clown Productions consists of a dedicated group of artists who believe in producing relevant and passionate work in the fields of Theatre, Film, Music, Photography, and any form of media culture.  Our efforts revolve around the development of our craft and the support of art as a universal medium. Based out of Harford County, Maryland, Sad Clown Productions is a focused and diverse production company which understands that powerful art can happen anywhere, impact anyone, and reach people in distinct and enagaging ways. We strive to reach new heights in the contemporary pursuit of what the arts are about and why we should continue to develop as artists. Please join us in our journey.

"Give them something to talk about on the ride home"

What we need: 

We have talent and determination to spare but the funding is hard to come by, that's where our supporters come in! Expenses we'll need to cover for the launch of our first professional production are show rights, a show space, set dressings/lumber, paint, costumes, props, and basic production costs. The quality of our productions are incumbent upon the amount of money we can put forth, and the group of professional artists that make up the the Sad Clown Company are of the highest caliber. Some of our artists have worked on/for Broadway, New York Fashion Week, Comedy Central, Veep, and House of Cards. Any and all help is greatly appreciated and even if you don't have a dime to spare, a simple like and share to spread to word of Sad Clown would be wonderful! Please Help make our beautiful ideas a reality!

story:
Short Summary

  • Action To The Word are an independent emerging theatre company
  • While A Clockwork Orange travels the world and has created prolonged employment for it's company, this doesn't allow financial liberty for the creation of new projects, which have a trajectory to tour and further West-End life
  • You will help us buy our drum-kit which will be used for our forthcoming productions of The Oresteia - Eumenides and for our forthcoming production of Dracula

What You Get

  • Action To The Word enjoy a fine reputation as the new kids on the block with a catalogue of fantastic reviews and a reputation of theatrical excellence. We provide great opportunities for young and emerging performers all over the country.
  • As an ACTION ANGEL you will have thanks in our programmes, websites and publications. You will be given Press Night invites to all forthcoming work and meet and greets with the performance team. In addition, you will also be able to attend our Brush Up Your Shakespeare Scheme workshops on priority and free of cost.
  • As an ACTION CHERUB you will have thanks in our programme and website and priority notice of our theatre work and programmes.

Short Summary

What You Get

As an ACTION ANGEL you will have thanks in our programmes, websites and publications. You will be given Press Night invites to all forthcoming work and meet and greets with the performance team. In addition, you will also be able to attend our Brush Up Your Shakespeare Scheme workshops on priority and free of cost.
As an ACTION CHERUB you will have thanks in our programme and website and priority notice of our theatre work and programmes.

story:
Who are we? We are the creative peeps of Songs For A More Funnier World: the musical, and we are headed to NYMF, that is, the New York Musical Theater Festival in July 2013! What are we?  We are a musical (weren’t you listening?) about 4 singers who awake to find themselves in yet another serious musical.  But this time they decide to make it their comedic bitch. And, Who are you?  You are the beautiful and generous and kind and did I say beautiful people who want to help get us there, increase their Karma, and make theater “more funnier!” Now go donate!!! Tell your neighbor, your grandma, your gerbil, the world!  Use the Indie Go-go share tools!  What more do you need to know!? What, you need more info? Ok. Here goes.

So this is our story, Songs For A More Funnier World (SFAMFW) was once a wee lil tot of an idea, and after some years of work, it grew into a full length musical.  All it wanted was to be in the most prestigious musical theater festival in the world: The New York Musical Theater Festival (did you hear the sweeping strings crescendo when you read that?)  So it applied, and after months of waiting by the cyber mailbox, it was accepted!  Now the only thing standing between it and being a smashing success at NYMF 2013 is money.  Where does your money go? To our Swiss bank accounts and hedge fund manager?  Unfortunately as theater people we’re lucky to have $10 on our Starbucks card.  No your money goes to “Hey kids, let’s put on a show!!” as Judy Garland and Gene Kelly would say, ie: production costs.  It pays for everything from microphones, to the set, to rehearsal space, to designers and to the most amazing cast ever assembled: Amy Albert (I Love You You’re Perfect, Delilah Dix,) Kevin Massey (Tarzan, Memphis,) Steven Strafford (Spamalot, Methtacular) and Cortney Wolfson (Addams Family, Legally Blonde.)  And most importantly it goes into the future of the show.  If a show is a hit at NYMF it can go on to off-Broadway, Broadway, and even Poughkeepsie!  And you can say: I was a part of that! And oh you will.

SFAMFW is the creative child of Stuart McMeans, whose comedy songs are frequently performed by Broadway performers in NYC and around the US. It is being directed by the amazing Adam Fitzgerald, director to some of the funniest stuff you’ll see in New York. It also contains music written by some of NYC’s most talented composers:  Paul Castrataro, Ben Green, William TN Hall, and Michael Kooman.  

So in all sincerity every little bit helps us on our way to NYMF.  And for every level you donate, you get a special something, a little token of our appreciation and some bigger tokens too.  Look at the PERKS!  And share this campaign with your friends, family, coworkers and enemies even.  It will make them nicer I promise.  That’s what giving does.

It is being directed by the amazing Adam Fitzgerald, director to some of the funniest stuff you’ll see in New York. It also contains music written by some of NYC’s most talented composers:  Paul Castrataro, Ben Green, William TN Hall, and Michael Kooman.  
So in all sincerity every little bit helps us on our way to NYMF.  And for every level you donate, you get a special something, a little token of our appreciation and some bigger tokens too.  Look at the PERKS!  And share this campaign with your friends, family, coworkers and enemies even.  It will make them nicer I promise.  That’s what giving does.

story:
ABOUT JENNIFERCHINdance

Summer 2013 took Jennifer to the Florence Dance Festival as a choreographer-in-residence for Toscana Dance Hub. She created a new work for 14 dancers that was performed at The Bargello, in addition to her solo, Seduction of a Sparrow. 

Earlier in 2013, the company took part of The Breaking Ground Festival in Tempe, Arizona. where they performed the duet Aftermath. Jennifer then taught Master classes to the undergraduate and graduate students at Arizona State University.

This May marked the first ever JENNIFERCHINdance company Benefit and fund-raising campaign where we raised over $6,000 through individual contributions and silent auction. These funds helped us take part in the above festivals. Now we need your help to continue our ‘evolution’ in 2014. While organizations can afford a teaching fee there is often not enough funding for touring costs. That's where you come in.

We’re looking to show work in New York City, and teach and perform in California. All of our performances are self-produced. You can make our next concert possible!

Any donation that you can share will make a difference, from $5-$5,000. Here's a small breakdown of what a dance budget looks like:

  • $20 - an hour of studio rental for rehearsal.
  • $50 - one day’s per diem while on tour.
  • $200 - one night performer’s fee.
  • $250 - one performer’s costume.
  • $420 - airline ticket to California.
  • $1,000 - hotel for a week in Los Angeles.
  • $3,000+ - performance space in NYC.

-And donation up to $500 will get you an invite to an Open Rehearsal You get to see the inner workings of the company and speak to collaborating artists.

-Donations over $500 include the above and a special wine reception at our next performance.

-Besides a financial contribution JENNIFERCHINdance is always looking for volunteers to help out behind-the-scenes. Consider what skills you can bring to our company. There is no job too small.

-If our work speaks to you then go ahead and speak to your friends about us! Stay connected by liking our Facebook page www.facebook.com/jenniferchindance

“The inspiration for my choreography can be visceral, visual or theoretical. I strive for the viewer to be transported to the world I have created and/or stimulated to create their own narrative. Each piece begins with a seed of a thought- sometimes a physical gesture, a still image, a piece of literature or perhaps a speculative question. I am consistently intrigued by the way movement can explore ways of communication, either between dancers or between the performers and the audience. I want my work to take the viewer on a journey.

My teaching aims to empower dancers with the tools to enhance their life as performers. Using my experience from teaching The Limòn technique for the past 14 years, my goal is for students to become more aware of the body and discover efficiency in movement. My goal is to imbue dancers with anatomical knowledge and strengthening skills so they can have a long, healthy career.”

-Jennifer

story:
This Is What Happened

Movement Continuum is a contemporary dance company that was founded at a Thanksgiving dinner party in one of our tiny, apartment living rooms.  Five of us had gotten together for a potluck-styled evening, and during the aftermath of full bellies we were all laying around and began talking about what we always talk about: dance.  If we didn't know each other beforehand because of dance, we all met in college because of it.  It's our common ground.  It's the reason we all keep moving.  And, if we have a free second, we dream about it.  That night in November was a night for dreaming.  Thoughts were thrown around, we laughed a lot, said "what if?" about 3,000 times, and then, it happened.  All of a sudden we decided it was going to be real.  We were going to start our own professional dance company.  It was like that moment when Wendy learns she can fly in Peter Pan.  She finally just lifts off, and before she knows it, she's second star to the right and straight on till morning.  That same night we began planning our premiere performance.     


Flaming Youth

Our premiere performance, Flaming Youth, is a full length dance production based completely in the 1920's.  Why the 1920's?  Because we're obsessed with the fashion.  We're in love with the finger waved hair and the blood red lips.  But, mainly, we picked the 1920's because it's a time period rife with similarities to our own, now in the 21st century.  We're all interested in what our roles and positions are, as women, in the society and culture America has put in front of us.  Are we liberated?  What does that question mean?  We are women and we all have the opportunities to go to work, school, drink in public, vote, and buy our own homes.  But, we also look at magazines every day that tell us we need a smaller waist, higher heels, Botox, longer lashes, thicker hair, smoother skin, thinner legs, and bigger breasts.  We're told that even if you are going to save the world by spear-heading a campaign to save the wolves in Alaska, we should probably still look sexy while doing it.  And we see, that even if you're a brilliant woman running for any political office or trying to run a company, you're still going to be sexually harassed and the media will probably pay more attention to your cup size then your stock holdings or poll popularity.  These all sound like the things women have been creating a dialogue about for years, but maybe that's the whole point.  If we're still talking about them, then something hasn't changed.  There is still work to be done. 

None of these concerns are so different from the 1920's.  Women believed to be liberated.  No more corsets, no more whale-boned dresses with high necks, but with that change came binding breasts and hips to achieve the stylistically popular boy-shaped figure.  What we want to show are the parallels between then and now.  Where have we come from as women?  Where are we going?  And, what stops did we make on the way?  These are some the questions we have translated into movement.  We hope our performance will not only be entertaining, but will also be thought-provoking and perhaps create a dialogue within our own community of how we all can work together to build an avenue for change.
      

The Impact


So, what's going to happen if we don't get to put on this performance?  You know, the trees aren't going to split down the middle and there aren't going to be sudden appearances of crop circles,  But, what will happen is this: a community that desperately needs a stronger, physically visual, artistic presence will not have that opportunity for continued growth.  A dance company that could have made an important, positive impact on the young girls of this community, won't make it through it's first season.  There's nothing tragic about that.  But, there is something just a wee bit tragic anytime an artistic voice is silenced.  Anytime someone is forced to hold their breath and not tell their story, well, things like that just shouldn't happen.  We feel like the reason we are here, on this earth, is to create.  We want to share everything we create in the hopes that it will spur a dialogue.  It will propel change.  The impact of this show could be a tiny drop in the ocean, but we don't believe that for a second.  In fact, we've never believed in anything more.  Our voice isn't going to be silenced.         


What We Need & What You Get

The long and short of the matter is that we mainly need money to pay our balance for our venue rental, but we also need it to pay for costumes, prop building and incidentals like having posters printed to promote our show.    Every penny we make from this page will go directly to funding the things listed above.  The $1,000 we are asking for will give us the breathing room we desperately need. It is unbelievably expensive to clothe eight dancers for a full length performance, let alone hire out the help we need to have our props built.    


We'll give you free tickets, signed posters, signed DVD's, you want to come hang out backstage and see what really happens?  We'll get you that, too.  We just want to share, share, share what we love and hope that you love it all as much as we do.  It's hard building from the ground up, and we need all the support we can get.  


Other Ways You Can Help!


Movement Continnum is hosting a fundraising event October 12th at Al's Bar, located at 6th & North Limestone in Lexington, Kentucky.  There will be poetry readings by the magnetic Bianca Spriggs and charismatic Eric Sutherland, music by musical genius, Warren Byrom, belly dancing performances by Rakadu and Mecca Dance Company, and Red Lotus Henna will be there in all her beautiful glory to do henna.  We'll also be showing our promotional trailer for Flaming Youth, filmed by the uber-talented Landon Antonetti.  It's going to be a fabulous night!  Things kick off at 7:30 p.m.  Be there and support the local artistic community! We're taking a suggested donation of $5 at the door, and you know we'll have to pass around the hat like we're at church, too. 

Check out our website:  www.kentuckymovement.com

"Like" us on facebook : www.facebook.com/movementcontinuum

Share us on facebook!

Follow us on twitter & tweet about us!  twitter.com/#!/mvmntcontinuum

Share this page with friends and family & watch our trailer!

And most importantly...come to our premiere performance on November 4th & 5th, 7:30 p.m. at the Lyric Theater!

story:
Project Summary

Our current production, Clarence Darrow by David W. Rintels, delves into the life and legal pursuits of this famous attorney whose impact is still being felt in courtrooms and in our society today. The play examines his life, his impact on our judicial system and his quest to tackle issues of social justice. This evening of living history provides the audience with an opportunity to examine the growth of our nation and to contrast the social issues from our past as they relate to our present day struggles as a society. In addition to performing Clarence Darrow on campuses and in theatres, our plan is to also perform at law conferences and law schools.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise at least $8500.00 to launch Old Shoe, promote our current production and obtain bookings. Among the items that we need to raise funds for are:

  • Implementation of on-line booking tools on website
  • Creation of printed materials
  • Membership in NACA (National Association for Campus Activities) and attending their National Convention to promote the show and obtain bookings
  • Set pieces (roll top desk, chairs, barristers bookcase) and travel cases for props and materials
  • Enclosed cargo trailer
  • Obtaining licensing to produce the show
  • start up capital for early travel costs
  • Venue rentals and showcase opportunities
  • Possibly a small RV capable of towing a trailer

The Impact of your contribution

  • Given the current social and political climate in the U.S.,where workers rights, civil rights and many aspects of social justice are once again at the forefront, we feel that Darrow's work and his message continues to resonate with audiences.
  • Your generous contribution will help us to continue to tell Darrow's story and to relay his timeless message of fairness, equality, tolerance and justice.

  • One of the goals of our crowdsourcing campaign is to cross promote artists who we have an “old shoe” relationship with by offering their creations as donation incentives. As artists, we at Old Shoe believe that we need to support one another in the pursuit of our artistic endeavors and cross promotion feels like the old shoe thing to do.

Risks & Challenges

 As with any new venture there are risks and challenges to overcome. We at Old Shoe feel that we prepared to to mitigate the risks that we foresee:

  • Booking shows on college campuses with NACA: The Old Shoe Production Company team is fortunate to have a NACA veteran of over 20 years as our Production Manager and Technical Advisor to ensure a successful launch with NACA 
  • Community theatre booking: in addition to performing on college campuses, Old Shoe will also be promoting "Clarence Darrow" to community theatres. Our initial focus will be in New England where we have contacts at the community theatre level.

Other Ways You Can Help

Old Shoe realizes that not everyone can make a monetary contribution, but that doesn't mean you can't help. Perhaps you have the following that you could donate:

  • Enclosed 4X8 cargo trailer in good condition
  • An older roll top desk and chair
  • 3 old wooden chairs (circa 1920-30's) for use in the courtroom
  • A small RV capable of pulling a cargo trailer

story:
Ending Suicides for LGBTQ Youth

Every single day in the US, 2 to 5 LGBTQ youth commit suicide.  That's around 1000 youth per year.  This is unacceptable.  I am passionately dedicated to helping to lower these numbers to zero.

Hi. I'm Pandora Scooter. I'm a spoken word artist, which means I write and perform exciting, electric poetry for my audiences.  I founded a company called standUP & standOUT productions, dedicated to providing inspiring, life-changing, and entertaining programming for LGBTQ youth.  I've been dedicated to the LGBTQ youth community/audience for 10 years now and this is my second solo show written specifically for them.

The show is called I AM ENOUGH and it is about suicide prevention and self-confidence building.  It follows the story of Pan and her struggles with rejection from family and friends for being different and being gay.  After a few suicide attempts, and the help of a fabulous counselor, Pan gets clear that she wants to live, thrive and that she is enough.

I AM ENOUGH opens the door for conversations about this very sensitive and critical topic.  It provides permission to talk about suicidal ideation and by talking about it, we can lessen the number of youth who attempt suicide.  

What We Need & What You Get

We will be touring to LGBTQ Community Centers with very limited budgets.  To offset the cost of the tour, we need to raise funds to pay for gas, food, lodging, personnel, tolls, rental vehicle and scholarships for the Centers that can't afford to pay for the show.  All told, the I AM ENOUGH tour will cost $19,100.

Here's how it breaks down:

  • Fuel (7000 miles of travel)...........$1500
  • Food.....$4200 (when we can't get meals from venues)
  • Lodging...$3500 (when we can't crash at someone's house)
  • Boxes/Tape....$400 (props for the show)
  • Scholarships.....$5000 (to cover the expense of the show for Centers that can't afford the show)
  • Tour/Merch Manager....$4500
In exchange for your generous donation, there are a wide variety of perks including House Concerts, Personalized Poems, Skype Sessions with Pandora and I AM ENOUGH swag.
If we don't raise all the money...well...we're still going on tour.  We'll have to tighten our belts a lot and possibly skip some of the Centers that can't afford the show.  If we fail miserably with the fundraising, then I'm going to use the money to film the show and post it on YouTube for LGBTQ youth to see across the US.
But let's not think that way!  If we can get 400 people to donate $50, we've got the goal covered!  And if you are considering giving (thank you!) then I bet you'd be willing to encourage some friends to give, too.
We're going to make this tour happen.  It has to!  Because:

The Impact

You can help make sure that there is:

One less LGBTQ youth suicide in the US.

And ten less suicide attempts, as well.

That's the minimum impact of the I AM ENOUGH tour.  The maximum?  Hundreds fewer suicide attempts and hundreds more conversations about suicide instead of attempts.  And maybe we keep 10, 20 or more LGBTQ youth alive.

The show has been endorsed by a child psychologist as well as another therapist who deals with LGBTQ clients and GSA Advisors.  And LGBTQ youth have endorsed it as well.

My last show OUTwordlyFabulous, which I took on tour in the southern states was a critical and popular success with the LGBTQ youth and Advisors I performed for.  The tour also broke even, with the help of sponsors and donors, like you.

Risks & Challenges

Raising almost $20K for a relatively obscure, but potent, problem like LGBTQ youth suicide isn't easy.  Our society isn't very conversant when it comes to suicide.  And people are always worried, "Well, if you talk about it, won't you encourage it?"  

Well, my 30+ years dealing my suicidal thoughts/tendencies/attempts (my own and many others) has taught me a lot.  One: Talking about suicide NEVER leads to suicide.  Two: NOT talking about suicide leads to suicide attempts.  Three:  Spotting someone who is unstable is pretty simple.  Four:  I am not a professional, and I always refer youth who confide in me to professionals in their resource Centers.

I AM ENOUGH is a responsible, inspiring and informative show about suicide prevention.  It is not going to give anyone the idea to kill themselves.  It is going to do the opposite.  It is going to give LGBTQ youth hope and a positive way to think about themselves.

So, overcoming these challenges will be difficult.  But I believe I can make the issue plain for people who are willing to listen.

Other Ways You Can Help

Hey, so if you're down for the cause, but you can't contribute, that's A-OK.  Here's some other ways you can help, please:

  • Share this END SUICIDE FOR LGBTQ YOUTH campaign on your Facebook, Instagram, Twitter pages/feeds. 
  • Call up one friend and tell them about it and ask them to donate
  • Facebook Message or Email one other friend or family member to ask them to take a look at the campaign and donate
  • If you're part of a social group, book club, softball team, knitting circle, potluck, or any other organized group, consider pitching the campaign to the group and collecting $5 or $10 from each person and then donating it on this page.
  • Don't forget to use the IndieGoGo share buttons, either.
And THANK YOU so much for reading all this! You rock!

Tour/Merch Manager....$4500 
In exchange for your generous donation, there are a wide variety of perks including House Concerts, Personalized Poems, Skype Sessions with Pandora and I AM ENOUGH swag.
If we don't raise all the money...well...we're still going on tour.  We'll have to tighten our belts a lot and possibly skip some of the Centers that can't afford the show.  If we fail miserably with the fundraising, then I'm going to use the money to film the show and post it on YouTube for LGBTQ youth to see across the US.
But let's not think that way!  If we can get 400 people to donate $50, we've got the goal covered!  And if you are considering giving (thank you!) then I bet you'd be willing to encourage some friends to give, too.
We're going to make this tour happen.  It has to!  Because:
  The Impact You can help make sure that there is:
One less LGBTQ youth suicide in the US.
And ten less suicide attempts, as well.
That's the minimum impact of the I AM ENOUGH tour.  The maximum?  Hundreds fewer suicide attempts and hundreds more conversations about suicide instead of attempts.  And maybe we keep 10, 20 or more LGBTQ youth alive.
The show has been endorsed by a child psychologist as well as another therapist who deals with LGBTQ clients and GSA Advisors.  And LGBTQ youth have endorsed it as well.
My last show OUTwordlyFabulous, which I took on tour in the southern states was a critical and popular success with the LGBTQ youth and Advisors I performed for.  The tour also broke even, with the help of sponsors and donors, like you.
Risks & Challenges
 Raising almost $20K for a relatively obscure, but potent, problem like LGBTQ youth suicide isn't easy.  Our society isn't very conversant when it comes to suicide.  And people are always worried, "Well, if you talk about it, won't you encourage it?"  
Well, my 30+ years dealing my suicidal thoughts/tendencies/attempts (my own and many others) has taught me a lot.  One: Talking about suicide NEVER leads to suicide.  Two: NOT talking about suicide leads to suicide attempts.  Three:  Spotting someone who is unstable is pretty simple.  Four:  I am not a professional, and I always refer youth who confide in me to professionals in their resource Centers.
I AM ENOUGH is a responsible, inspiring and informative show about suicide prevention.  It is not going to give anyone the idea to kill themselves.  It is going to do the opposite.  It is going to give LGBTQ youth hope and a positive way to think about themselves.
So, overcoming these challenges will be difficult.  But I believe I can make the issue plain for people who are willing to listen.
 
  Other Ways You Can Help Hey, so if you're down for the cause, but you can't contribute, that's A-OK.  Here's some other ways you can help, please:

Share this END SUICIDE FOR LGBTQ YOUTH campaign on your Facebook, Instagram, Twitter pages/feeds. 
Call up one friend and tell them about it and ask them to donate
Facebook Message or Email one other friend or family member to ask them to take a look at the campaign and donate
If you're part of a social group, book club, softball team, knitting circle, potluck, or any other organized group, consider pitching the campaign to the group and collecting $5 or $10 from each person and then donating it on this page.
Don't forget to use the IndieGoGo share buttons, either. 
And THANK YOU so much for reading all this! You rock!

story:
What is The Horror!?

The Horror! is an ensemble created immersive horror experience that explores the ideas of fear and audience choice. The style of the show allows audience members to explore different characters and storylines by mentally and physically creating their own path through the experience. This can play out in many ways- through voyeurism, audience tasks, and even one-on-one moments with the performers.

The Horror! began as a lab production at The Theatre School at DePaul University in March of 2014 and was remounted at Free Street Theatre the following October. The coming return of The Horror! will take place at Young Camelot. Their unique space is both intimate and impending and offers fantastic creative opportunities for a bigger badder horror. The project has developed an anthology style- with the core ensemble members returning for each show to create an entirely new story and experience in a new space.

Our hope for The Horror! is that it will provide an alternative to haunted houses that is grounded in the idea of creating an exciting, engaging, thought-provoking, and terrifying theatrical experience for our audience. So get ready, because The Horror! is back for round three and as goes the gospel according to Scream: Rules of a trilogy: Chapter one sets the rules. Chapter two bends the rules. But in the finale...forget the rules.


What We Need & What You Get

Young Camelot is generously providing their space for our production, however there are many expenses that go into building a production, particularly one that attempts to create the most immersive environment possible. Your contributions will be put towards:

  • Set/Props
  • Costumes
  • Practical effects (i.e. fake blood and other essentials)
  • Marketing/Advertising materials
  • Audience goodies

This production has become a labor of love. The team hopes to continue exploring this project simply because we are excited about making new discoveries and working together again to create a bigger and better production for a wider audience. No one involved is being paid from these funds. All contributions will go toward creating a higher quality experience for our audience.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that most of our supporters are not high rollers. If you can contribute please do. This could be as little as $1-5 or as much as you have in your bank account. If you are unable to contribute financially, please spread the word to your friends and any theatre or horror fans you may know. This production will only be possible with your help, and whatever form that takes is greatly appreciated.

The Horror! Ensemble includes:

Drew Beyer

Andrew Huber

Ian Miller

Abbie O'Donnell

Jill Perez

Jordyn Prince 

Raquel Villalobos 

Connor Wang 

Dramaturgy by: Kaysie Bekkela

Original Music by: Eric Richardson

Managed by: Colleen Debelius

Produced by: Bryce Sommer

Directed by: Lauren Fields

story:
Hi, we are A.N.O.N Productions, a theatre company dedicated to producing plays by, adapted from, and inspired by The Bard.

After our successful run of As You Like It this spring, we are delighted to announce our next production of Hamlet, to be opening in the fall. We have a wonderful team assembled are excited about getting started.


ABOUT THIS PRODUCTION OF HAMLET: This production was inspired by issues raised by the He For She campaign and the desire to make the characters and issues of the show gender universal (after all, there is female protagonist of a Shakespearian tragedy, and yet the themes and issues of Hamlet relate just as much to women. Likewise Ophelia's issues can very much resonate with men.) It's set ever so slightly in the future in a highly militarized society where Hamlet is a woman who has been raised as a man for succession purposes. Horatio is the highest ranking woman in the military, Ophelia is a slightly effeminate, sensitive (in contrast to the militarized society) man, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are the "Queen Bees" of Wittenberg, and Horatio is the only high ranking woman in the military (all the other roles are "gender appropriate.")


However, in order to get started we need your help. We are looking to raise $6000 dollars to put this wonderful production on. We are dedicated to paying our wonderful team of performers and technicians and if we surpass our goal , we have been given the opportunity to, not only transfer this show to a theatre in New Jersey, but to take it across the Atlantic to a fringe theatre in the UK.

We thank you for any assistance, and in return, we will grant you some special perks.

story:
Welcome to Theater Boleyn!

Theater Boleyn was founded in 2013 by Serena Pomerantz and Katie Adams, two theater artists who wanted to create a stir in the Chicago theater scene. Theater Boleyn is devoted to performing interactive pieces of theater that will not only entertain the audience, but will also enlighten and give a newfound appreciation for the classical playwrights of yesterday.

Theater Boleyn is committed to making Elizabethan, neoclassical, Restoration, and beyond understandable and enjoyable to the modern audience. We strive to get people of all ages, backgrounds, and means to simply go to the theater. Each production is performed in the environment that the play takes place in and will constantly keep the audience engaged and involved in the production. In addition, we will run classes to children and adults that will range from acting classes to theater appreciation classes. These classes also plan to stretch out to other communities, particularly those of underprivileged youth.

Theater Boleyn is ready to show everyone that heightened language, corsets, and the past are relevant and accessible.

But We Need Your Help.

Theater Boleyn is committed to producing a high-quality production and paying its actors, stage managers, directors, designers, and all the other unsung heroes who go into making a production thrive. We need your help in order to rent a space in Chicago, pay for sets, costumes, and give the hard-working artists a token of what they deserve. Your help will also allow us to begin teaching classes in the greater Chicago area as soon as possible.

The Impact of Your Help.

We will give back to the community fully-staged and affordable professional productions that help make classical theater accessible to people of all ages and backgrounds. We will strip down unneeded high concepts that are often added to productions and bring them back to a focus on language, story, and theme. The audience will be completely involved in the story from the start, following the characters around their journeys.

It isn't ingrained in people's blood, especially that of young people, to want to go to the theater, let alone to a play with language that seems overwhelming, but with your help, we can bring appreciation back to Chicago. Your help will also give us the resources to beginning running classes to the greater Chicago community. We will be providing two different types of classes, one for professional development and one for community outreach.

You will help fund classes such as:

-Brush up Your Scansion
-Play Appreciation
-Scene Study 
-Elizabethan Styles and Movement
-Dialect Work

Thank you again for supporting Theater Boleyn.

story:
Short Summary

Uprising is a new play by Samantha Lee Manas and Jasmine Brown that combines the lessons of the turn of the century labor movement and Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire with a look at labor today in an innovative way.  Live theater scenes about the uprising and fire will be interwoven with interviews with labor leaders and historians to help us look at labor from both a historical and modern viewpoint.  This play not only will show what people can achieve when they band together, but what young women can achieve almost entirely on their own. No matter what side of the issue you are on, labor is currently both losing and gaining ground.  Let's take a deeper look together. Thank you for your support!

Written by Jasmine Brown and Samantha Lee Manas

Directed by Samantha Lee Manas

Starring: Kent Abbett, Stephanie Alvarez, Justin Bennett*, Alicia Giangrsostomi*, Lisa Younger*, Michelle Cammarata, Tierney Nolen,  Erica Becker, Sophia Sapronov, Sam Charny, Brian Kirn, Stephen Stapinski, Anna Stefanic*, and Alex Miskin

*appearing courtesy of Actors Equity Association

Crew: Lauren Bremen and Jabari Clarke-Pennegen

Producing Company Members: Graydon Gund and Karl Custer

What We Need & What You Get

We need this money to put on a show that will be both accurate and inventive.

Costume rentals: $1800 

Lighting: $200

Set: $200

Video: $500

Actors: $300

    The Impact

    Uprising  will explore an important issue in the life of workers and politics today, while encouraging further discussion on the usefulness of unions and what acceptable working conditions should be. In the tradition of playwrights like Brecht, we strive to bring about a play that will cause the audience to think and afterward act on those thoughts.

    Between Us Productions is committed to bringing daring and compelling theater to our audiences and pushing our boundaries as artists. Likewise, it is important to us to support artists who share our commitment to performing relevant work.  Since its inception in 2010, Between Us has presented two full length productions, two 10 minute play festivals, one evening of one acts, and countless readings and variety shows. Uprising will mark their third full production.

      Risks & Challenges

      The largest risk of this piece is that we may be sending a message that will not appeal to all.  Unions and the labor movement have become such divisive issues that no matter what stance you take, not everyone will agree.  However, we welcome this discussion and are hoping that the risk will pay off when this play becomes a catalyst for further discussion of the issue.

        Other Ways You Can Help

        Want to help?  Obviously, giving to our campaign will be a great way to help.  However, if you are not in a position to give, please share our campaign with all your friends and family.  Tell them how important the story of these girls is and encourage them to give. Thank you for your support!

story:
What We Want To Do

  • We are a new Theatre company based in Dublin born to stage Shakespeare's work.
  • We are a profit-share company, focused on making it possible to stage our favourite Shakespeare play.
  • We are passionate about putting on one of Shakespeare's lesser known plays, The Winter's Tale. We feel it has magical things to say to us about jealousy, friendship, speaking the truth and the redemptive powers of art.
  • The play will be on for a 5 night run in June in The Teacher's Club, in Dublin.
  • Your contribution would mean a great deal to us. Contributions would help us mainly with costs of renting the Theatre venue for a week.  Your contributions will also help with costs associated with making the costumes, simple staging material, and with smaller details such as printing etc. All of these things will make it possible for us to stage this wonderful play by Shakespeare. We will be so very grateful to you for your contribution!

What We Need & What You Get

To be precise:

  • We need 1200 euro so that we can cover the cost of renting the Theatre space for five nights.
  • We'll need approximately 50 euro for costume-making, for threads and dye etc.
  • We'll need approx. 100 euro for printing of promotional Posters, Fliers and programmes, and printing of scripts.
  • We'll need approx. 50 euro for props.
  • We are delighted to offer you unique perks for your donations.
  • If we don't reach our goal, anything we do receive will still be put towards the renting of the Theatre space for the 5 night run.

The Impact Of Your Contribution

The difference your contribution can make:

  • We bring our playfulness and creativity to Shakespeare. Using bedsheets for costumes and set,  we believe in more than just recreating the traditional. We believe Shakespeare's stories and words still have the power to move us today. The Winter's Tale features some of Shakespeare's most outspoken female characters. There are wonderful moments when they take huge risks by speaking their truth. 
  • Our director Sarah Bradley recently graduated from TCD Drama and Theatre Studies. She has written and directed many plays, including A Midsummer Dream for The Trinity College Shakespeare Festival. 
  • While this is Bedsheet Theatre Company's first ever production, we are being kindly assisted by the Burning House Productions, who have staged several plays in Dublin and around Ireland. They are lending us their experience and support to ensure we fulfill our goal of staging Shakespeare's The Winter's Tale, so that more people can breath-in this story by seeing it performed live.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If it is not possible for you to contribute at this time, there are other ways you can help:

  • Please spread the word about our campaign, in person and online. 
  • Feel free to use the share tools to spread the word on facebook 

Thank you so much from all of us at Bedsheet Shakespeare Company and Burning House Productions.
