story:
Why do we need your help?

LivelyWood Pictures, producers of the show in association with South Hill Park Arts Centre, needs your help to be able to get this production to the Edinburgh Fringe. Taking a show to the Fringe can be an expensive, but invaluable task. We would like your help to cover some of the costs involved in taking a show to the Fringe. In return you will receive the benefits detailed in the appropriate 'Perk'. With your help, this production can be seen by thousands of people, and potentially possible to be on tour in 2014, celebrating Charlie Chaplin's Centenary year since bursting onto our screens in 1914 - This is an important target for us to achieve, and your help will edge us closer to achieving this.

The Show

Spencer Franks, a young actor played by Clive Elkington, has been given the chance to step into the hat, the cane and the moustache of his idol, as well as those not so little tramp shoes. In the moments before he goes on stage, whilst running through his lines, he talks himself through the highs and lows of Charlie Chaplin’s life, emanating pure inspiration from the film legend as he aspires to recreate his success. Spencer draws on the enthusiasm and influence of Chaplin a hundred years ago, through the trials and tribulations that still pushed him further through his career no matter what, making him a world famous film star before the end of World War I. Mixing live theatre and multimedia, with a great big toothy grin and the inspiration of a legend behind him, Spencer takes the audience through it all. With Chaplin’s centenary year in sight since bursting onto our screens, this production, approved by the Charlie Chaplin estate based in France, is a visual and visceral story of two men’s ingenuity.

The History

Back in April 2011, this whole process began. Initially, finding a pre-existing one man show about was difficult, so we went on the hunt for a writer. When we came across JeTamme Derouet, immediately we were throwing ideas together about what we wanted in the show and JeTamme's sheer knowledge and expertise on Chaplin was superior - we knew she was right for the job. An original show was performed in October 2012 under the title 'The Man, The Myth, The Legend'. It has since gone on to be adapted by David Wembridge and the new version of the show, 'The Hat, The Cane, The Moustache' will preview at South Hill Park, Bracknell in July, before heading to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in August.

What We Need and What You Get

We have set our target to £1800, which is actually only a small fraction of the cost involved with taking a show to The Fringe. This amount will mostly help us to pay for accomodation so that we don't have to sleep in the workhouse for 5 weeks.

All donations, including any we receive beyond our target will be gratefully received and will help to cover other costs, for example: travel, living costs, administration, set, printing.

The best bit, what do you get in return? Well...

£10 - You will receive a flyer for the Edinburgh production, signed by the cast.... Well, Clive. (It's a one man show), as well as updates about the production on it's road to The Fringe, whilst at The Fringe, and after The Fringe if it goes on tour in 2014. (Please supply email address for the updates).

£25 - You will get your name in the programme as a supporter of the show, as well as a signed flyer and updates about the show (email required).

£50 - You will be IN the show. A photo of you will dress the set alongside other donaters of this level. As well as a signed flyer, updates about the show (email required) and your name in the programme.

£100 - You will receive your own personal copy of the script, signed by Clive. As well as a signed flyer, updates about the show (email required), name in the programme and photo of you in the show.

£500 - You will receive Legend status, lots of major thanks and a bottle of champagne. Ok, seriously. If you donate this, you will be noted as a sponsor of the show, and if you have a company or similar, we will place your logo on the programme and links to your website will be posted on our social media pages. You will also receive a complimentary ticket to see the show either at South Hill Park (19-20 July) or Edinburgh (1-26 Aug). As well as, a signed flyer, updates about the show (email required), name in the programme, personal signed copy of the script and photo of you in the show.

The Impact

Every penny will help here and will be gratefully received.

We would like the opportunity to celebrate the centenary year of Chaplin next year, and by doing Edinburgh Fringe Festival helps that target of being a little closer than before. You will be making it possible by donating, and we could not be more thankful for it.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate anything, or not that much, other ways you can help us is by simply supporting the show by coming to watch, and telling others about it.

Please share the following links, and if you haven't already, please 'like' or 'follow' them yourselves:

Facebook: www.facebook.com/ChaplinEdFringe 
Twitter: www.twitter.com/ChaplinEdFringe

You can book tickets for the PREVIEWS at South Hill Park here: http://www.southhillpark.org.uk/8769/shows/the-hat-the-cane-the-moustache.html

You can book tickets for the EDINBURGH Run at C Venues - C too here: https://www.edfringe.com/whats-on/theatre/hat-the-cane-the-moustache

You can also share this campaign by using the link given towards the top of the page.

The Team

JeTamme Derouet, Writer – Biographer, copy writer and Charlie Chaplin historian.

David Wembridge, Writer, adaptations – David is one half of theatre company ‘Too Many Daves’ under which he has written, directed and performed in a number of productions.

Luke Burton, Director – Luke is a Producer and Studio Theatre Manager at South Hill Park Arts Centre. Also, as an actor, Luke has performed in a wide array of productions.

Clive Elkington, Producer (LivelyWood Pictures), ‘Spencer’ – Clive has been acting for over 10 years and has performed roles in a number of different productions, on stage and on screen. Clive was one of a number of performers who performed across 3 of the 4 ceremonies of the London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic games. He set up LivelyWood Pictures in 2011 with the aim to create and provide work for other fellow actors who may have time out of work but still would like to be doing something relevant to the industry they enjoy working in so much.

South Hill Park, Producer – South Hill Park is an Arts Centre of great distinction in the South East. A key part of South Hill Park’s remit is supporting and commissioning new work across the arts, from both established and emerging artists. South Hill Park’s supporting statement: “South Hill Park is supporting “The Hat, The Cane, The Moustache” because we could see so much potential in the early R and D stage which we hosted last year. We are working with Clive Elkington to develop the show as we believe it has the potential to be a real Edinburgh hit and a popular touring show. Clive has a passion for the work of Charlie Chaplin and an uncanny ability to portray him physically. He has a charming storytelling style which will hold audiences mesmerised from start to finish. SHP is delighted to help mould this piece of work and to assist taking it to Edinburgh to reach the industry and a wider public.” – Ron McAllister, Chief Executive.

Bubbles Inc./Roy Export S.A.S, Charles Chaplin Estate - Bubbles Inc. owns the merchandising rights in and to the Chaplin name and image. Bubbles Inc was set up in 1972 for merchandising of the unique character Charles Chaplin created – The Little Tramp. Since so many years went into the development of the character, Bubbles Inc does not license the use of the image without taking into consideration the quality of the article manufactured by potential licensees, their reputation, and above all the image of the Little Tramp that they propose to use. Though it is true that it needs but a bowler hat and cane to inspire instant recognition, products should be as close to the feeling and personality of the Little Tramp as possible. There is a lasting quality to the Little Tramp – his image appeals to all age groups, even to those too young to have seen a whole Chaplin film. Bubbles Inc aims to keep the character present in these "modern times". We are not simply licensing an image, but the lifetime’s work which that image represents. Roy Export Company Establishment which owns the copyrights and other relevant rights to all films made by Chaplin from 1918 onwards. Association also manages the Chaplin Archives and serves as a link between the above mentioned companies and the Chaplin family. The only members of the Association are also members of the Chaplin family.

story:
“ . . . far better than others with similarly provocative titles... a skit... may be the funniest of the year.”

- Neil Genzlinger, New York Times, Naked Holidays

“Honest and courageous, Naked Holidays steps outside the Disney-filled Christmas box by offering something entertaining, raw, and audaciously clever. This excitingly raunchy, provocative show will become more of a holiday tradition than egg nog and mistletoe.”

-Christina Mancuso, broadwayworld.com, Naked Holidays

“Pushing theater to the edge fearlessly and perhaps even wantonly . . . unlike anything else that’s playing in New York at the moment”

-Martin Denton, newyorktheater.com, Vignettes for the Apocalypse

“ . . . as absurd, senseless, and unabashed as the subject material itself and, as such, it works beautifully.”

- Andrew Turner, stageandcinema.com, Manson the Musical

“Top of the 2009 crop . . . creepy-sexy and dependably weird . . . As Fringe shows go this is a veritable bear on a trike.”

- Robert Avilla, SF Bay Guardian, The Godling

 

 

THIS IS ENDTIMES

EndTimes is an independent Theater/Film Production Company founded in New York City in 2006. Since then, EndTimes has produced 10 Full-Length Productions, and over 100 short plays, involving the talents of more than 300 theater artists. The company has performed in the New York, San Francisco, and Edinburgh Fringe Festivals, winning top honors for Best Production, Best Director, and Best Ensemble at the San Francisco Fringe Festival in 2008 for William Whitehursts Knuckleball, and again in 2009 for Mark Borkowskis The Godling. EndTimes also won the Best Production award in 2010 for its presentation of Jamie King's TMZTV at the Shortened Attention Span Festival. EndTimes has been widely featured in various publications, including, Time Out New York, The New York Times, The Huffington Post, The San Francisco Chronicle, The New York Post, The Daily News, and Broadwayworld.com. 

EndTimes focuses on work that is dark and satiric, with an underlying element of social commentary. Incorporating dance, music, vaudeville, and comedy, we produce high-energy, entertaining theater that is aimed at a wider audience than more traditional forms. Drawing for inspiration from sources as varied as the Marx Brothers, Alice Cooper, Robert Anton Wilson, Del Close, the Annoyance, and George Romero, EndTimes merges popular forms with the ancient tradition of live performance to create a theater experience that is appealing and accessible to modern audiences.

 

 

WHERE WE'RE GOING

EndTimes has been truly blessed over the past year, garnering critical acclaim, and finding an amazing new home at The 133rd Street Arts Center.  Starting with an empty building one year ago, EndTimes has gradually renovated the space, offering rehearsal and performance opportunities to local artists, for a fraction of the price of downtown facilities.  As a result, the formerly empty space, is now alive with activity around the clock, and its black box theater books out 6 months in advance.  

EndTimes has also used the freedom from outrageous downtown rental costs to launch a new division, The EndTimes Bunker, under the leadership of former Managing Director Matthew Kreiner, whose focus is the development of new works from new writers.

Artistically, EndTimes also raised the bar this year, moving Naked Holidays from its downtown home (RIP Ace of Clubs), to its first Off-Broadway level production, at The Times Square Arts Center, selling out most of the run to a primarily out-of-town audience.  Its been a long, strange, wild trip for a troupe that faced financial collapse not so very long ago.  But to keep moving onward and upward, we need a little help from our friends.

 

 

Our new home needs a lot of work.  To really become the fully functioning arts facility that it could be, we need to replace floors and ceilings, hire a contractor to fix the terminally leaky roof, lay down sound proofing between our two active floors, and even run heat to our rehearsal studio, which we’re currently forced to close down for the winter.  Its an old building, that’s been neglected for a long time.  To really make it come alive again is going to take funds.  By contributing those funds, you aren't only helping one company, you're helping to provide a much needed low-cost facility to the entire New York arts community.

 

 

OUR SEASON
(or.... "WHY WE NEED TO RAISE MONEY.")

 This season will be our most ambitious yet.  Here's how it breaks down:

Vignettes for the Apocalypse

The festival that started it all, and has gone on to become New York's oldest and largest horror/sci-fi themed theater festival.  This year we'll be presenting 15 short new works, one new full-length, and a reimagining of Karel Capek's classic "RUR", the play that first coined the term  "robot."  Playing 9/19-9/30, at the The 133rd Street Arts Center. The best part? It's happening now. We mounted this multi-show festival on our own just to prove we could. Come and see it, and see why we're worth fostering. Because it leads up to...

Naked Holidays

New York's favorite and most anticipated anti-holiday holiday bacchanalia returns to The Times Square Arts Center, and this time its personal.  Meaning EndTimes is personally writing the entire show.  This year we've hired a full band, an amazing dance corps, a puppeteer, and a lot of people who at various times and in various places have been known to be naked.  The budget for this one has doubled year over year for the past three years.  Without your help, we may just have to keep our clothes on this time.  Believe it, or not, its cheaper.  Playing 11/30-12/30, at The Times Square Arts Center. And right after we take the manger underwear off, box up the tiny penis hat, and flame throw the last fleck of tinsel....

Stephen King in High School: The Musical

Stephen King's senior year in high school is a tough year. With the super flu slowly killing the student body, the principle seeming more and more like an evil killer clown, and his best friend being sexually harassed by his living car, Stephen's finding it really hard to finish his first novel. When a waifish new transfer student with an active mind floats into town, Stephen can't seem to keep his head in the page. Can he finish his magnum opus before the principle and his maniac English teacher literally squeeze it out of him?

EndTimes first musical since its long-running hit, Manson: The Musical, and the first musical scripted and composed entirely by the EndTimes company, we're really excited about this one, and we hope you can help us to make it happen.  Playing 4/1-4/28, at The Times Square Arts Center.  

The EndTimes Bunker 

Headed up by Artistic Director, Matthew Kreiner, The Bunker will present both readings and full mountings of new works, as well as taking a stab at the classics.  At least if we can talk Matthew into bloodying up The Miser a bit.  Through The Bunker, EndTimes continues its long-standing mission of supporting new works from new writers.

Yeah, its a really big season.  We've been accused of a lot of things (theft, arson, meth, camp, bribary, madness, etc.), but no one's ever accused us of being lazy.  Now that James Brown's dead, we're the hardest working people in showbusiness, and through our productions and facilities, EndTimes makes an enormous positive impact on the local arts community.  

If you can help out with a contribution, that's amazing. We'll show our amazement and gratitude with a personal thank you, and one of the nifty gifts to the right.

And even if you cant contribute, please spread the word via Facebook, Twitter, Text, Likes, Retweets, and foggy Instagram pictures. Shout your barbaric yawp over the rooftops of Brooklyn.  Let people know the campaign is happening. Tell as many people as you can about EndTimes Productions efforts to put together the best season ever.

Thanks to everyone who has supported EndTimes over the years, and continues to make our work possible. 

We have provided a creative home for hundreds of theater artists during the past five seasons, and will continue to create a space where artists can try out the craziest thing they've ever thought of doing, in an environment that fully supports that choice.
story_txt:
“ . . . far better than others with similarly provocative titles... a skit... may be the funniest of the year.”
- Neil Genzlinger, New York Times, Naked Holidays
“Honest and courageous, Naked Holidays steps outside the Disney-filled Christmas box by offering something entertaining, raw, and audaciously clever. This excitingly raunchy, provocative show will become more of a holiday tradition than egg nog and mistletoe.”
-Christina Mancuso, broadwayworld.com, Naked Holidays
“Pushing theater to the edge fearlessly and perhaps even wantonly . . . unlike anything else that’s playing in New York at the moment”
-Martin Denton, newyorktheater.com, Vignettes for the Apocalypse
“ . . . as absurd, senseless, and unabashed as the subject material itself and, as such, it works beautifully.”
- Andrew Turner, stageandcinema.com, Manson the Musical
“Top of the 2009 crop . . . creepy-sexy and dependably weird . . . As Fringe shows go this is a veritable bear on a trike.”
- Robert Avilla, SF Bay Guardian, The Godling
 

 
THIS IS ENDTIMES
EndTimes is an independent Theater/Film Production Company founded in New York City in 2006. Since then, EndTimes has produced 10 Full-Length Productions, and over 100 short plays, involving the talents of more than 300 theater artists. The company has performed in the New York, San Francisco, and Edinburgh Fringe Festivals, winning top honors for Best Production, Best Director, and Best Ensemble at the San Francisco Fringe Festival in 2008 for William Whitehursts Knuckleball, and again in 2009 for Mark Borkowskis The Godling. EndTimes also won the Best Production award in 2010 for its presentation of Jamie King's TMZTV at the Shortened Attention Span Festival. EndTimes has been widely featured in various publications, including, Time Out New York, The New York Times, The Huffington Post, The San Francisco Chronicle, The New York Post, The Daily News, and Broadwayworld.com. 
EndTimes focuses on work that is dark and satiric, with an underlying element of social commentary. Incorporating dance, music, vaudeville, and comedy, we produce high-energy, entertaining theater that is aimed at a wider audience than more traditional forms. Drawing for inspiration from sources as varied as the Marx Brothers, Alice Cooper, Robert Anton Wilson, Del Close, the Annoyance, and George Romero, EndTimes merges popular forms with the ancient tradition of live performance to create a theater experience that is appealing and accessible to modern audiences.
 

 
WHERE WE'RE GOING
EndTimes has been truly blessed over the past year, garnering critical acclaim, and finding an amazing new home at The 133rd Street Arts Center.  Starting with an empty building one year ago, EndTimes has gradually renovated the space, offering rehearsal and performance opportunities to local artists, for a fraction of the price of downtown facilities.  As a result, the formerly empty space, is now alive with activity around the clock, and its black box theater books out 6 months in advance.  

EndTimes has also used the freedom from outrageous downtown rental costs to launch a new division, The EndTimes Bunker, under the leadership of former Managing Director Matthew Kreiner, whose focus is the development of new works from new writers.

Artistically, EndTimes also raised the bar this year, moving Naked Holidays from its downtown home (RIP Ace of Clubs), to its first Off-Broadway level production, at The Times Square Arts Center, selling out most of the run to a primarily out-of-town audience.  Its been a long, strange, wild trip for a troupe that faced financial collapse not so very long ago.  But to keep moving onward and upward, we need a little help from our friends.
 

 
Our new home needs a lot of work.  To really become the fully functioning arts facility that it could be, we need to replace floors and ceilings, hire a contractor to fix the terminally leaky roof, lay down sound proofing between our two active floors, and even run heat to our rehearsal studio, which we’re currently forced to close down for the winter.  Its an old building, that’s been neglected for a long time.  To really make it come alive again is going to take funds.  By contributing those funds, you aren't only helping one company, you're helping to provide a much needed low-cost facility to the entire New York arts community.
 

 

OUR SEASON(or.... "WHY WE NEED TO RAISE MONEY.")

 This season will be our most ambitious yet.  Here's how it breaks down:

Vignettes for the Apocalypse
The festival that started it all, and has gone on to become New York's oldest and largest horror/sci-fi themed theater festival.  This year we'll be presenting 15 short new works, one new full-length, and a reimagining of Karel Capek's classic "RUR", the play that first coined the term  "robot."  Playing 9/19-9/30, at the The 133rd Street Arts Center. The best part? It's happening now. We mounted this multi-show festival on our own just to prove we could. Come and see it, and see why we're worth fostering. Because it leads up to...

Naked Holidays
New York's favorite and most anticipated anti-holiday holiday bacchanalia returns to The Times Square Arts Center, and this time its personal.  Meaning EndTimes is personally writing the entire show.  This year we've hired a full band, an amazing dance corps, a puppeteer, and a lot of people who at various times and in various places have been known to be naked.  The budget for this one has doubled year over year for the past three years.  Without your help, we may just have to keep our clothes on this time.  Believe it, or not, its cheaper.  Playing 11/30-12/30, at The Times Square Arts Center. And right after we take the manger underwear off, box up the tiny penis hat, and flame throw the last fleck of tinsel....

Stephen King in High School: The Musical
Stephen King's senior year in high school is a tough year. With the super flu slowly killing the student body, the principle seeming more and more like an evil killer clown, and his best friend being sexually harassed by his living car, Stephen's finding it really hard to finish his first novel. When a waifish new transfer student with an active mind floats into town, Stephen can't seem to keep his head in the page. Can he finish his magnum opus before the principle and his maniac English teacher literally squeeze it out of him?
EndTimes first musical since its long-running hit, Manson: The Musical, and the first musical scripted and composed entirely by the EndTimes company, we're really excited about this one, and we hope you can help us to make it happen.  Playing 4/1-4/28, at The Times Square Arts Center.  

The EndTimes Bunker 
Headed up by Artistic Director, Matthew Kreiner, The Bunker will present both readings and full mountings of new works, as well as taking a stab at the classics.  At least if we can talk Matthew into bloodying up The Miser a bit.  Through The Bunker, EndTimes continues its long-standing mission of supporting new works from new writers.

Yeah, its a really big season.  We've been accused of a lot of things (theft, arson, meth, camp, bribary, madness, etc.), but no one's ever accused us of being lazy.  Now that James Brown's dead, we're the hardest working people in showbusiness, and through our productions and facilities, EndTimes makes an enormous positive impact on the local arts community.  
If you can help out with a contribution, that's amazing. We'll show our amazement and gratitude with a personal thank you, and one of the nifty gifts to the right.
And even if you cant contribute, please spread the word via Facebook, Twitter, Text, Likes, Retweets, and foggy Instagram pictures. Shout your barbaric yawp over the rooftops of Brooklyn.  Let people know the campaign is happening. Tell as many people as you can about EndTimes Productions efforts to put together the best season ever.

Thanks to everyone who has supported EndTimes over the years, and continues to make our work possible. 
We have provided a creative home for hundreds of theater artists during the past five seasons, and will continue to create a space where artists can try out the craziest thing they've ever thought of doing, in an environment that fully supports that choice.

story:
The Phoenix Project is a creative arts workshop that was born out the desires of two women, Laura Gosheff and Sheri Heller, to share the healing and reclamation that they experienced through the writing and telling of their own stories in LET THE PHOENIX RISE!, a play that dramatizes the lives of four teenage girls beset by abuse and neglect, and their ultimate triumph over adversity. Through the creative process, the writers discovered that art transcends class, gender, and race barriers, and has the potential to teach, inspire, and catalyze insight and action. It has the ability to move past the mechanisms we use for daily survival, and touch our souls; it makes the sub-conscious conscious. The artistic exploration and expression of one’s life is a courageous act, and it carries tremendous impact and hope for those suffering from the repercussions of childhood abuse and trauma.

By bridging the creative arts with psychological and spiritual healing, The Phoenix Project’s mission is to inspire marginalized, traumatized, and culturally under-served women and girls in the public sector of New York City to give creative expression to their traumatic histories, and to find creative solutions to life’s conflicts by using LTPR! as a catalyst and reference for healing and self-reclamation. The Phoenix Project aspires to amplify its potential for offering a powerful healing experience for workshop participants from treatment facilities servicing women and girls, by collaborating with myriad organizations that offer diverse forms of artistic expression.

Let the Phoenix RiseA Sistah Tribe Production is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Let the Phoenix RiseA Sistah Tribe Production must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Who We Are:

The Group Theatre Too is a theatre collective based in Manhattan.  2013 marks our tenth year producing quality, entertaining theatre.  Our newest play, YANKEE WIVES, by David Rimmer, opens August 28th at the Hudson Guild Theater in New York City.

The Play:

Yankee Wives, by David Rimmer (Pulitzer Finalist for Album; author of New York) is a sexy, irreverent look behind the scenes at six women thrown together because their husbands happen to play for the same Major League baseball team. Yankee Wives shows the often comic side of being married to big babies with big egos, who often succumb to big temptations on the road. The play exposes the real personalities behind the smiling surface and how the wives cope with living simultaneously in the spotlight and in the shadow of their husbands. Ultimately these women create a team-within-a-team.

What We Need:

Producing a play is expensive, but you can help us reach our goals.  Below are some of the costs we plan to cover using the funds raised on Indiegogo:

- Theater Rental

- Rehearsal Studio Rental

- Set Construction

- Prop Rental

- Costuming

- Transportation (Sets, Props, Actors, etc.)

How You Can Help:

Our campaign offers many levels of pledging, all with exciting perks.  We know that YANKEE WIVES will be an uplifting experience for audiences.  It is a universal story with a strong message about love, betrayal and forgiveness.  Please help us bring it to life!

story:
Infinite Expectation of the Dawn

Human rights are inalienable, unassailable, unquestionable. But sometimes, we sacrifice our rights for a greater good.

Set in the dystopian world after the United States suffers Civil War II, “Infinite Expectation of the Dawn” weaves the stories of Joan and Alicia, two perspectives from a country burdened with fear, who both made personal sacrifices to create their ideal reality.

“We must learn to reawaken and keep ourselves awake, not by mechanical means, but by an infinite expectation of the dawn, which does not forsake us even in our soundest sleep.” Henry David Thoreau. 

Who I Am

“Infinite Expectation of the Dawn” is an expanded version of a 10-minute solo performance created as part of Marya Sea Kaminski’s class at Freehold Studios, which I attended in 2012. That original work questioned what people are willing to give up for safety, and the true definition of “Freedom” in a country that no longer teaches skepticism or craftsmanship. 

As a theatre artist, I focus on new, locally-written theatre, and believe in the amazing talent collected in Seattle. I recently participated in Director’s Lab West 2014, and have worked with such wonderful Seattle theatre companies as Annex Theatre, Live Girls! Theatre, Taproot Theatre Company, and Ear to the Ground. I have also worked on shows with Cornish College of the Arts, Theater Schmeater, and Work It Productions’ Shakespeare on the Troll. My one-woman show, “best-of-craigslist: Live!” went to the Portland Mini-Fringe Festival in 2011, and if you buy me a margarita, I might talk about my very first solo performance, “Sockpuppet MacBeth.” 

The Impact

Basically, I need financial help with this show. While I'll have some income from ticket sales, that will most likely cover my venue costs and little else. I need a costume, and most importantly, I'd like to pay the design team I'm gathering. 

I estimate that I will need $750 - not much, but enough to cover costuming, lights and sound designer, and marketing design and production. I'm not asking for payment for myself, just to cover production costs. 

Risks & Challenges

This show is designed to run on very little budget, but if I don't make my goal, I won't be able to pay my small production team as much. What I do pay them will come out of my own pocket. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't throw $5 to this - and trust me, I understand - then please help by spreading the word in other ways. 

    • "Infinite Expectation of the Dawn" will run as part of the Seattle Fringe Festival, September 17th - 21st, 2014. Please come see it, and let people know it's happening!
    • Repost this fundraiser and ask people to help!

    You guys are all awesome! Thanks for your support!

story:
The renovation of the building of Soltis Lajos Theater

In 1980 a theatre group was established in the village of Sitke. In 2001 we migrated to nearby Celldömölk, where we adopted the name of 'Lajos Soltis'. Soltis Lajos Theater is a nonprofit organization. Our new home used to be the building of the old town cinema and its acoustics and layout are very suitable for an alternative theatre, a studio theatre. Being an alternative theatre group in the countryside has always been a real challenge. We are a poor theatre, yet we try to do our utmost to fulfill the expectations of this kind of theatre idea, using all our strength and experience. If we want to create something, either a performance, a set or costumes of a play or a tour, we must work at it with blood, sweat and tears. Team spirit has always been very strong here. Here work has a certain sanctity, and everyone has a suitable attitude. Perhaps that is the most important thing.


We give 150 performances a year for over 20 000 spectators.

People used to say that the very existance of this group is a totally special natural phenomena, like... finding some delicate flower in a desert. They wonder about how it got there and how does it survive.


Now we would like to save and renew the building which we work in. The entire work will cost around 44 000 dollars, and we can pay only the half of it. Please support us, to let this unique community and theater work on.

Be a sponsor and feel at home in our place!


Other ways you can help

No amount is too small, but we understand that making a donation is not possible for everyone. You can still be a huge help to us by simply spreading the word about our campaign and sharing our video on facebook and twitter. You can use the IndieGoGo share tools to make this easier. You can also follow us on Facebook! 

Thank you for your attention!


Hungarian translation:

1980-ban Sitkén megalakult egy falusi színjátszó csoport. 2001-ben átköltöztünk Celldömölkre és felvettük a Soltis Lajos nevet. A Soltis Lajos Színház egy közhasznú, nonprofit szervezet. A volt városi mozi épülete, ami egyébként az akusztikája, és mindenféle elrendezése révén is nagyon is alkalmas egy alternatív színház, egy kamaraszínház működésére. Vidéken alternatív színházként működni  igazi kihívás. Szegény színház vagyunk, és minden erőnkkel, tudásunkkal azon munkálkodunk, hogy ennek a színházi ideának az elvárásainak tudjunk megfelelni. Ha valamit akarunk létrehozni, legyen az egy előadás, vagy egy előadás díszlete, jelmezei akár, vagy egy turné, akkor azért vérrel-verítékkel meg kell dolgozni. Nálunk mindig is nagyon jó csapatszellem volt. Itt van szentsége a munkának, és mindenkiben megfelelő a hozzáállás. Talán ez a legfontosabb.

Évente nagyjából 150 előadást tartunk, több mint 20 ezer nézőnek.

Szokták mondani, hogy ez egy teljesen különleges természeti jelenség, hogy ez a csoport egyáltalán létezik, tehát minthogyha a sivatagban találnék egy virágot és nézném, hogy ez most hogyan él itt meg.

Most szeretnénk felújítani a színházunknak otthont adó épület külsejét, és ehhez kérjük az Önök segítségét! A teljes munka közel 44 000 dollárba kerül, aminek a felét vagyunk képesek előteremteni. Kérjük, támogassanak minket, hogy ez az egyedülálló közösség és színházi műhely tovább működhessen!

Legyen a szponzorunk és érezze otthon magát nálunk!


További lehetőség a segítségre

Nincs az a kis összeg, mely ne lenne fontos számunkra, de tudjuk, hogy nem áll módjában mindenkinek támogatni minket. Az is hatalmas segítség lehet, ha Ön megosztja, terjeszti kampányunkat ismerősei között, továbbá a facebookon vagy a twitteren!

Köszönjük a figyelmet!

story:
SPECIAL NOTE: 

As of December 28,  with delight and gratitude, we have surpassed our funding goal of $2000.00 by almost 50%

If we can achieve $3000.00 or more, I, Matt Haynes, artistic director of The Pulp Stage, will be doing laps while submerged in a tower of boxes: 

Pioneer Courthouse Square, Portland OR

Monday, January 5th

12pm…

That's right: The campaign is still taking tax-deductible contributions until January 2 and if by then we can crack $3k, I will take my boxes and be recorded doing a Pioneer Square “victory lap” in your honor. For every $100 raised after the $3k, I will do an additional lap inside the square.

Everyone is welcome to contribute up through Friday, January 2nd. And of course, everyone is welcome to witness the victory laps at noon in the square on Monday, January 5th

And now... the company story: 

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

WHO ARE WE?

The Pulp Stage theatre company offers live theatre to fans of Science Fiction, Fantasy and Suspense. We've been operating out of Portland, Oregon for the last five years and are delighted to have recently been awarded status as a non-profit organization. *Please see an important note about tax deductions at the bottom of our story.


Artistic Director Matt Haynes (tall guy in the back) and The Pulp Stage team (from the left): Racheal Joy Erickson, Kaia Maarja Hillier, Tina Connolly, Lily Warpinski, Sue Ellen Christensen and Daniel Smith. Photo by Brian Johnson.

WHAT ARE WE DOING NOW?

Over the past year, we've been developing something we call Prime Plays: High quality evenings of theatre that can be produced with little-to-no materials. In fact, all you need are:

-An audience

-Actors

-Digital tablets from which to read

These plays have life-and-death stakes as well as fantastical atmospheres but it's all boiled down to crackling dialogue. Audiences have loved the Prime Plays because of the storytelling. We love Prime Plays because they offer a new, easier way to put on live theatre.

Actors, tablets and audience! This is one of 17 different Prime Play showcases we've
brought to venues ranging from bars, to living rooms to back yards! Performers (from the left) Kaia Maarja Hillier, Matt Haynes and Donna Kay Yarborough. Photo by Daniel Smith.

WHAT'S OUR PROJECT?

In January of 2015, we're going to premiere BOX, a Prime Play by Tina Connolly and Matt Haynes. BOX is a science fiction series that will be shown in three weekly installments. 

Sometime in the future...

Jane, a high school student, has been arrested under suspicion of a heinous crime. In a government detention center, Jane is wired into a virtual reality program that sends her through a series of flashbacks and fantasy games... all with the intent of exposing her crime and reprocessing her mind.

Taylor Elizabeth Hansen and Racheal Joy Erickson. Original photography by Rio Image Maker.

WHAT DOES YOUR DONATION DO?  

We are investing in our most ambitious project and our biggest performance venue to date. By funding BOX, you are helping us reach our widest audience yet. With your support, we can introduce the Prime Play approach to a larger community of clients and collaborators.

Revenue and profits are put immediately to use in research, presentation and development of new Prime Plays. 

On January 26, 2015 our first episode will be premiering at the Fertile Ground City-Wide Festival Of New Works. Logo design by Michael Buchino.


WHERE DOES YOUR DONATION GO?  

We are hoping to raise $2,000 to produce BOX.   We've eliminated many potential expenses through our Prime Play format (just actors, tablets and audience). However, to reach our new expanded audience we're investing in:

-Rental of a 100 seat venue 

-Registration fees for the 2015 Fertile Ground City-Wide Festival Of New Works

 -Publicity

-Playbill Printing

 -Maintaining a $10 ceiling on all ticket prices

 ...and OF COURSE it's very important to us to pay our actors, director and playwrights!!!


WHAT ARE THE PERKS?

Oh, have we got some fun for you: Passes to special events! Books! CDs! Stickers! Meetups with the authors and producer! Producer CREDITS! And for all donors, our special VIP-mail newsletter containing campaign updates and insiders-only tidbits on our story.

Perking up: Taylor Elizabeth Hansen and Racheal Joy Erickson model your potential emotional state! Photo by Rio Image Maker.

WHAT IF WE DON’T REACH THE ENTIRE GOAL?
We will present BOX this January. Indiegogo will award us whatever money we raise, minus their percentage of the take. While we hope to use ticket revenue to fund future endeavors, if needed, they will be used to cover production costs for BOX.


WHAT’S THE POINT?
The Prime Play project is aimed to create a new, easier way to put on live theatre. Our grab-it-&-read-it format gives actors a simple and direct way to deliver drama in its prime form: Dialogue.  We believe that having easier ways of making live theatre results in more live theatre. More live theatre, we believe, makes for healthier and more vibrant communities. Would you like to help?

WHY YOU’RE IN GOOD HANDS

The Prime Play project is not just some theory. Over the last year and a half since the project started:

-We have received over 240 submissions from around the country.

-We’ve showcased 34 plays, 3 of which are world premiere adaptations from renowned science fiction stories.

-We’ve worked with over 30 different actors in 17 showcases put on in 8 different venues throughout Portland, from bars to private residences.

-We have also collected over 160 anonymous surveys that our audiences fill out after each show. We have frequently gotten top numbers when asking how the audience would rate the show as“Exciting.” Other write-in descriptions: “Gripping”, “delightful”, “eye-opening”, “cool”, “fun”, “intense”, “cutting edge” and “FABULOUS”!

Both in the office and on the stage, we've been hard at work developing this unique form of theatre. We're ready take the next leap with your support.

Backstage before one of our showcases at the Jack London Bar last spring (from the left): Steve Coker, Donna Kay Yarborough, Kaia Maarja Hillier, Otniel Henig, Racheal Joy Erickson and David Bellis Squires. Photo by Matt Haynes.

WHAT RISKS ARE WE VENTURING?
Besides the financial chance we’re taking by producing BOX, we are challenging ourselves with the following artistic questions:


-Can we weave a convincing otherworldly atmosphere through pure dialogue?

-Can we create something that the audience will be able to follow easily, week by week? 

-Can this original play hold its own within a genre with such well-established avenues (movies, TV, books, etc)?


WHAT IF I CAN'T CONTRIBUTE RIGHT NOW?

Firstly, a reminder that no contribution amount is too small. Some bucks here, some bucks there... if everyone in our network pitched in, the campaign would be successfully funded.

Still: No money right now? No problem! See below...

CAN YOU "SNEEZE" IT? 

"Sneezers" (concept from marketing guru, Seth Godin) are word-spreaders. For a project to go viral you need people who like to "sneeze." Do you like the idea for the BOX project? Do you like the idea of the Prime Play project and how it can serve communities?  Take a deep breath and sneeze away! Where to aim and fire:

-Go to the Share Box at the top of this page and have at it!

-Copy the URL for this page and post it on facebook, twitter, your blog, or even email it to your network!

-"Like" The Pulp Stage on Facebook and share our updates!

Let's bring a beloved art form to a new stage.


*An important note about tax deductions and PERKS:
We want you to be rewarded for your donation. If you'd like to deduct the maximum amount of your donation from your taxes, please select:

"No perk, I just want to contribute."

If you'd like to claim your perk, we'll be happy to advise the monetary value so you can deduct the difference (common example: Going to a charity dinner and paying $50 for a meal that would run about $20= You deduct $30).

We're proud of our perks and no matter which one you choose, your donation should end up being at least 75% deductible. We think that you'll be quite pleased with what your donation gets you in either case!
story_txt:
SPECIAL NOTE: As of December 28,  with delight and gratitude, we have surpassed our funding goal of $2000.00 by almost 50%If we can achieve $3000.00 or more, I, Matt Haynes, artistic director of The Pulp Stage, will be doing laps while submerged in a tower of boxes: Pioneer Courthouse Square, Portland ORMonday, January 5th12pm…

That's right: The campaign is still taking tax-deductible contributions 
until January 2 and if by then we can crack $3k, I will take my boxes 
and be recorded doing a Pioneer Square “victory lap” in your honor. For every $100 raised after the $3k, I will do an additional lap inside the square.
Everyone is welcome to contribute up through Friday, January 2nd. And of course, everyone is welcome to witness the victory laps at noon in the square on Monday, January 5th
And now... the company story:

story:
STORY

Transformational Personal Theatre, LLC is a collaborative expressive arts company based in Eugene, Oregon. We give voice to those who are stereotyped and marginalized in our culture, while promoting personal growth, development, and healing from trauma. Performers tell their life stories using creative, multi-media expressive arts forms, including spoken word, live original music, as well as recorded music, poetry, visual arts, dance, movement, stand-up, and video projections.

The current show in development is focused on addiction recovery. The title of the show is, NOT HERE: From Howling Hurt to Healing Hope, the Alchemy of Addiction Recovery. The title is based on a poem called "Not Here," by sixteenth century mystic poet Rumi, that speaks to the need to walk through fire in order to transform.

The intention of the project is to facilitate positive transformations in each individual's recovery process that can also be sustainable once the show is over. A secondary goal is to raise awareness about the magnificence and worth of every human being, no matter what challenges are present that overshadow personal gifts and authentic essence.

With a diverse cast of ten women and men, the show is a deeply rich portrayal of personal triumph over pain and suffering. The performers, most of whom have never had any sort of theater experience, are truly gifted and amazing individuals who exhibit sheer courageousness in daring to tell their personal stories.
WHAT THE DONATIONS WILL BE USED FOR:
-PROPS & COSTUMES
-TECHNICAL & OFFICE EQUIPMENT, OFFICE SPACE RENTAL
-REHEARSAL MEALS
-STIPENDS FOR VIDEOGRAPHERS, LOCAL GUEST WORKSHOP PRESENTERS, AND SUPPORT TEAM
-INSURANCE
-REHEARSAL SPACE
-PROJECT ITEMS & PERKS
-THEATER RENTAL
-POST-SHOW RECEPTION
-DESIGN AND PRINTING OF PROGRAM, POSTERS, AND TICKETS 
-EDITING AND COPYING OF DVDS
-RENTAL OF ART HOUSE MOVIE THEATER FOR SCREENING OF DVD
-PAYMENTS FOR COPYRIGHT PERMISSIONS
-FUNDS FOR PERFORMERS TO ATTEND RELATED EVENTS
-MEALS FOR HOLIDAY AND POST DRESS REHEARSAL PARTIES

IMPACT STATEMENT
The impact of this project will benefit the performers and audience alike. The project provides a healthy outlet for creative expression. This form of performance art can reignite life force energy, and self-discovery to one’s true essence and purpose. From a place of living one’s authentic self, new hope for healthy and sustainable growth and change is generated.

Audience members will be moved profoundly in bearing witness to the immense bravery, heart-felt messages, and multidimensional symbolic portrayals of real life. This witnessing acts as a catalyst for catharsis of the performers, and has the potential to do the same for audience members, as they recognize their own similar experiences. In this way, performers and audience members act as sacred mirrors, one for the other.

Ultimately, acceptance and unconditional positive regard for oneself and others is the core objective underlying the development of this performance. From a place of compassion and love, hope for healing becomes most possible.

WHAT WILL HAPPEN TO DONATION IF PERFORMANCE DOES NOT HAPPEN
Regardless of whether the performance happens, remaining expenses will be donated to White Bird's Chrysalis Behavioral Health Services, which is the non-profit we are working in conjunction with. Those funds will be earmarked specifically to help support those in treatment for substance abuse issues.

WAYS TO PREVENT PROJECT FROM NOT REACHING ITS GOAL OF PRESENTING A SHOW
The performers in this show are enacting their own life stories, and therefore there is a risk that the performers could change their minds at any time about the decision to publicly expose information about individual addiction. Counseling is available at every rehearsal, and between rehearsals, to help the performers with their goal of making it to the stage.

Each performer has the opportunity to become a client of Chrysalis Behavioral Health Services, in order to receive counseling support during the development of the show, and for two to four months after the show is over, at no cost. This will help the performers sustain any positive transformations in their recovery processes they were able to achieve as a result of participation in the show.

The facilitator also makes every effort to recruit additional performers if someone opts out of participating, thereby helping the development of the show continue to progress.

The commitment and enthusiasm of the performers has grown since the beginning of this project. The anticipatory excitement of the Indiegogo campaign has fueled our fire!

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contribute financially, but there are other ways you can help!

  • Share this Campaign on your Facebook page!
  • Like & Share our new Facebook page to keep updated with the show and project! https://www.facebook.com/transformationalpersonaltheatre
  • If you're local to the area, we could always use more help! Volunteer positions for costumes, prop help, backstage support, tickets and concessions.

Thank you so much!

story:
The Plot:
This modern adaptation of Molière'sTartuffe brings out the best from this classic play: sex, power, and manipulation. In this production, Tartuffe is presented as a narcissistic spiritual guru who gleefully takes advantage of his charismatic power to get whatever he wants from his followers. Masquerading as a righteous man, he uses the weakness of Orgon, a faded rock-star who is unable to get his career back on track, to infiltrate his family and cause rifts.

The Players:
Cast (in alphabetical order): Cullen Kuch, Elcio Monteze, Emily Oliveira, Isli Hoxha, Katharine Nedder, Mariana Coelho, Michal Birnbaum, Philipp Gilly and Rosaria Caporrimo.

The Run:
November 21st @ 8pm
November 22nd @ 8pm
November 23rd @ 7pm

American Theatre for Actors (Chernuchin Theatre - 2nd Floor)
314 W 54th Street (between 8th & 9th aves)
New York, NY, 10019

Your Contribution:
Your contribution will go into the cost of supplies for the set, wardrobe, makeup, props, lighting (and lighting technician), sound design (and sound mixer), and printing of scripts and posters. This is our estimation for a low budget production. If we exceed this goal, we will be able to compensate our talented team! This is one of the reasons your contribution would be so greatly appreciated!

If you are unable to donate money, here are other great ways in which you can support our production:

- Like our Facebook page: www.facebook.com/youvebeentartuffed
- Spread the word about our campain & our production. 
- Share this indie gogo campain with friends & family.

story:
We are a group of seniors from Fairview High School in Boulder, Colorado, putting on a student run production of "Dog Sees God: Confessions of a Teenage Blockhead." The show brings the beloved characters of the Peanuts comics to the stage, taking us through the struggles that Charlie Brown and the gang face in high school.

Our show is well under way: we have begun the production on both the actor's side as well as the technical side. We are an independent student company that is seeking help. We are not looking for profit, we are simply a group of people passionate about putting on a show, by the students and for the students.

The money that is contributed will be put towards paying for the rights fees, venue rentals, scripts, and printing. The total amount we are seeking is $2,000.

If we do not reach our goal through IndieGoGo, we will have to raise ticket prices and continue to fundraise in other ways in order to make the show possible.

The student directed show is a continuation of a new tradition. The production team has been participating in theater for many years, on and off the stage. Lizzy Mosher, Director, has directed for the school's One Act Festival and is the President of Fairview's chapter of the International Thespian Society. Natania Bloch, Assistant Director, has participated in Fairview theater for years in roles such as Tybalt (Romeo and Juliet) and Ginette (Almost, Maine). Sydney Chinowsky, Technical Director, has been active and has held leadership roles in Fairview's tech department for several years (Assistant Director for Romeo and Juliet, Stage Manager for Anything Goes, and many more).

This project is valuable to us because it is a show about high schoolers put on by the high schoolers. It deals with real issues faced by teenagers every day. Buried under parody and hyperbole, the show has a good heart which will inspire kids struggling with bullying, depression, and the search for identity.

Please spread the word: text your friends, like our page on Facebook, share our campaign, and tell the world!

story:
Who Are We?

We are Any Other Name Company and our focus is providing a platform for marginalized voices to tell their stories through the lens of classical theatre. 

Which is our fancy way of saying that, last fall, a couple of idealistic college friends, a little drunk on ice cream and chicken wings, disheartened at the lack of representation in our chosen field, turned to each other and said: “We should just start our own company.”  

However, don’t let that fool you; we are actually qualified to do so. 

Aside from our BFAs in Classical Acting, we have each worked at professional theaters across the country directing, performing, managing, educating, marketing, supervising, and producing a variety of projects from Shakespeare to modern classics.

Why All Women?

As we discussed piece selection – the day after our ice cream and chicken bender, at a conference focused on bringing advocacy to women in the arts – we were feeling so optimistic at the grand ideas of we could achieve. After two days of conferencing with other attendees, we were feeling pretty confident about our talents, abilities, and future. 

Then, that afternoon, Brett Kavanaugh was confirmed, and suddenly, every woman in the room with us visibly diminished. All of us knew what it felt like to be the woman who wasn’t believed. 

However, being women, we dusted ourselves off and got on with it. To paraphrase many wise people: In every disaster lies opportunity.  Our idea for a theatre company suddenly had a clear direction for our first production: An all-female Measure for Measure.

“Who Will Believe Thee…?”

In the second act there is a scene where the heroine, Isabella, is being coerced by Angelo, a powerful city official, into giving up her virginity to save her brother’s life. When she threatens to expose him his response is, “Who will believe thee, Isabel?” Although written 400 years ago, this still hits home for too many people today. 

Simply put, this is a woman’s story, and we believe women need to tell it.

This Part is Numbers, But There are Cookies at the End

Our fundraising goal is $4,000. This amount will help us pay for a venue for auditions, rehearsals, and two weeks of performances. It will also provide a budget for set design, costumes, sound, and lighting. 

Finally, and most importantly, we want to pay our artists! 

With an acting cast of at least eight, and various designers and technicians, we want to ensure everyone is compensated fairly for their time and effort.

Obviously, we don’t expect something for nothing, so we have a lot of great perks for you! They include everything from discounts on tickets to homemade cookies to a stellar thank you gift when all is said and done.

What’s The Point?

So what are we really trying to do? 

We want to provide a side of a narrative that often goes unheard. We are hoping that anyone of any gender or identity who sees themselves in Isabella’s story feels less alone and more empowered. For those who don’t relate to Isabella, all we hope is that this story will help them consider what side of this power equation they are on, and how they can help balance it in the future. 

Eventually, we plan for this company to grow into a space for people whose stories and viewpoints are often overlooked in film, television, on stage, and in the national conversation as a whole. A place for anyone regardless of race, gender, ability, or orientation  can create both a mirror and a window where their community can see themselves represented and where others can see their point of view. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you’re saying to yourself “This sounds incredible, and I really want to help, but I have no money.” Thank you, you sound incredible too! And guess what: We would still love you to be involved in any way you can. If you’re in the Chicago area, or are just incredibly enthusiastic, email us to volunteer your time and abilities. 

If you’re not in Chicago, or are and just don’t want to lift heavy things, feel free to share our campaign on social media(s) and let other people know about our work here.

story:
BAD BABY PRESENTS: HER FIRST CANADIAN TOUR!

 

Bad Baby: Then & Now

Audiences first met Bad Baby, Janelle Hanna's adorable & provocative clown character, at the 2017 Toronto Fringe Festival where Bad Baby debuted her first ever solo show. She sang, she danced, she made us laugh – and gave us a memorable "surprise" at the end of the show (read more about it below). Before the run had closed, we knew more people needed to experience Bad Baby and see this show. We started talking about a tour, and now, two years later, we're delighted to be sending Bad Baby to both the Winnipeg and Edmonton Fringe Festivals. It's a tour! Across Canada! Manitoba and Alberta! We're so excited! And...a little nervous! 

 

Why We're Asking for Support

Why are we nervous? Lark & Whimsy has been producing independent theatre since 2016. We have a proven track record of successful shows, including Bad Baby Presents: Rules Control the Fun and last year's Toronto Fringe hit, Robert. But we've done all that here, at home in Toronto. Touring is a "next level" challenge. We know we're up for that challenge: Robert sold 87% of it's available box office, and we're confident that Bad Baby will be as much of a hit in Winnipeg and Edmonton as she was in Toronto. But touring means travelling and travelling means flying (Canada: it's a big country) and flying means expensive. 

We've done our best to keep all of our production expenses low, and we have a history of creating quality theatre productions on a dime. The one expense we have no control over is the cost of flights. Which is why we're asking for your help: 100% of funds raised will go towards the cost of air travel to both cities for writer/performer Janelle Hanna and a stage manager. Air travel costs include the price of the flight itself, plus additional fees for checked baggage, airport fees and applicable taxes. 

 

What Your Support Means

Your support means that neither artist will have to pay out of pocket to travel for work. More importantly, your support will enable more of the box office revenue to go towards paying artists for their time, energy and talent. And trust us, it feels good to help artists get paid. 

Supporting this campaign will also help Lark & Whimsy grow: we're incredibly excited to produce our first multi-city Canadian tour as it represents a big step. Our mandate is to produce original, meaningful Canadian theatre, and this tour enables us to share that work with more Canadians. 

 

About Bad Baby Presents: Rules Control the Fun

Bad Baby knows all the rules for a great fringe show. All of them. And she’s gonna follow the rules because rules control the fun! Bad Baby wanted to be an actor so she could sleep in and kiss boys, and lately she hasn’t gotten to do either of those things. With exceptional acting skills, unmatched good looks, one balloon arch, and a surprise you can’t miss, we guarantee - “...nothing compares to Bad Baby.” (The Torontoist)

 

TOP 5 PICK! - Torontoist 

“Bad Baby singlehandedly rescues the concept of meta-narrative at the Fringe.”

​

RAVE REVIEW & STAFF PICK!! - Mooney on Theatre

“A true Fringe gem!”

 

OUTSTANDING PERFORMANCE!!! - Now Magazine

 “Bold and brave”

 

Bad Baby Presents: Rules Control the Fun is written & performed by Janelle Hanna and directed by Briana Brown. Stage management by Chris Baker (Winnipeg) and Briana Brown (Edmonton). Lighting Design by Gabriel Cropley. Promotional photography by Scott Murdoch, Five by Five Photography. Produced by Janelle Hanna & Erin Vandenberg. A Lark & Whimsy Theatre Collective production. 

 

About Lark and Whimsy Theatre Collective

An artist-driven collective, Lark and Whimsy produces original Canadian plays that pair rich theatricality and language with challenging content. Part of Toronto's indie theatre scene, L&W strives to create theatrical experiences that illuminate and engage. We love the slightly absurd, the handcrafted and the delicate. We explore the frictions arising out of conflicting perspectives, the challenges inherent in creating a more equitable world, and, as Gwendolyn MacEwen once put it, the "imponderable agony of just being here." We try to be funny sometimes too.     

Past productions include: Salt by Erin Vandenberg (2016), Bad Baby Presents: Rules Control the Fun by Janelle Hanna (2017), and Robert. by Briana Brown (2018). Upcoming: Conway by Chris Baker. 

You can learn more about Lark & Whimsy on our website: www.larkandwhimsytheatre.com. 

 

Other Ways to Help: Toronto Preview Shows

Before she hits the road, Bad Baby is doing two preview shows in Toronto at Bad Dog Theatre on Thursday, June 6 & Sunday, June 9. As confident as she is, Bad Baby needs a chance to get in front of an audience again. Plus, she'll be working with a new stage manager on tour, so this will give the two of them the opportunity to get to know each other. If you missed Bad Baby the first time around or if you just want to see the show again, you can click here to purchase tickets! 

We also want to be transparent and let you know that the preview shows are another fundraising initiative for us. Please know that we're not asking you to fund us twice – this is just another way you can support us. And if you want to get a little VIP treatment at the shows, check out our "You Knew Bad Baby When" perks. 

 

Other Other Ways to Help

You can share this campaign on your social media!

You can follow us on social media! 

  • Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/larkandwhimsytheatre/
  • Twitter: @lark_and_whimsy
  • Instagram: @lark_and_whimsy @badbabypresents

If you saw the show at the 2017 Toronto Fringe, you can share the campaign along with some thoughts or memories of the show. (But please no spoilers!) Tag us, we'll say hi!

And finally, you can invite your Winnipeg and Edmonton friends to the show! 

  • https://www.winnipegfringe.com/
  • https://www.fringetheatre.ca/

story:
Summary

Ventana Ballet seeks to accomplish two competing goals, and we humbly seek your help to achieve them.
1) To provide artistically relevant and technically proficient dance performance and education opportunities to the community.
2) To make these opportunities accessible to all members of the community by offering low cost entry.

What does this mean?  We want to pay our artists well, and we want to charge a reasonable ticket price for all audiences. 

 

What We Are Asking For

  • We are looking to raise at least $5000.
  • This funding will cover the costs associated with theater and rehearsal space rentals to present this show and provide a great experience for our audiences and community.
  • This funding will also help pay the artists who have worked diligently to perfect their craft and profession.
  • This funding will allow us to keep ticket prices below market value. 

 

The Impact

  • Your contribution will enable Ventana Ballet to "do it right."
  • So many artists are underpaid. Help us show that we value their work and their artistry.
  • So many people can't go see great art because it costs too much. Help us welcome all audiences into the experiences we create for them. 
  • Ventana Ballet has successfully produced great work in the past. The Watchmaker's Song was a popular success, and we plan to bring it back bigger and better this December!
  • We are simply asking your help to keep that a reality moving forward, as we work through our first year as a company.

 

Our Team

Choreographers, Dorothy O'Shea Overbey, Erica Gionfriddo, AJ Garcia-Rameau

Dancers, Nicole Del Bene, Rachael Culver, Rachel Meador, Navaji David Nava, Megan Dollar, Allyson Morales, Alyssa Johnson, Ginnifer Joe, Dorothy O'Shea Overbey, AJ Garcia-Rameau

Musicians, Daniel Kopp (cello), Matt Lammers (violin), Kamila Swerdloff (piano)

Lighting Designer, Stephen Pruitt

Director, AJ Garcia-Rameau

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate any and all contributions - no contribution is too small. There are other ways to help, if you are unable to help us reach our budget goal. Spread the word! Bring your friends to the shows and to our classes. Follow us on social media and share our stories. Volunteer with us! We value every single supporter, no matter the contribution. Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

Duke Raulston is our producer and he had this wonderful idea to utilize the beautiful, Princess Theatre in South Pittsburg, Tennessee, in a horror hosting venture. He contacted me, Hope Holloway, to act and direct. Together we put gathered an amazing group of actors, writers, videographers, photographers, and other crew. We plan on having our live performances at The Princess (which will include variety show aspects, theatre and then the showing of the classic horror movie) filming webisodes, and doing character appearances, etc. We have well developed, quirky characters all ready to go. 

What We Need & What You Get

To really get started for our first live show, we need $2,000. There is the deposit on the theatre, the fee for renting the theatre, the fee for licsening the movie and some advertising fees. That is just the bare bones of what we need for the first show. If we are able to raise more than that, we will be able to do more thorough advertising, spend some on costuming and start with the needed equipment. 

 

If you spend:

Up to $25--Our "undying" grattitude.

$25--A sticker of one of our characters

$50--A Dark Princess Theatre t-shirt

$1,000--4 tickets and a Dark Princess Theatre t-shirt

$2,000--1 year membership (admission for one person to any and all live shows for 1 year) and a Dark Princess Theatre t-shirt

 

 

The Impact

We plan on changing the way people look at horror hosting, with a strong female horror host that defies the stereotypes. Our approach will be unique in many ways. We will be introducing dance, music, sword fighting and many other types of unusual aspects. 

By bringing this exciting new venture to South Pittsburgh, Tennessee--Duke's hometown--we hope to shine the light on both the town itself and also the lovely, renovated Victorian theatre, The Princess. South Pittsburg is conveniently located, about 30 minutes outside of Chattanooga and with easy access to Nashville and Huntsville. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, we would still be very appreciative of your help. If you could just share our campaign for us that would help out tremendously! You can use the Indiegogo share buttons--easy peasy! Thank you so much!

story:
Who & What

I am Danielle Selby, the director of SelbyDance.  Since graduating college with my degree in dance my friends and I have been getting together every summer to continue to make dance even though we have been scattered over several states.

Last summer to help lessen the financial burden we launched a mini dance intensive. This summer our sights are set even higher. We will be creating our first concert series.  This is a large creative and financial undertaking and my dancers and I can not take on this financial burden on our own.

Our concert series will include the completion of Menagerie of the Uneven Minds, a 40 minute piece about Fear.  Already partially created this work is inspired by H.P. Lovecraft and the horror genre. Delving into our deepest darkest places we exploit the fears, passions, obsessions and hatred found there. This dance will be the centerpiece of our summer concert series.

How

How can you help make this project a reality? What we are asking for will not cover all of our expenses.  The list below includes bringing dancers to Lansing, Michigan to rehearse and perform.  It also includes travel to and housing in Stowe, Vermont in order to perform.

  • Flights to Lansing $2000
  • Rental Car and Gas $500
  • Lodging and Food $800
  • Dancer pay $600
  • Performance space $800
  • Costumes $500
  • Promotion $300
  • Unexpected/Incidental Costs $500

 

 

Why

Your contribution will make this performance series happen.  If we get 60 people to give $100 or 120 to give $50 then this series will happen. By supporting this project you will be supporting the arts, the creation of new original works, and a concert series which will bring these dances to a wide and diverse audience. Every contribution, regardless of size, will bring us closer to our goal.  So please contribute and help SelbyDance continue to grow by creating and performing original works! 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to help but don’t have the disposable income to contribute? Share this campaign with your friends and family.  The more friends we have sharing our campaign the more funders we will find.  Thank you for reading and helping in any way you can.  Find out more about SelbyDance at www.SelbyDance.com

Last summer to help lessen the financial burden we launched a mini dance intensive. This summer our sights are set even higher. We will be creating our first concert series.  This is a large creative and financial undertaking and my dancers and I can not take on this financial burden on our own.
Our concert series will include the completion of Menagerie of the Uneven Minds, a 40 minute piece about Fear.  Already partially created this work is inspired by H.P. Lovecraft and the horror genre. Delving into our deepest darkest places we exploit the fears, passions, obsessions and hatred found there. This dance will be the centerpiece of our summer concert series.
How
How can you help make this project a reality? What we are asking for will not cover all of our expenses.  The list below includes bringing dancers to Lansing, Michigan to rehearse and perform.  It also includes travel to and housing in Stowe, Vermont in order to perform.

Flights to Lansing $2000
Rental Car and Gas $500
Lodging and Food $800
Dancer pay $600
Performance space $800
Costumes $500
Promotion $300
Unexpected/Incidental Costs $500

 
 
Why
Your contribution will make this performance series happen.  If we get 60 people to give $100 or 120 to give $50 then this series will happen. By supporting this project you will be supporting the arts, the creation of new original works, and a concert series which will bring these dances to a wide and diverse audience. Every contribution, regardless of size, will bring us closer to our goal.  So please contribute and help SelbyDance continue to grow by creating and performing original works! 
 
Other Ways You Can Help
Want to help but don’t have the disposable income to contribute? Share this campaign with your friends and family.  The more friends we have sharing our campaign the more funders we will find.  Thank you for reading and helping in any way you can.  Find out more about SelbyDance at www.SelbyDance.com

story:
Touch Me Philly Productions, LLC is so excited to be bringing Charles Busch's “Psycho Beach Party to Philadelphia this fall! We have four amazing shows under our belt now, including “The Rocky Horror Show,” “Burlesque Bedtime Stories” our short play festival, “Normal...?” and our spooktacular short film event, “Macabre Movie Night.” Now we are ready to kick it up a notch and bring you weeks of amazing interactive theater with “Psycho Beach Party.”

Your donations help us to make this incredibly fun show a reality! It helps us secure our venue, pay our actors & technicians, rent equipment, and create the amazing sets, costumes & props to bring you into a world full of “Psycho Beach Party,” We'll immerse you in sun, surf, slash & split personalities! All this just in time for Halloween!

We thank you for making a donation today, and encourage you top check out all the awesome perks you can receive for your contribution. From t-shirts to tickets, stickers to official spoor titles, we have lots of great incentives for you to check out.

To learn more about us and our past shows, please click on over to our official website: www.TouchMePhilly.com! If you have any questions for us, shoot us an email: Info@TouchMePhilly.com.

We are so grateful to our amazing community here in Philadelphia. We appreciate your donation and sharing this campaign with your friends and family. Thank you all for supporting Touch Me Philly Productions and for being such an amazing audience!

 

Peace, Love & Theater Magic,

Alyson Rodriguez Orenstein & Amanda Sylvester

Co-Owners & Producers of Touch Me Philly Productions, LLC

story:
Iain Stringer Works presents, in association with theSpaceUK Prevail: a dramatic tale told through music and dance at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe 2018

What's Prevail about?

An oppressive way of life dominates. Two men are alone. Intimate. They are ambushed by a gang. There’s a struggle. One escapes. The other is humiliated and the event filmed and shared on social media. He attempts to fight back. The gang take him away and report untruths to the authorities about him. He faces a trial and is imprisoned by a judge. Punished by an interrogator.... Though both are separated, they fight for the right to be reunited and for the truth.

What's the background to Prevail?

Prevail is a narrative dance work. Iain Stringer began writing the plot and composing the music for full orchestra in 2010. In 2015 he won a Wandsworth Council arts grant to workshop Prevail at the Putney Arts Theatre, London. In 2017 the work was part of an Arts Council England/Lottery Funded programme for St. Helens Council’s Arts In Libraries/Cultural Hubs initiative. Prevail dancers then and presently are:

... and the cast?

4 dancers...

Eneko Borao, Sydney Robertson, Jake Evans and Luke Sheppard                                                                                                                          

... audience reactions so far?

‘Brilliant... A wonderful performance.’ St. Helens Art Service
‘Fantastic Performance... It was really great.’ St. Helens Unlimited
‘A packed out performance... Haunting.’ Cultural Hubs, St. Helens Libraries.  

'Incredibly engaging… malevolence, tenderness all through, splendid choreography and music.' audience member  '… an engaging, moving show.' audience member. '… a very captivating performance that flowed effortlessly from one scene to the next.' audience member 

 

See a highlight from St Helens... https://youtu.be/QTmnU3FX7PM

 

Show: Prevail  

Company: Iain Stringer Works
Venue: Venue 9, theSpace @ Niddry Street, Edinburgh, EH1 1TH
Dates: 20-25 August 

Show time: 7:20pm (50 mins) 

Tickets: £10.00 Concessions £8.00

Venue box Office: 0131 510 2383 boxoffice.niddry@thespaceuk.com
Fringe box office: 0131 226 0000 www.edFringe.com
 

Prevail is a collaboration between Iain Stringer and a company of four dancers. They have created Prevail- an original, dramatic dance work. We are a small, independent dance company with big vision!

We want people to be caught up in the emotion and thrill of a dramatic dance work, and to feel passionate about story telling through dance and music.

There has been no commissioning or public award for this project, so your support means the world to us! To reach the Edinburgh Festival Fringe we would like your support. Your backing. 

Why not be a part of bringing Prevail to life...!

We need to raise an additional £7000.00 to add to the money we have aleady raised.

Your contributions will not be wasted.

Your contributions- big or small- will go a long way towards funding:

  • the hire of the dancers,
  • theatre hire,
  • rehearsal space hire,
  • travel,
  • accommodation,
  • insurance,
  • marketing and media,
  • props and costumes,
  • creating an artwork of original music and dance by a small company with big ideas!

 

Why support Prevail?

Small, independent dance works often fail to reach the Edinburgh Festival Fringe because they don't have the financial support. So they just don't get seen or heard. Great talent and great artwork gets wasted. With Prevail you'll be supporting an original work, an independent company- in a world of big companies, It shouldn't always be the big companies with the cash, right? 

In addition, you'll help the cast of Prevail reach a wide audience.

Your influence will travel far and wide. The Edinburgh Festival Fringe is a huge global event.

Be a part of it! ;)

 

We achieved our workshop in London. We achieved our try out in St. Helens. Now we're ready for the time of our lives and reaching the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. You can make that happen. Yes that's true. Thanks to the Indiegogo platform.

 

Are there other ways to help?

Oh YES! Of course.

We understand that not all people can contribute funds, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask friends, family, work colleagues, neighbours and your social media networks (a tweet anyone??) to get the word out and make some noise about Prevail.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools if sharing on social media!

A MASSIVE thank you for your time and support.

Maybe we'll see you soon in Edinburgh...

story:
- Scroll down for English version -

/NL

Collectief Verloren is een Brussels podiumkunstencollectief. Onze nieuwste productie A Warm Place is een sterke, visuele monoloog over de fysieke impact van depressie en angststoornissen.

We zijn deze zomer geselecteerd voor enkele internationale festivals: Theaterwelten (Rudolstadt, Duitsland), Spots Op West (Westouter, België) en de Mondial du Théatre, in de opera van Monaco.

Met jullie steun kunnen we deze fantastische ervaring bekostigen. Je draagt bij tot onze eerste internationale performances. Concreet gebruiken we het geld om de herwerking van onze voorstelling voor Spots Op West te financieren.

Meer info op onze website.

 

/EN

Collectief Verloren is a Brussels based performing arts collective. Our latest production A Warm Place is a strong, visual monologue about the physical impact of depression and anxiety disorder.

This summer we were nominated for a few international theatre festivals: Theaterwelten, (Rudolstadt, Germany) Spots Op West (Westouter, Belgium) and the Mondial du Théatre in the opera house of Monaco. 

With your donations we'll be able to realise this wonderful experience. You'll support our first international performances. We will use the money to rework our performance for Spots Op West. 

More information on our website.
