story:
Short Summary

Kidz Theater needs your help to provide scholarships for our 2019 season!  We are currently dealing with the skyrocketing costs of production in New York City--while we are looking to raise $15,000--a fraction of the cost of the scholarships we give out per season.  

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is $15,000 for this season. We provide well over $40,000 in tutition assistance yearly, and as such, this money would be instrumental in providing rehearsal space, renting the theater, props, costumes, set, as well as making sure we can keep mainstage participation for our mentor performers COMPLETELY FREE!

The Impact

Our program serves as a professional training ground for children and teenagers pursuing careers in musical theater and technical theater. Every season, our productions are both performed and technically operated by a VERY talented group of teenagers working both on and off stage. Our performers have gone off to alma maters such as Boston Conservatory, University of Cincinnati College-Conservatory of Music (CCM), Carnegie Mellon, Pace University, New York University, Elon University, Point Park University, Shenandoah University, among others; and have appeared on Broadway in The Cher Show, Aladdin, Les Miserables, Dear Evan Hansen, The Book of Mormon, Evita, School of Rock, and The Phantom of the Opera; on the West End in Dreamgirls and in National Tours in Newsies, Les Miserables, among others.

Risks & Challenges

The disappearance of Kidz Theater mentorships and scholarships would destroy the mission and purpose of Kidz Theater, and would lead to the disappearance of one of the strongest performing arts educational platforms in the tri-state area.  

If we cannot raise this money, our doors may close.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word!  Tell your friends! Tell your friends' friends! Text them, call them, email them. We need word of mouth to get out about Kidz Theater so that people know who we are and what we do.  We rely on you all to keep our home growing and changing, and we TRULY thank you for all that you have done and continue to do.

story:
About the Show

Mockus is a thrilling tale based on true events of a mayor desperate to save his city and the clown who inspires him through a world of imagination. The clown’s antics, and his success, provoke fear and jealousy. Will they survive, armed only with laughter and love? Featuring spectacular acrobatics and exhilarating music and dance, Mockus will transport you to the sublime world of the three-ring circus.

This premiere production is being performed from March 26th to April 4th, 2020 at the West Village Theatre in Calgary, Alberta and is being produced by Jupiter Theatre. 

This show is fun and full of circus arts and dance! It's a poignant, silly, and important story for our times and has a high-energy cast of performers and a talented artistic and design team. This is Jupiter Theatre's largest production to date and we need your help to make it happen.


Our Team​



Cast
Mockus Aurelius - Kristy Benz
Juan Antonio - Jerod Blake
Sofia Antonio - Mary Elizabeth Chisholm
Messenger 1 - Kayla Mackenzie
Messenger 2 - Caitlyn O'Connor
Messenger 3 - Shaylea Pangle
Parades - Braedan Pettigrew
Will Garipissimo - Kodie Rollan
Faustina Antonio - Susan Rowland

Artistic Personnel
Director/Choreographer - Andrew G. Cooper
Playwright - George M. Johnson
Assistant Director - Cassandra Watson
Set Designer/Technical Director - Skylar Desjardins
Costume Designer - Jordan Wieben
Lighting Designer - Kai Hall
Composer/Sound Designer - Kyla Ferrier
Head of Properties - Mikee Ames
Magic Designer/Consultant - Simon Mallet
Intimacy Advisor - Jelena Minshall
Stage Manager - Jordan Payne
Assistant Stage Manager - Eszter Gorombey

Company
Artistic Producer - Andrew G. Cooper
Artistic Associate - Madeleine Taylor-Gregg
Artistic Associate - Cassandra Watson
Mainstage Production Producer - Kodie Rollan

 

So where do you come in?

Mockus is a very large project. It's the most ambitious production we've attempted to date and we want to do the performances justice. We've been doing our best to raise money, apply for grants and seek out sponsors, but we still need more help! And that is where you come in.

Your contributions will go directly towards:

  • ARTIST FEES - Paying the artists who work for Jupiter Theatre is the production's biggest expense and we truly believe that it should always be that way. We have nine brilliant cast members, four members of the directing and stage management team, six designers, and a devoted group of technicians and producing staff.  Our team will be working tirelessly on creating this show and it is important to us to pay them for the time and talent that they bring to us. 
  • VENUES - All the world may be a stage, but we need space to rehearse and perform this production. After rehearsing part-time for two months, the show will go up at the West Village Theatre, a space large enough to facilitate our needs but not too large as to be outside of our projected budget.
  • CIRCUS ELEMENTS - This show is a big spectacle and you can't do a circus show without a bit of razzle dazzle! Whether it be juggling balls, magic tricks, hula hoops, poi, or an aerial apparatus, we're going to need funds to bring together all the elements that the directors and designers have dreamed up for this show. 
  • COSTUMES - This show is very visual in nature and the costumes will be very stylized (and delightful)! Clowns need noses, dancers need shoes, and your money will help bring this wonderful piece of theatre to life on stage. 
  • SET - All the circus props and costume pieces in the world would mean nothing without something to perform on! We need help raising money for materials to construct and paint the show's set. 
  • MARKETING AND PUBLICITY - We want to share this amazing show with as many people as we can. We have to pay for the printing of our programs, handbills and posters, advertisements, as well as for the maintenance and upkeep of our website. 

 

Your Help Makes a Difference!

So now you know where your money is going. Your donations are very important to us and we're hoping to show you that through the perks we're offering in return for your help. This campaign is the only way to get tickets for this show until the new year! Our last production, FOUR by the Jupiter Ensemble, sold out it's entire run this fall so we're anticipating tickets for Mockus will be in high demand. 

But what if I don't live in Calgary or even Alberta you ask? Fear not my friend! Besides the fantastic perks we are offering to people who donate (and we ship items worldwide) you can also be filled with the wondrous feeling of helping in the creation of live theatre. The arts need the support of people like you whether you're our neighbour or you live in a neighbouring country!

We want as many people as possible to experience this wonderful show and any amount of money you can donate will help us to reach that goal. If you or your business are interested in donating to Jupiter Theatre for amounts above $250, please email our Artistic Producer to inquire about our sponsorship program. We have a variety of sponsorship levels that are catered to the diversity of businesses and organizations in our community. 


About Jupiter Theatre

Jupiter Theatre creates original works of Canadian theatre that are visual, physical, and musical. We seek to share powerful stories that explore the human condition and challenge audiences with contemporary social issues through visceral and innovative productions.

Jupiter Theatre provides long development periods for new pieces of theatre through its New Play Development Program, the Jupiter Ensemble Theatre Syndicate, co-productions with other companies, and tours of new works. Mockus by George M. Johnson was originally workshopped and performed in Kamloops, BC by Chimera Theatre and the script and project are currently undergoing significant revisions. We are very excited to be premiering a new version of this show in Calgary in the spring of 2020. 

You can find out more about us or take a look at our 2019/2020 season on our website. 

Want to know more about our team? Visit our staff page to read up on the faces behind Jupiter Theatre.

You can also find us our Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter! Follow us to stay up to date on our fundraising goals for this project!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you've read this far, we're guessing that you're interested in helping us bring this amazing project to life. We do understand, however, that not everyone can afford to financially support us. If you'd like to aid the project but can't make a donation, there are two easy ways you can make a difference for us. 

  • Tell people about this campaign! Tell your friends, tell your family members! Make some noise and spread the word. The more people that know about our fundraiser, the more likely we are to meet our goal. 
  • Share this campaign on your social media channels! Indiegogo has great share tools. The simplest way to let more people know about this is by sharing it on Facebook, Twitter, etc. 

Thank you so much for your interest in Mockus and Jupiter Theatre. Your support, no matter how large or small, means a great deal to us.

SET - All the circus props and costume pieces in the world would mean nothing without something to perform on! We need help raising money for materials to construct and paint the show's set. 

MARKETING AND PUBLICITY - We want to share this amazing show with as many people as we can. We have to pay for the printing of our programs, handbills and posters, advertisements, as well as for the maintenance and upkeep of our website. 

 

Your Help Makes a Difference!
So now you know where your money is going. Your donations are very important to us and we're hoping to show you that through the perks we're offering in return for your help. This campaign is the only way to get tickets for this show until the new year! Our last production, FOUR by the Jupiter Ensemble, sold out it's entire run this fall so we're anticipating tickets for Mockus will be in high demand. 
But what if I don't live in Calgary or even Alberta you ask? Fear not my friend! Besides the fantastic perks we are offering to people who donate (and we ship items worldwide) you can also be filled with the wondrous feeling of helping in the creation of live theatre. The arts need the support of people like you whether you're our neighbour or you live in a neighbouring country!
We want as many people as possible to experience this wonderful show and any amount of money you can donate will help us to reach that goal. If you or your business are interested in donating to Jupiter Theatre for amounts above $250, please email our Artistic Producer to inquire about our sponsorship program. We have a variety of sponsorship levels that are catered to the diversity of businesses and organizations in our community. 

About Jupiter Theatre

Jupiter Theatre creates original works of Canadian theatre that are visual, physical, and musical. We seek to share powerful stories that explore the human condition and challenge audiences with contemporary social issues through visceral and innovative productions.
Jupiter Theatre provides long development periods for new pieces of theatre through its New Play Development Program, the Jupiter Ensemble Theatre Syndicate, co-productions with other companies, and tours of new works. Mockus by George M. Johnson was originally workshopped and performed in Kamloops, BC by Chimera Theatre and the script and project are currently undergoing significant revisions. We are very excited to be premiering a new version of this show in Calgary in the spring of 2020. 
You can find out more about us or take a look at our 2019/2020 season on our website. 
Want to know more about our team? Visit our staff page to read up on the faces behind Jupiter Theatre.
You can also find us our Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter! Follow us to stay up to date on our fundraising goals for this project!

 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you've read this far, we're guessing that you're interested in helping us bring this amazing project to life. We do understand, however, that not everyone can afford to financially support us. If you'd like to aid the project but can't make a donation, there are two easy ways you can make a difference for us. 

Tell people about this campaign! Tell your friends, tell your family members! Make some noise and spread the word. The more people that know about our fundraiser, the more likely we are to meet our goal. 
Share this campaign on your social media channels! Indiegogo has great share tools. The simplest way to let more people know about this is by sharing it on Facebook, Twitter, etc. 

Thank you so much for your interest in Mockus and Jupiter Theatre. Your support, no matter how large or small, means a great deal to us.

story:
A Brief History of a Small Company ... 

Lucky Wench Productions has produced three shows previously, two of which were at the Edmonton International Fringe Festival ("Death Comes to Auntie Norma" in 2015 & "The Sunset Syndrome" in 2017). Both were critical and financial successes. We strive to create theatre that is by women, for all women. The team for Guenevere is 50% female identifying.

We Need Your Help

The total cost of this project is $3000. We have invested $1500 of our money in the project, and need help with the remaining $1500. Should we raise more funds than our goal, they will go toward covering costs so that more revenue from ticket sales can be passed directly to the artists involved.

We have twelve (12) artists you can sponsor, with wonderful perks included!

Playwright - John Richardson
Director - Eric Smith
Stage Manager - Brinnameade Smith
Cast - Jesse Harlton, Austin Kumar, Bridget Lyne, Brooklyn Melnyk, Andres Moreno, Ben Osgood, Maggie Salopek, Sarah Spicer, and Catherine Wenschlag

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to provide financial assistance, we ask that you please share this campaign with others - you just never know who will be interested until you ask! 

Many thanks!

story:
What is Catalina La O?

Catalina La O presenta: Ahora Conmigo is a solo theatre performance inspired by the life of musician and performer khattieQ, and the lives of Puerto Rican singers Myrta Silva, Lucecita Benitez, and Ruth Fernandez, among others.

Growing up in Puerto Rico, music was always playing in khattie’s house. Her mother adored the balada singers. They were glamorous and feminine. Feminine in a way that felt untouchable and dangerous to a queer little kid in 1980’s Puerto Rico. khattie’s mother died at the age of 49. The loss was sudden and world-shattering. As the years passed, khattie began to embody the character Catalina La O. Playing Catalina gave khattie the opportunity to express the feminine that seemed untouchable as a child. It also created an invisible link between khattie and her mom.

Through sight gags and clowning, confession and cabaret Catalina La O is ultimately a piece about survival. How do we survive trauma? How do we rebuild after a natural disaster? What do we become when we allow ourselves to flourish?

Why now?

Catalina La O presenta: Ahora Conmigo is a piece for the queer and POC communit(ies). It is a piece for the colonized body. It is a piece for women. It is a piece for Puerto Ricans. It is a piece for the non-gender binary. It is a piece for anyone who has experienced heartbreak. It is a piece for mothers. It is a piece for daughters. It is a piece for survivors. It is a piece for those who have been left to fight alone in the middle of a storm. It is a piece that speaks to resistance.

Who are we?

We are khattieQ (musician/performer) and Jenny Larson (writer/director) and we create collaboratively devised queer performance.

Hailing from Puerto Rico, khattieQ has played as a professional musician with over twenty bands including touring with queer femme core band The TunaHelpers. Jenny is an interdisciplinary theatre artist who formerly served as the AD of Salvage Vanguard Theater in Austin, TX.

Our piece Catalina La O presenta: Ahora Conmigo is the recipient of the 2020 Fringe New Play Prize from Playwright Theatre Centre and Vancouver Fringe Festival. This fall Catalina La O will receive a test production and we are raising funds to help pay the artists who are working with us on this project.

When is the performance?

We will present the film of the performance in October of 2020 as part of the Vancouver Fringe Festival.

We will premiere the performance as a live experience in the 2021-2022 theatrical season, as an associate production of the internationally acclaimed Neworld Theatre.

What do we need?

We are raising $6500 to cover the minimum expenses associated with paying our team for their work in September.

We have an incredible group of talented individuals gathered to bring Catalina La O to life. Everything we raise from this campaign will go directly to them. You can read a brief bio about our creative team at the end of our campaign details!

What if we don't meet our goal?

If we don’t raise the full $6500 we are still committed to honoring our minimum commitment to each artist.

What if we exceed it?

If we raise more than we are asking for, we will be able to pay each artist a larger honorarium. At present, their minimum honorariums are not enough. We need to pay everyone more. Thank you for helping us make that happen.

What are the perks?

We have the best perks y'all!

Including a digital download of the original music from the show by khattieQ and composer Anton Berríos, a Catalina La O sticker, and a karaoke party with khattieQ.

What if the show can't go on?

The show will go on!

We’ve moved early stages of development to digital formats in response to the current pandemic, and find this piece uniquely adaptable in its explorations on themes of isolation and survival.

The audience discovers Catalina sheltering in place alone after a catastrophic storm. She performs for the camera, desperate to reach her audience, and her mother, through the lens.

How else can I help?

Please help us spread the word!

Share our campaign on the Faceplace and the Tweeter.

And follow us on Instagram (@khattie and @_jennylars_) for all things JKJK.

Who is team Catalina La O?

khattieQ (creator) is a musician and performer from Puerto Rico. She has played as a professional musician with over twenty bandsincluding touring with queer femme core band The TunaHelpers. She was the creator of punk band BLXPLTN, and served as lead vocalist from 2013 to 2015. khattieQ has performed in a number of music festivals including, Afropunk in Brooklyn, SXSW in Austin and Pop Montreal. jkjklol.org

Jenny Larson (creator) is an interdisciplinary theatre artist. She has an MFA from the University of British Columbia. She served as the Artistic Director of Salvage Vanguard Theater in Austin, Texas from 2008-2017.  Credits include: From the Pig Pile by Sibyl Kempson co-directed with Shawn Sides for the Rude Mechs. Guest by Courtesy devised with Hannah Kenah, has played Fusebox Festival in Austin, Texas, SHE MAKES THEATER festival in Sofia, Bulgaria, and the Brooklyn Yard. jkjklol.org

Anton Berríos (composer) is a producer/musician from Puerto Rico. He has been composing and producing different genres from punk, funk, rock, hip hop, trap, Latin trap, Reggaeton, pop, and other Caribbean and American genres for over 20 years.  He was also active in Austin, TX music scene where he did sound in SXSW and produced several records of Pop, Kizomba, R&B, Trap, Rap, Reggaeton with different local artists.

Shanae Sodhi (producer) is an emerging theatre artist who lives and works in Vancouver. Shanae is a recent graduate of Studio 58. Recent producing credits include Coyuntura 2020 (Canadian Latinx Theatre Artist Coallition) and Straight White Men (ITSAZOO Productions). He is interested in creating work that helps the stories of marginalized voices find a prominent place in Canadian society.

Zach Levis (lighting designer/production manager) is a queer lighting designer, production manager, and wearer of many hats based out of Vancouver. Credits include: for Circus West, James and the Giant Circus Peach (Lighting Design), and for UBC Theatre, Revolt. She Said. Revolt Again. (Sound Design), and GOLDRAUSCH (Projection Design). Check out more of their work at http://portfolio.stellardrift.ca.

Michelle Thorne (costume designer) is an Award-Winning Theatre Artist originally from Fort McMurray Alberta. She served as the co-founder and co-Artistic Director of the Independent Company “Theatre; Just Because” She graduated with her MFA in Direction from the University of British Columbia, and has worked with the Arts Club Theatre Company as an Intimacy Coordinator.

Erika Champion (sound designer) is a Lighting & Sound Designer based in Vancouver. She is a graduate of the University of British Columbia BFA Theatre Production and Design program. Sound design credits include: Kayak (Echo Collective), Hosanna (Theatre at UBC), GOLDRAUSCH (Theatre at UBC). More info at: erikachampion.wixsite.com/portfolio

Heather Barr (stage manager) (she/her) is a queer stage manager based on the unceded territories of the Musqueam, Squamish, and Tsleil-Waututh Nations. Her recent SM credits include: Double Happiness: Detour This Way (N. Tam & R. Jacob) and She Mami Wata & The Pussywitch Hunt (the frank theatre). She is the 2020 recipient of the Jessie Richardson Sam Payne Award for Most Promising Newcomer. 

Joanna Garfinkel (dramatruge) is the co-creator, with Yoshié Bancroft, of JAPANESE PROBLEM, a site-responsive piece about the Japanese Canadian Incarceration, presented in Vancouver, at Soulpepper in Toronto, and many other cities. Co-created the pedicab adventure Tour for HIVE 3, (Electric Company/Universal Limited/Cultural Olympiad) as well as (Theatre SKAM/SummerWorks). Recent credits include Berlin: The Last Cabaret (PuSh) Poly Queer Love Ballad, (Theatre Passe Murailles). She is the project dramaturg for PTC.

We would like to acknowledge that we are building this performance on the unceded territories of the Musqueam, Tsleil-Waututh, and Squamish Nations.

*Video by Christina Nakhla, which included footage by Yasuhiro Okada and photos by Steve Rogers.

story:
Let's Keep Live Theatre Alive!

My name is Dan Kostelec, and I play your friendly, neighbourhood Shakespeare at Renaissance Faires, schools and more all over the country in my one-man, audience-interactive Shakespeare show, "Shakespeare Approves!". I take some of The Bard's plays and turn them into half-hour, live-action, interactive cartoons where the audience members are the actors, props, and scenery.

I'm not sure if you've been keeping up with the news, but the COVID-19 crisis is shutting down everything - including theatres and renaissance faires. And some of the most vulnerable people in this gig-based economy are your favourite performers from that world.

12th Night and the 3 Bears - Live and Online! is planned to be just the first in a series of online performances on Facebook where I gather some of my friends - your favourite actors from the Renaissance Faire community - to do live readings of my shows that I normally perform at the renaissance faires - shows like Macbeth: Death By Fluffy Kittens!, Titus Andronicus: Ya Know - For Kids!, and Romeo & Juliet: The Flying Implement of Doom Edition!

I'm looking to raise $1,100.00 for this first performance, so that I can guarantee each actor a minimum of $100 for their time in bringing us joy and laughter. And that's where you come in. We need your help to make it happen!

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $1,100.00.

  • 9 actors, earning $100 each
  • Indiegogo's fees
  • A little bit to maybe start the next show

What do you get? A part in the show!

If you're familiar with my live, in-person ren faire show, you know that I use the audience members as my cast, the set, even as some of the props. So keeping with that tradition, if you are able to donate to this cause, the first 4 people to donate $50 or more will get to be in the show. Yeah, it sounds like pay-to-play, because it is. But if you can afford it, I guarantee that you'll have a marvelous time!

The Impact

You will directly be helping professional entertainers keep "professional" as part of their job title, by helping us to pay our bills, buy our groceries (when we dare to venture outside during this social distancing period), and not sink deeper into poverty or credit card debt.

You're helping to extend hope and build morale for our fellow members of humanity by giving them a much-needed distraction during this crisis, a sense that a return-to-normal is not just possible but inevitable.

You're keeping live theatre alive.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Share this campaign with your friends, family, even enemies!

And that's all there is to it.
 

Thank you.

I love you - you love me - there is mutual, glorious affection!

story:
About the Play & Us

Brief Chronicle, Books 6-8 (From 3 Hole Press) is a “quietly heartbreaking new play that grounds epic themes—unabated longing, violence and imperialism, and the bond between mother and son—in the small ways we hurt and love one another and decide where to go on vacation.” This production is a co-production with Son of Semele.

This play is the inaugural production of Plastic Kitchen Collective. Most of us met at CalArts over the last few years. Through various collaborations, we struck upon an artistic engagement that challenged each of our individual practices and, when collided together, created something unfamiliar and exciting. Our ultimate goal is to avoid the rational and run head first toward projects that are wholly experiential.

Playwright: Alexander Borinsky

Director: Blake Harris

Actors: Cullen Arbaugh, Miranda Kahn, Cordelia Istel, Neha Sobti

Scenic/Costume Designer: Elizabeth Smith

Lighting Designer: Dylan Phillips

Sound Designer: Dan Gower

Producer: Betty Hu

 

Location: Son of Semele Theater (Los Angeles, CA)

Premier Date: December 1, 2017

 

What We Need & What You Get

Theatre is expensive. Like, really expensive. We’re raising $6,000 to cover some of the following expenses:

  • First and foremost, we pay all our collaborators
  • Set (paint, furniture, props)
  • Costumes (that marching band uniform won’t buy itself!)
  • Equipment rental
  • Rehearsal space rental
  • Documentation
  • Travel expenses

To make it fun and show you our gratitude, we’ve created some fun perks!

The goal of $6,000 ensures that, at a minimum, we can bring our collective artistic vision to fruition. If we don’t make the goal....we’ll have to make some really tough cuts and that’s just not great.

 

The Impact

We’re not going to make assumptions of what people will take away from this piece, but we know what we’re bringing to the piece.

We want to explore America’s imperialistic approach to global events and how that trickles down to our everyday interactions. We want to test the elasticity of attraction and repulsion. We want to create an experience that challenges the role of spectatorship. We want to challenge the very format of process and production. For many of us, our understanding of America has shifted radically over the past few months. We want to reflect, play and question what that might look like in a performance; not in a didactic way, but a deeply personal, and sometimes silly, way.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t contribute financially? Please share!

Instagram: @briefchronicle #briefchronicle

FaceBook: #briefchronicle #plastickitchencollective

And of course, come see the show.

Documentation
Travel expenses
To make it fun and show you our gratitude, we’ve created some fun perks!The goal of $6,000 ensures that, at a minimum, we can bring our collective artistic vision to fruition. If we don’t make the goal....we’ll have to make some really tough cuts and that’s just not great. The ImpactWe’re not going to make assumptions of what people will take away from this piece, but we know what we’re bringing to the piece.We want to explore America’s imperialistic approach to global events and how that trickles down to our everyday interactions. We want to test the elasticity of attraction and repulsion. We want to create an experience that challenges the role of spectatorship. We want to challenge the very format of process and production. For many of us, our understanding of America has shifted radically over the past few months. We want to reflect, play and question what that might look like in a performance; not in a didactic way, but a deeply personal, and sometimes silly, way. Other Ways You Can HelpCan’t contribute financially? Please share!Instagram: @briefchronicle #briefchronicleFaceBook: #briefchronicle #plastickitchencollectiveAnd of course, come see the show.

story:
Our Story

Alma Theatre is the brainchild of married duo Aksam Alyousef (playwright/producer) and Amena Shehab (actor). Hagar is their first mainstage theatre venture since arriving to Edmonton from Syria in the mid-2010s. The Canadian mainstage debut for Alyousef. Hagar will be presented at the ATB Financial Arts Barns in Edmonton from June 1-8, 2018, including two Arabic-language performances sponsored by the Syrian Cultural Heritage Association. 

While Hagar is not based on any one individual’s true story, it incorporates common, painful truths about the human toll of the Syrian refugee crisis into an honest, harrowing narrative. Part of Alyousef’s motivation for writing Hagar was to provide an outlet for audiences to “understand the deep humanity Canada has shown by receiving refugees as human beings, and not as a nuisance or as intruders. It is a thank-you letter to Canadians, and also a portrait of the [situation] that many refugees face.” With over 5,000 Syrian refugees having settled in Alberta from 2015-2017 alone, this international story has very local connections, told by two of Edmonton’s newest, distinct artistic voices.

Alyousef and Shehab have partnered with Edmonton and Toronto-based director Morgan Norwich, director of Canadian Fringe Festival circuit hit Redheaded Stepchild. Hagar is stage managed by FengYi (Mona) Jiang and features projection design by Alexander Boldt.

Tickets and more information will be available through fringetheatre.ca.

 

Perks, perks, perks!

In appreciation of your generous support, Alma Theatre would be delighted to extend some thank you gifts to our donors. Some perks that are up for grabs include:

  • Recognition in the lobby display and program
  • A signed Hagar poster
  • Complimentary tickets
  • "Lunch with the Artist" - we'll treat you to a meal with Aksam and Amena!
  • Prints from Syrian visual artist Aboud Salman
  • ... and more!

 

How else can I help?

Whether or not you are able to contribute to our campaign, there are many ways to support this production:

  • Share this campaign with your circle!
  • Come to the show! Hagar runs June 1-8 at the ATB Financial Arts Barns (tickets will be available through fringetheatre.ca shortly).
  • Tell your friends about the show!

 

The creation and production of Hagar is a true labour of love, and it is because of amazing people like you who spread the word, attend the show, and donate to the work that we are able to make this happen. If you ever have any questions about the show or Alma Theatre, don’t hesitate to reach out to us at theatrealma@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

Six Degrees Dance is a contemporary dance company based in New York City. We are excited to be gearing up for our  7th annual Six Degrees of Separation showcase in July bringing together 6 companies all removed from each other by one degree. This year's theme is "Becoming."  We love to collaborate with other artists and bring together talent that might not otherwise have the opportunity to work together, and this year we are thrilled to present our first commissioned work by the fabulous Sean Scantlebury of Battery Dance.

 

What We Need & What You Get

All of the money we raise goes towards theater rental costs and dancer salaries. The more we raise, the more we can share with our collaborators. Making art is really not possible without support from generous, art-loving individuals like you, and there is no amount too small to be hugely helpful. To show our gratitude, we have gifts! Invitations to open rehearsals, a tote bag, the opportunity to be an artistic collaborator,  and tickets to upcoming performances.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are other ways besides monetary donations to show your support. Spread the word about our show. Talk it up at happy hour, post about it on Facebook, bring a friend, Tweet till your heart's content! Or you can volunteer your time to work the box office or help out during the performances. And most of all, come see our work, discover 6 other companies you may never have seen before, and fall in love with dance the way Six Degrees makes it!

story:
Overview

Support an innovative theatre project that helps us with our mission of “Celebrating the kaleidoscope of people in Japan through theatre”

「演劇を通して色鮮やかな日本を描く」をスローガンとする、演劇プロジェクトへ皆さまの温かいご支援をお願い申し上げます。

Theatre Mangekyo presents 

Written by the ensemble members / 脚本：メンバー 一同

Directors: Juri Ito and Faith Evans / ディレクター：伊藤樹里、フェイス・エヴァンズ

Stage Manager: Natasha Milligan / ステージマネージャー：ナターシャ・ミリガン

Producer: Aya Kawakami / プロデューサー：川上綾

 

Come join our online work-in-progress theatre piece that was created using the devising process! The work is inspired by and developed from Japanese mythology and the lived experiences of our ensemble members around the world. The story revolves around the daily lives of modern-day gods within an online-like sphere of existence. This is not a retelling of Japanese mythology, but a window into the real lives of people in Japan. At first glance, Japan may seem mono-cultural but in reality, we believe it is a rich and diverse ecosystem made up of the unique individuals who call it home.

 

シアター万華鏡による、ワークショップ公演「Disconnected」へご招待いたします！

異次元の神の世界、「ニアーザ」における物語。オンライン上でしか会えなくなった神たちの日常を描いたワーク・イン・プログレス作品です。

今回の作品は、日本の神話からインスピレーションを得て作りました。しかし、日本神話の改作ではありません。私たちが今社会で直面する現実や、日本に住んでいる、もしくは日本とつながりがあるメンバーの経験に着想を得た創作劇になります。

世界中から、多様なバックグラウンドの人が集まり、出来上がった物語です。ぜひご参加ください。

 

Dates and Times:  Please click on the times below to look up your local time! The performance and feedback session will be roughly over 2 hours (TBC).

Place: Streamed on YouTube accessible via private link. Links to access the show and feedback session will be sent via email before the show.

  1.  July 15th (Thurs) - 19:30 JST / 06:30 EDT / 03:30 PDT
  2.  July 16th (Fri) - 19:30 JST  / 06:30 EDT / 03:30 PDT
  3.  July 17th (Sat) - 11:30 JST / July 16th (Fri)  22:30  EDT / July 16th (Fri) 19:30 PDT
  4.  July 18th (Sun) - 9:00 JST  / July 17th (Sat) 20:00 EDT / July 17th (Sat) 17:00 PDT
  5.  July 18th (Sun) 19:30 JST  / 06:30 EDT / 03:30  PDT

Feedback Session: After each workshop performance we ask you to kindly join us for a 20-30 minute interactive feedback session on Zoom that will help us with the devising process and progress from Phase 1 to Phase 2 of our project. Your perspectives, experiences, and opinions will help shape our final stage performance! If you cannot attend a feedback session, you can participate in the dialogue by filling out an electronic survey and submitting it after the performance.

Tickets:  1000yen (Included in all perks!)

 

ワークショップ公演は、7月15日（木）〜7月18日（日）の間、YouTubeにて、5回ライブ配信されます。チケットは1000円で、ご支援をいただいた方には、全員に配信用限定リンクをお送りいたします。

  1. 7月15日（木）19時30分開演
  2. 7月16日（金）19時30分開演
  3. 7月17日（土）11時30分開演
  4. 7月18日（日）9時00分開演
  5. 7月18日（日）19時30分開演

日時は上記をご確認いただき、ご都合の良い時間にご参加ください。もちろん、2回以上のご参加も問題ございません。

また、このワークショップ公演は、ワーク・イン・プログレスの作品です。みなさまには、各ワークショップ公演の後、Zoomにて20～30分のフィードバックセッションにご参加いただけます。いただいたフィードバック、意見、アイデアを参考にし、脚本をしっかり磨き、最終ステージに向けて準備していきます。フィードバック・セッションへのご参加が難しい方は、公演後にアンケートにご協力いただけますと幸いです。

※公演+フィードバックセッションで、2時間前後を予定しております (後日発表)。

 

Who we are

In response to COVID-19 and the BLM movement,  four women reflected on their current practices and wanted to contribute to positive change  in the world. We came together to create the Theatre Mangekyo project aimed at increasing representation, diversity, and inclusion in theatre in Japan.   We came together to create a kaleidoscope (Mangekyo in Japanese)  - a union of complex, intricate patterns in constant flux. We are all unique and we are always evolving as individuals, members of society, and a community.

 

2020年、新型コロナウイルスと、未だかつてない規模で世界へと拡がったブラック・ライブズ・マター (BLM) 運動。現実を振り返る中、日本で演劇活動をしている4人の女性が集まり、シアター万華鏡プロジェクトをはじめました。

多様な背景と、奥行きをもたせた、質の高い物語を作りたい。

大きい形から小さい形までさまざまな模様が入っていて、色鮮やかで繊細なデザイン。うっとりと吸い込まれるような不思議な世界が映り出される万華鏡。そんな「万華鏡」は私たちメンバーと、このプロジェクトを表すぴったりな名前だと感じました。

多様性が広まりつつある一方、理解が足りない言葉や無意識の偏見から、悩みを抱えている人もいることでしょう。日本の演劇における表現、包括性、多様性を高めることを目的とし、私たちは昨年から活動をしています。

 

What we are doing

The Disconnected project is made up of 3 phases:

Phase 1: (Devised) Workshop Performance 

Phase 2: Script Development 

Phase 3: Final Stage Performance 

With your support and purchase of a ticket to Phase 1, we aim to move on to Phases 2 and 3. Since we are using the devised process, YOU can be a part of the process! After the workshop performance, we aim to develop a script based on audience feedback and through working with members of the community we hope to represent. The goal is to create a piece that honors the diverse people who make up Japan.  Once COVID-19 measures allow, we hope to finally gather in-person and perform a final stage performance in Japan to record and stream for audiences all around the world.

 

本プロジェクトは、３段階を踏みます。

第1段階: (創作) ワークショップ公演

第2段階: 脚本制作

第3段階: 最終舞台公演

 

ワークショップ公演へのご支援により、第2、第3段階へと進むことを目指しています。

そして、もし興味を持っていただけましたら、皆さまも制作過程に参加可能です！

ワークショップ公演の後、皆さまのご感想を元に、脚本をさらに磨いていきます。このプロセスでは、多様なコミュニティーの方々とコラボし、参加メンバーを広げる予定です。なぜなら、色々な方々が自分たちの言葉で、自分たちのコミュニティの物語を紡いでいくことが大事だと考えているからです。参加にご興味ある方はご連絡ください。（下記参照）

新型コロナウイルスの状況が改善した後、メンバーで集まり、日本で最終舞台公演を行って映像として残したいと思っています。もちろん、それは世界中の皆さまにご覧いただけるよう、配信予定です。

 

What else is Theatre Mangekyo up to?

Inclusivity and representation are key values of this project.  In order to achieve this, the project members have been:

  • Proactively inviting interested members of underrepresented groups to participate in the project, regardless of prior experience in theatre or acting
  • Conducting interviews with people of various backgrounds to reflect their experiences in our piece 
  • Using the devising process to incorporate ensemble member’s voices in all stages of the creation process
  • Creating a safe space for members so they can comfortably share their experiences, and express their feelings through art   
  • Promoting the diverse array of people who have a connection to Japan through our My Japan social media series 

 

包括性は、私たちにとって重要な価値観です。そのため、下記の取り組みを行っています：

  • 参加者は演劇や演技の経験の有無で限定せず、興味や関心に重きを置く
  • その中でも特に、マイノリティグループの方々の声に耳を傾け、積極的に制作過程に招待
  • 多様なバックグラウンドを持つ人々にインタビューを行い、彼らの経験を作品に反映
  • 創作劇プロセスを使用し、メンバー全員の意見やアイデアを作品に反映
  • メンバーそれぞれが、経験や考えを共有できる、安心安全の話し合いの場づくり
  • SNSにて、My Japanシリーズを通じ、日本と関係のある様々な人々を紹介

 

With your donation, we will able to help cover the cost of:

  • The theatre space
  • Rehearsal space
  • Basic equipment such as lighting, audio, and video equipment 
  • Promotional materials and advertising

 

皆さまからご支援いただいた資金は、公演劇場、リハーサル会場、照明、音響、撮影器具等、そのほか基本的な設備、宣伝素材、広告費用などに使われます。

 

Donors can receive:

A ticket which gives you exclusive access to our workshop performance and feedback session after each show.

A 24-hour stories shoutout on our social media platforms*

A shoutout in a post on our social media platforms*

A small donation made in your name gifted to Black Lives Matter Youth (Nagoya)

A free download of the song Disconnected from our show!

A shoutout during one or all of our workshop performances (for donations made by June 30th JST)*

A bouquet of flowers sent to a cast or crew member of your choice sent after The Workshop Performance

A VIP all-access invitation to "Barlava Brunch" (Behind the Scenes talk with the directors, producers, and cast) on July 18th, Sunday 12:00PM JST 

A digital copy of the workshop performance with access up to 1 year

A thank you video message from our cast and crew

*you can promote your work, handle name, upcoming performance details, or even your friend's! You just tell us what to post. For those that don't need a shout-out, no worries. We won't post without your request.

 

ご協賛いただいた金額に応じて、下記のお礼をさせていただきます：

・ワークショップ公演チケット。詳細は上記をご参照ください。

・本プロジェクトSNSの24時間ストーリーにて、あなたが発信したいものを投稿（ご希望の方のみ）

・本プロジェクトSNSの投稿で、あなたが発信したいものを投稿（ご希望の方のみ）

・学生団体 Black Lives Matter Youth（名古屋）への寄付

・ワークショップ公演の曲「Disconnected」の無料ダウンロード

・ワークショップ公演内で、あなたが発信したいものを配信（6月末日までにご支援いただいた方のみ、ご希望の方のみ）

・ご指名のキャスト・スタッフへ花束をプレゼント

・公演後の二次会へのVIP招待。ディレクターやプロデューサーとの舞台裏トーク会「Barlava Brunch」にご参加！7月18日(日) 正午開始（日本語可）

・ワークショップ公演　動画アクセス権（1年間アクセス可能）

・キャスト・スタッフからのお礼動画メッセージ

 

Get Involved Today!

By becoming a backer you will contribute to our efforts:

  • To support a project that aims to create inclusive art 
  • To support more inclusive ways of storytelling through non-traditional forms of theatre 
  • To help provide a safe space for and encourage promotion of underrepresented artists
  • To contribute to raising awareness of social issues and inequalities in Japan through art 

 

私たちはこれまでの活動を通じ、マイノリティとマジョリティの間にある見えない壁、日本社会について知る機会を得る事が出来ました。プロジェクトに共感​いただける方に、ご支援いただけますと幸いです。

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Please like and share this page! Even if you can't contribute funds, you can join our email list to get updates on future shows and opportunities in theatre. We are always looking for people and sponsors who want to get involved. We are specifically looking for people with experience in writing, set design, video editing, dramaturgy, EN/JP translation, social media content creation, accounting, general administration, etc.  

 

そのほか支援方法、プロジェクトにご興味を持っていただけた方は、このページや私たちのSNSに「いいね！」と「シェア」をお願いします。今後の公演に関する最新情報をお届けします。

また、私たちはご参加に興味ある方やスポンサーを常に募集しています。募集分野：ライティング、セットデザイン、ビデオ編集、ドラマツルギー、日英翻訳、SNSコンテンツ制作、会計、一般事務

ご興味ある方は、ぜひご連絡いただけますと幸いです。皆さんと一緒に活動するのを、楽しみにしております！

 

Email：theatremangekyo@gmail.com

Instagram: @theatremangekyo 

Facebook: Theatre Mangekyo / Facebook event page: https://fb.me/e/4lQqPjO8U

Website：https://theatremangekyo.com

 July 18th (Sun) - 9:00 JST  / July 17th (Sat) 20:00 EDT / July 17th (Sat) 17:00 PDT

7月18日（日）9時00分開演
7月18日（日）19時30分開演
日時は上記をご確認いただき、ご都合の良い時間にご参加ください。もちろん、2回以上のご参加も問題ございません。また、このワークショップ公演は、ワーク・イン・プログレスの作品です。みなさまには、各ワークショップ公演の後、Zoomにて20～30分のフィードバックセッションにご参加いただけます。いただいたフィードバック、意見、アイデアを参考にし、脚本をしっかり磨き、最終ステージに向けて準備していきます。フィードバック・セッションへのご参加が難しい方は、公演後にアンケートにご協力いただけますと幸いです。※公演+フィードバックセッションで、2時間前後を予定しております (後日発表)。 Who we areIn response to COVID-19 and the BLM movement,  four women reflected on their current practices and wanted to contribute to positive change  in the world. We came together to create the Theatre Mangekyo project aimed at increasing representation, diversity, and inclusion in theatre in Japan.   We came together to create a kaleidoscope (Mangekyo in Japanese)  - a union of complex, intricate patterns in constant flux. We are all unique and we are always evolving as individuals, members of society, and a community. 2020年、新型コロナウイルスと、未だかつてない規模で世界へと拡がったブラック・ライブズ・マター (BLM) 運動。現実を振り返る中、日本で演劇活動をしている4人の女性が集まり、シアター万華鏡プロジェクトをはじめました。多様な背景と、奥行きをもたせた、質の高い物語を作りたい。大きい形から小さい形までさまざまな模様が入っていて、色鮮やかで繊細なデザイン。うっとりと吸い込まれるような不思議な世界が映り出される万華鏡。そんな「万華鏡」は私たちメンバーと、このプロジェクトを表すぴったりな名前だと感じました。多様性が広まりつつある一方、理解が足りない言葉や無意識の偏見から、悩みを抱えている人もいることでしょう。日本の演劇における表現、包括性、多様性を高めることを目的とし、私たちは昨年から活動をしています。 What we are doingThe Disconnected project is made up of 3 phases:Phase 1: (Devised) Workshop Performance Phase 2: Script Development Phase 3: Final Stage Performance With your support and purchase of a ticket to Phase 1, we aim to move on to Phases 2 and 3. Since we are using the devised process, YOU can be a part of the process! After the workshop performance, we aim to develop a script based on audience feedback and through working with members of the community we hope to represent. The goal is to create a piece that honors the diverse people who make up Japan.  Once COVID-19 measures allow, we hope to finally gather in-person and perform a final stage performance in Japan to record and stream for audiences all around the world. 本プロジェクトは、３段階を踏みます。第1段階: (創作) ワークショップ公演第2段階: 脚本制作第3段階: 最終舞台公演 ワークショップ公演へのご支援により、第2、第3段階へと進むことを目指しています。そして、もし興味を持っていただけましたら、皆さまも制作過程に参加可能です！ワークショップ公演の後、皆さまのご感想を元に、脚本をさらに磨いていきます。このプロセスでは、多様なコミュニティーの方々とコラボし、参加メンバーを広げる予定です。なぜなら、色々な方々が自分たちの言葉で、自分たちのコミュニティの物語を紡いでいくことが大事だと考えているからです。参加にご興味ある方はご連絡ください。（下記参照）新型コロナウイルスの状況が改善した後、メンバーで集まり、日本で最終舞台公演を行って映像として残したいと思っています。もちろん、それは世界中の皆さまにご覧いただけるよう、配信予定です。 What else is Theatre Mangekyo up to?Inclusivity and representation are key values of this project.  In order to achieve this, the project members have been:
Proactively inviting interested members of underrepresented groups to participate in the project, regardless of prior experience in theatre or acting
Conducting interviews with people of various backgrounds to reflect their experiences in our piece 
Using the devising process to incorporate ensemble member’s voices in all stages of the creation process
Creating a safe space for members so they can comfortably share their experiences, and express their feelings through art   
Promoting the diverse array of people who have a connection to Japan through our My Japan social media series 
 包括性は、私たちにとって重要な価値観です。そのため、下記の取り組みを行っています：
参加者は演劇や演技の経験の有無で限定せず、興味や関心に重きを置く
その中でも特に、マイノリティグループの方々の声に耳を傾け、積極的に制作過程に招待
多様なバックグラウンドを持つ人々にインタビューを行い、彼らの経験を作品に反映
創作劇プロセスを使用し、メンバー全員の意見やアイデアを作品に反映
メンバーそれぞれが、経験や考えを共有できる、安心安全の話し合いの場づくり
SNSにて、My Japanシリーズを通じ、日本と関係のある様々な人々を紹介
 With your donation, we will able to help cover the cost of:
The theatre space
Rehearsal space
Basic equipment such as lighting, audio, and video equipment 
Promotional materials and advertising
 皆さまからご支援いただいた資金は、公演劇場、リハーサル会場、照明、音響、撮影器具等、そのほか基本的な設備、宣伝素材、広告費用などに使われます。 Donors can receive:A ticket which gives you exclusive access to our workshop performance and feedback session after each show.A 24-hour stories shoutout on our social media platforms*A shoutout in a post on our social media platforms*A small donation made in your name gifted to Black Lives Matter Youth (Nagoya)A free download of the song Disconnected from our show!A shoutout during one or all of our workshop performances (for donations made by June 30th JST)*A bouquet of flowers sent to a cast or crew member of your choice sent after The Workshop PerformanceA VIP all-access invitation to "Barlava Brunch" (Behind the Scenes talk with the directors, producers, and cast) on July 18th, Sunday 12:00PM JST A digital copy of the workshop performance with access up to 1 yearA thank you video message from our cast and crew*you can promote your work, handle name, upcoming performance details, or even your friend's! You just tell us what to post. For those that don't need a shout-out, no worries. We won't post without your request. ご協賛いただいた金額に応じて、下記のお礼をさせていただきます：・ワークショップ公演チケット。詳細は上記をご参照ください。・本プロジェクトSNSの24時間ストーリーにて、あなたが発信したいものを投稿（ご希望の方のみ）・本プロジェクトSNSの投稿で、あなたが発信したいものを投稿（ご希望の方のみ）・学生団体 Black Lives Matter Youth（名古屋）への寄付・ワークショップ公演の曲「Disconnected」の無料ダウンロード・ワークショップ公演内で、あなたが発信したいものを配信（6月末日までにご支援いただいた方のみ、ご希望の方のみ）・ご指名のキャスト・スタッフへ花束をプレゼント・公演後の二次会へのVIP招待。ディレクターやプロデューサーとの舞台裏トーク会「Barlava Brunch」にご参加！7月18日(日) 正午開始（日本語可）・ワークショップ公演　動画アクセス権（1年間アクセス可能）・キャスト・スタッフからのお礼動画メッセージ Get Involved Today!By becoming a backer you will contribute to our efforts:
To support a project that aims to create inclusive art 
To support more inclusive ways of storytelling through non-traditional forms of theatre 
To help provide a safe space for and encourage promotion of underrepresented artists
To contribute to raising awareness of social issues and inequalities in Japan through art 
 私たちはこれまでの活動を通じ、マイノリティとマジョリティの間にある見えない壁、日本社会について知る機会を得る事が出来ました。プロジェクトに共感​いただける方に、ご支援いただけますと幸いです。 Other Ways You Can Help:Please like and share this page! Even if you can't contribute funds, you can join our email list to get updates on future shows and opportunities in theatre. We are always looking for people and sponsors who want to get involved. We are specifically looking for people with experience in writing, set design, video editing, dramaturgy, EN/JP translation, social media content creation, accounting, general administration, etc.   そのほか支援方法、プロジェクトにご興味を持っていただけた方は、このページや私たちのSNSに「いいね！」と「シェア」をお願いします。今後の公演に関する最新情報をお届けします。また、私たちはご参加に興味ある方やスポンサーを常に募集しています。募集分野：ライティング、セットデザイン、ビデオ編集、ドラマツルギー、日英翻訳、SNSコンテンツ制作、会計、一般事務ご興味ある方は、ぜひご連絡いただけますと幸いです。皆さんと一緒に活動するのを、楽しみにしております！ Email：theatremangekyo@gmail.comInstagram: @theatremangekyo Facebook: Theatre Mangekyo / Facebook event page: https://fb.me/e/4lQqPjO8UWebsite：https://theatremangekyo.com

story:
So, why Benches?

     20 years ago, Matthew Eamon Ryan wrote a song. A song of wanting, waiting, and hoping for someone to care for. He wrote a series of songs about this wanting and waiting. He turned to his good friend and playwright Frank Williams with the idea for a new musical they could co-write. They sat on park benches smoking cigarettes and talked about the stupid games we all played to get that someone to care for them. These talks became Benches a Musical. The show consumed their lives for awhile and a few workshops were performed but they never quite found it's voice.  They let it go for awhile.

      Time and a whole lot of life experience found the true voice of Benches for Ryan and Williams. The friends they made 20 years ago are still in their lives. Some remain close while others drifted away. Ryan, prompted by a recent life changing moment, realized that Benches is not about the stupid games played on proverbial park benches. 

    Benches is about the back and forth journey we take to find the people who we'll need the most throughout our time here on earth. It's about sharing the memories and laughs but letting go of the past. Benches is about our partners,families, and friends. The show follows the journey of 8 friends and lovers from their university days to middle age. We see them happy. We see them drift apart and reunite after many years when one of them is in great need.


Who are we?

     Cobblestones Theatre Company is a brand new Boston area theatre company founded by Matt Ryan focused on bringing new musicals to life for Boston audiences. We chose to present Benches in concert style for 1 night in the coming year at a Boston area theater to introduce its moving rock score to Boston audiences and introduce Cobblestones Theatre Company to the public.


What We Need & What You Get

We have simple needs for a 1 night show but simple needs can add up sometimes.    

  • Space rental along with amenities-$1,750
  • Paying our actors and musicians-$1,950
  • Rehearsal space-$500
  • Marketing materials including graphic design-$800
  • Insurance-$200                                                                                                                               What you get
  • You can say you were part of the re-birth of a  great rock musical and be part of the birth of a brand new theatre company.
  • You get to see and hear new musical theatre in its infancy before it's fully staged.
  • A whole slew of perks await you if you donate to our humble event. 

The Impact

Benches a Musical  has the potential to not only help fund full-scale productions of the full show in the future but also could help launch Cobblestones Theatre Company  on a high note. A very high note.
It could help us introduce and produce other new musicals along side Benches.
We want you to share in the reflective power and unending passion of new musical theatre and its writers. 


Risks & Challenges

The greatest challenge for any new work is finding its audience. Sharing our campaign will go a long way towards meeting that challenge. Another challenge is time. Daytime survival jobs and varied schedules give us a small window to perfect this moving piece. We as producers, writers, and actors risk passionately putting our heart and soul into the project without a built-in audience to share in that passion. We do know that once the audience is found they'll stay with us to the end. 
Other Ways You Can Help

The biggest way you can help is to Share this campaign anywhere and everywhere you can and Indiegogo makes it easy. Word of mouth, Facebook, Twitter, and anywhere else. Help us shout it out there. 

Follow us on Twitter and like our Cobblestones Theatre Company Facebook page to get more detailed updates about the upcoming shows and events.

Come see the show!

story: Hey there good people! Thank for stopping by to support Ahriana's dream. Ahriana aka "Brownie" is a 12 year old scholar (maintaining at least a 3.0), dancer, teacher, and peer leader. She began her training when she was 7 and actually taught her first class at 9, where she received a grant to choreograph a community performance. She is currently a student at the Paula Brown Perfoming Arts Center where she is training in pointe (ballet), modern, jazz, and hip hop. This past March she auditioned and was accepted to the Joffrey Ballet summer youth intensive in NYC. We have registered and paid for her first 3 of the 5 weeks available to her, but we need your help so she can finish out her summer. Tuition for the last two weeks is $1, 199 and her room and board is $1,450 (the $3,000 goal includes lunch money and group activity fees). Please help us send our chocolate ballerina off to twirl into her dreams!

story:
Since 2008, Recess Productions has been putting on partnered alt-blues/fusion dance events across the United States and Europe. We have at our heart the desire to build a strong and inclusive dance community. Towards that end, we created a 'no one turned away for lack of funds' scholarship program, in which people are granted scholarships based on their own assessment of their financial need.

In the past, we have not funded scholarships with fundraisers, but now we feel like we need community support for its easy continuation. This year has been a bit rough for us, with a huge amount of unexpected expenses (tax audit!?). And we don't want to enter this next season concerned about how we will ensure event access for our community. 

So...we are throwing a party! A party (and this fundraiser) to help support our highly important (and highly utilized) no-questions-asked scholarship program. It's also a great excuse to throw a wild, globally coordinated party with everyone we ever loved! 

In this last year, Recess officially granted $15,610 worth of scholarships to our events. We are aiming to raise half of that here to support the coming year's scholarships. Though who knows, maybe we will manage to bring together the full amount.

By inviting you to raise this money, we hope to foster a community of solidarity and mutual aid. Community funded scholarships send a clear message that we, as a group, value each other not for our financial contributions, but for our human capacities. Thank you for continuing to bring what you have to this community.

AS FOR THE DANCE PARTY:
Recess community members will host house parties all over the world on the same night (March 19th)--each furnished with your own vision and inspiration. Recess will coordinate a live stream of our favorite DJs and live acts from all over the globe. People donate for their party entrance (no one turned away) to help support the campaign. 

Oh, and the house party/scene that raises the most money gets to pick a person of their choosing to be flown by Recess, all expenses paid, to a domestic Recess of their choosing. So get ye to a party.

Hopefully, there is a party near you (if not you could make one).
Go to the Recess website for a-continually-updated list of hosted and coordinated parties: Boston, Denver, Valencia, Bristol, Vancouver BC, Denver, Oakland, Durham, Philly, Eugene, Olympia, Sacramento, Toronto, Montreal, Glasgow, and more to come!: Global House Party

Global House Party Facebook Event

We're all excited. And thanks in advance for being supportive of us keeping our events financially accessible and keeping our scholarship program alive!

story:
JUMP-START: tRpnyc! 

HELLO FRIENDS, FAMILY, AND SUPPORTERS!

We are excited to announce and launch JUMP-START: tRpnyc! a campaign to support, establish, and build the infrastructure of the New York based dance company, Johnnie Cruise Mercer/TheREDprojectNYC!

Founded in Richmond, VA in August 2014, the company made its move to New York City in May 2015 to further its growth and deepen its explorative practices! Dedicated to investigative the human subconscious through movement, while revealing the strength in human vulnerability, the company creates work that provoke emotional responses to political and contemporary happenings.

This year has been amazing for the company here in New York City, performing in various venues including; Gibney Dance Agnes Varis Performing Arts Center, Brooklyn Arts Exchange, Eden's Expressway at Movement Research, Harlem Repertory Theater, The Greenspace, Center for Performance Research, and even a recent residency at University Texas at Austin within the Department of Theater and Dance!

Though we have achieved a lot this past year, we are now prepared for the next stage in our development as a company as we solidify our administrative foundation. In an effort to budget funds for studio space, take care of administrative fees, as well as take the first steps towards producing our first NYC season!

Photo by: Scott Shaw 

THE FUNDS, THE BLUEPRINT, THE PERKS 

The company’s 2016-2017 season will see the development and reworking of both current and new works as we continue to cement our presence in the New York dance community.

In order to develop new/current pieces the company must constantly establish a practice and rehearse together. Paying for space is one of the main issues present while trying to create and build work! The donations accepted through this campaign will provide stability and promise space for further research and deepening.

A number of residencies have been confirmed in the coming months including, Silo Farm House in Pennsylvania in June, and Denmark Arts Center in Maine in October. Both residencies are only possible if funding is found to support the food and travel of all artists involved. Both residencies will play a major role in the creation process and connectivity of the growing company of millennials.

The funds will also play a major role in paying for marketing, community engagement, and other administrative fees. In order to expand the reach of the company, energy must be put towards both building a strong social media presence as well as expanding our current media base! Administrative fees also include application fees, festival fees, and other miscellaneous items that usually come out of pocket.

Each landmark discussed above will lead to a culminating NYC Season in 2017 at Center for Performance Research! All media, marketing, works being explored/created/rehearsed during the upcoming period will become the blueprint for this monumental inaugural season!

Photo by: Torian Ugworji 

Risks & Challenge

There are many risks and challenges related to this campaign and the process of creating within the contemporary company structure. One primary challenge is the issue of time and money. The current company of millennial artists is working tirelessly to create with minimal pay understanding they are paving the frontier for the RED project in New York City. All rehearsal space, and other related fees come out of personal finances. If our projected goal is not met the artists will continue to sacrifice, however, this becomes taxing on all involved. This campaign lightens the load financially on all parties involved, creating a window for space to play, create, and engage in dance freely.

Can't Donate? What else can you do? 

If you are not able to donate or financially help simply share the campaign or come to a performance! Maybe follow us on Instagram (jcruisem_theredproj), or Facebook. Join our email list! Anything helps! We appreciate your support, love, and guidance as we set the foundation of this company!
www.trpnyc.com

The donations accepted through this campaign will provide stability and promise space for further research and deepening. 
A number of residencies have been confirmed in the coming months including, Silo Farm House in Pennsylvania in June, and Denmark Arts Center in Maine in October. Both residencies are only possible if funding is found to support the food and travel of all artists involved. Both residencies will play a major role in the creation process and connectivity of the growing company of millennials.
The funds will also play a major role in paying for marketing, community engagement, and other administrative fees. In order to expand the reach of the company, energy must be put towards both building a strong social media presence as well as expanding our current media base! Administrative fees also include application fees, festival fees, and other miscellaneous items that usually come out of pocket.  
Each landmark discussed above will lead to a culminating NYC Season in 2017 at Center for Performance Research! All media, marketing, works being explored/created/rehearsed during the upcoming period will become the blueprint for this monumental inaugural season!



Photo by: Torian Ugworji 


Risks & Challenge
There are many risks and challenges related to this campaign and the process of creating within the contemporary company structure. One primary challenge is the issue of time and money. The current company of millennial artists is working tirelessly to create with minimal pay understanding they are paving the frontier for the RED project in New York City. All rehearsal space, and other related fees come out of personal finances. If our projected goal is not met the artists will continue to sacrifice, however, this becomes taxing on all involved. This campaign lightens the load financially on all parties involved, creating a window for space to play, create, and engage in dance freely. 


Can't Donate? What else can you do? 
If you are not able to donate or financially help simply share the campaign or come to a performance! Maybe follow us on Instagram (jcruisem_theredproj), or Facebook. Join our email list!  Anything helps! We appreciate your support, love, and guidance as we set the foundation of this company!

www.trpnyc.com

story:
Hey, Myrrhia Rodriguez here! 

I'm an LA-based dancer, choreographer, & artist.

Tenses by Pia Mannikko ©. (2015)

I've been dancing since I was 3 years old and earned a BA in dance at UCLA.

This summer I've been accepted into a once-in-a-lifetime graduate course at CSU Monterey Bay featuring the Trisha Brown Dance Company...

...this will be my first ever dance intensive!!

I am 1 of 26 dancers invited from an international applicant pool, and have been awarded a partial scholarship.

Without your help, I won't be able to attend this program!

Unsink by artist. Photo by Lisa Wahlander ©. (2015)

Trisha Brown Dance Company & repertoire:

"Trisha Brown Dance Company (TBDC) is a post-modern dance company dedicated to the performance, and preservation of the work of Founding Artistic Director and Choreographer, Trisha Brown. Established in 1970, TBDC has toured throughout the world presenting the work, teaching and building relationships with audiences and artists alike." www.trishabrowncompany.com
Brown considered Son of Gone Fishin'  "the apogee of complexity" in all of her choreography, and the end result is a seamless and fluid 20 minutes of movement. To learn more about this work, here's an interview with Diane Madden, Associate Artistic Director of TBDC, conducted by The Dance Enthusiast.

I'll have the honor and privilege to study directly under former TBDC company members and world-renown master artists Eva Karczag & Lisa Kraus.

Now You See Me?, by artist. Presented as part of REDCAT’s Spring Studio. Photo by Steve Gunther © CalArts. (2016)

What will the course be like?

Here's a synopsis from the CSU Monterey Bay class syllabus:

The morning session will consist of rigorous technical training that includes improvisation, embodied anatomy, Alexander Technique, and full-bodied phrase-work. The afternoon training will be based on applying the material from the morning into collaboration, composition, and performance. The course culminates with a public student performance, which will be a contemporary translation of this historical work created by the students and mentored by the teaching artists.

I CAN'T WAIT to perform this dance piece knowing  it's challenges and the weight it holds for the dance community and the form's history!

In addition to very full days in the studio, we will be attending evening lectures, forums, readings, special performances, and will have the chance to use the studios for our own physical practice. 

Gateway by Jmy Kidd, on Ace Hotel Roof, performed by Sunland Dancers. Photo by Jonathan Potter. (2015)

Every $ donated = AWESOME perks for you!

I've been awarded a partial scholarship toward my tuition, but I need your help to reach my the rest of my goal of $2,400. Every donation—big or small—guarantees you a special perk and an eternal thank you!!!

Here's how much I need to raise:

  • $1,500 for the remainder of tuition
  • $600 for room/board
  • $300 transportation & fees
*any surplus in donations will go toward renting rehearsal space and paying dancers for my next show New Shoes #9 at Highways in Santa Monica, CA this December 2016.

The Impact

Recently, I have had the pleasure to perform my own choreography at venues in Los Angeles, like Pieter and REDCAT. My dance career and practice are still forming, that I know that I will be deeply changed by this experience, and that my own artistic practice will be forever altered. 

"Something like this intensive workshop is a rare opportunity, and Myrrhia would be the perfect dancer person at the perfect time to participate in it. I hope it can work out." Jmy Kidd

I've been waiting for a workshop that focused on the particular niche in art and dance that I love so much, and I couldn't imagine a better program.
Thank you to Jmy Kidd, Vic Marks, Amilcar Aguilar, Raymond Ejiofor, Nite Jewel, Pia Mannikko, Lisa Wahlander, Pieter, REDCAT, Aaron Rodriguez for filming, and The Dandelion Council for instrumental music.

Risks & Challenges

To be honest, I've never attended a dance intensive, because I haven't been able to afford one. I was very fortunate to attend UCLA on a full-scholarship, without which I wouldn't have been able to pursue dance as a career as an adult.

Now that I am trying to dance as much as I can while paying bills, it will be a huge sacrifice to attend this program. I won't be able to work or access paid-time-off during my two-week stay.

But I don't want to let finances stand in the way!

I'm positive that the same work ethic, drive, and passion that has propelled me to overcome these obstacles in the past will be was pushes me during the rigorous two-week training and through any financial set-backs.

Floor of the Forest, by Trisha Brown Dance Company, at The Hammer Museum. Photo by Marianne Williams. (2013)

After Donating, You Can Still Help:

  • Share this campain (just copy/paste the page link) to friends and family!
  • When you see it posted on FB and Instagram, go ahead and give it a like/comment to bump it into a wider circulation on social media platforms!

FAQ?

Please don't hesitate to ask any questions you might have. I would love to chat! You can email me at myrrhiacreative@gmail.com.

Thank you so much for your time, donations, and support!! 

I can't do this without you!!! XOXO

story:
Who We Are

Full Time Fools, founded by Bri LeBuff and Nick LaPenn, is a performance art initiative that brings together a mix of professional performers and emerging artists to collaborate on the creation of vibrant circus performances.

About the Event

Dr Van Nostrand’s Collection of Curiosities will take place in October 27th- November 5th, 2017. Our venue is the Player’s Ring in Portsmouth NH. 

Event Link: https://www.facebook.com/events/107940586546512/

Ticket Link: https://playersring.ticketleap.com

What you're funding

Here's a little info on what these funds will go toward:

  • Booking top notch talent! We have some of our favorites coming from near and far.
  • The Creepiest of costumes. We need extra limbs galore!
  • Building our set. We need lighting, props, furniture, paint and decor... Oh My!

What We Want To Do

We know between training time, costumes, and  traveling costs shows can be a financial undertaking for performers, so we're dedicated to keeping costs for our artists down as much as we can.  As well as have access to all the supplies necessary to create all the freak show art our little hearts have dreamt up for you.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to give financially, please share and get the word out! 

Local Sponsors - Message or email us for more details on additional sponsorship levels. 

Don't forget to add us on Facebook, Instagram, and check out our website!

story:
• Datca Theater Festival will start welcoming its participants at during 16-18th of July as an innovative and avant-garde experience and has its ground on “conversation”.
  • During 3 days, Turkey’s most priviliged theater groups will perform their plays which have been played to a full house for years. The Street Fair will welcome its participants all day so that the interaction between the actors and the audience is not interrupted as the curtains are drawn.
  • The Street Fair will also host Q&A sessions, performances, concerts, game areas in order to create a theatric atmosphere with no charge and open to the public.
  • Our time is limited and we need your support to make this dream come true.

"CONVERSATION"

Theater is more than a performance art, it is full of conversation... However, it is hard to enjoy the conversation despite the daily rush. We aim to open up a space for the ones who want to listen to and talk to each other. With the clowns of Talebe Theater, open mic activities of Music Stage, Festival Coffee, and other activities, The Street Fair will become a conversation station with all these means.

"INTERACTION"

So that the conversation between people lead to better interactions, we also have a camping area. Participants are able to stay at Kormen Camping for four days with reasonable prices in order to organize an affordable and accessible festival.

story:
ELEPHANT

We started this project with an urge to raise money for Lora McDonald, the executive director of MORE2, a local KC social justice non-profit that works to fight systemic racism through awareness and legislative action. We met with Lora and up-and-coming KC playwright Lewis Morrow, and had a conversation about creating a story that spoke to MORE2's message. Out of this, Lewis conceived Elephant, a story based on a real-life incident of a black man being approached by his white female boss with an offensive request - to wear a chicken suit as part of a presentation to impress the company's CEO. The play dives into a discussion about racism in the workplace and uplifts the perspective of Black and Latin individuals, showcasing how microaggressions can fester and explode, and how people of color resist and persist against those tensions.

 

THE ELEPHANT TEAM

Producers: Casey Jane and Bob Linebarger

Associate Producers: Shawnna Journagan and Rusty Sneary

Playwright: Lewis Morrow

Marketing Director: Ryan Hruza

Director: Bob Linebarger

Stage Manager: Taryn Eby

Cast: Lewis Morrow, Shawna Pena-Downing, Rebecca Munoz, Ellis Wallace, Casey Jane, and Connor Eastman 

Set Designer: Kyle Dyck

Lighting/Sound Designer: Lacey Pacheco

 

HOW YOUR DONATIONS WILL HELP

We are working to raise $5000 for this production, and this online campaign will give us a head start into our fundraising event, which will be held August 16th at The Living Room.

What your donation will help us pay for:

- Compensation for the time and talent of our actors, tech crew, and stage manager

- Cost of venue

- Set, props, and costumes for the show

- Marketing materials and the time and talent of our marketing director

-Donations to MORE2

 

MORE2 (Metro Organization for Racial and Economic Equity)

A little about MORE2 (from their website more2.org):

"MORE2 was created in late 2004 as an interfaith social justice organization reflecting different cultural backgrounds, faith traditions, skin colors and economic means. We are united in our commitment to transforming our communities by creating a metropolitan area that embraces all people and offers everyone the opportunity to achieve their greatest potential.

As people of faith, we are called to break down barriers that divide us along the lines of race and economic status. We know that what affects any one of us ultimately affects all of us.  We are called to be agents of change in our communities.

We join hands through building intentional relationships among the people in our faith communities. This builds broad grass roots participation so we can walk the path to social justice for our great metropolitan area. Together, with our faith as our guide, we claim the power to transform our bi-state metro region by overcoming obstacles to racial and economic equity in Kansas City. Rather than providing services or programs, we work to change policies in ways that promote racial and economic equity in the Kansas City metro region. 

We are affiliated with the Gamaliel Foundation, an organizing network of affiliates in 21 states across the United States, in South Africa and in the United Kingdom. Gamaliel represents over a million members of various faiths and cultures who work for social justice."

 

RISING TIDE PRODUCTIONS (RTP)

Rising Tide Productions is a new theatre company based out of Kansas City, MO. Formerly known as Different Choices, RTP is dedicated to highlighting fresh perspective, bringing new ideas and woke interpretations of old ideas to the forefront, while raising awareness and funds for local non-profits and enriching untapped KC markets with grassroots theatrical productions. RTP is run by Bob Linebarger, Denver Little, and Casey Jane, three passionate artists who thrive on how differences and collaboration bring power to expression. So far, RTP has four productions under its belt:The Bottom of Everything, at KC Fringe 2012; Danny and the Deep Blue Sea in 2014, a heavy drama interpreted as a romantic dark comedy; Matt and Ben, co-produced, directed, and performed by Bob and Denver in 2015; and Silly Animals: A Comedy of the Human Drama, a 2016 devised piece resembling an episode of Planet Earth, performed by an ensemble questioning the result of humans separating ourselves from the rest of the animal kingdom.

We know that the privileged can and must learn to listen to the oppressed, and by truly understanding these stories, progress will be made toward the empathetic existence we are all capable of. Through communication and collaboration we can rise above the ways in which we hold ourselves back, and we believe it is stories like Elephant - and organizations like MORE2 - that help push us forward and up toward that goal.

 

SHOW DETAILS

Runs 9/7 - 9/16 at The Living Room, 1818 McGee, KCMO

story:
A little about us (because we're awesome.)

Hi! We're Hannah and Ashlyn (also known as BABYCHILD). We are both graduates of Illinois State University with majors in acting. As our senior year drew to a close last Spring, we found ourselves clinging to the walls of our favorite bar (Maggie Mileys. Duhr.) thirsting to do a capstone project that encapsulated all of our experiences as friends at ISU. Hence, "Best Show Ever!" was born. We are both aspiring actresses, but with idols such as Mindy Kaling, Tina Fey and Diablo Cody paving the way, we decided to try our pizza grease-drenched hands at writing a short comedy. As our show was majestically received, we then decided to dream bigger. After taking some bad@$$ improv classes in Chicago, Ashlyn found LA's Written Comedy Festival through iO West. We took a chance and submitted "Best Show Ever!". Yeah folks. We got in. We have the opportunity to perform our show at the festival in front of some uber important folks, as well as learn from and network with big time comedy writers currently in the television scene. As we found out about this oh, say, 3 days ago and the festival is February 16th-22nd, ANY AND ALL OF YOUR HELP is necessary to make this happen for us! The magnitude of a few dollars on your end well help make our dream a major reality! 

What We Need & What You Get

1. We need $3000. Yeah, harrowing much? But it's not going to getting our weaves done! Promise! We need...

- A rental car. Because LA's public transport sux. 

- Hotel cost for 6 nights. 

- Plane travel from Chicago to Los Angeles and back.

- Small amount of consumable props we need. (Because who doesn't want to see us shoving our faces with pizza while singing karaoke?) 

- We get discounts on tickets to the assorted workshops throughout the week, but we still do need to purchase our tickets. Therefore, in order to be able to take advantage of these unique and incredible opportunities, we need extra funding! 

2. And what do you get...? HMMM???

You will receive a myriad of gifts from us if you choose to donate! From social media shout-outs, to a written scene inspired by a life story of yours, a thank-you card to a tee-shirt with one of our show's one-liners, we will DEFINITELY show you the love if you show us some! 

Any funds we make will go toward as much of the trip as we can. NONE of it will go to waste and will all go towards this event. 

The Impact

This festival gives us an opportunity to perform a show that we feel passionate about and showcases who we are as actors and people. It played a huge role in how we view ourselves as theatre artists today, and would be an honor to have the opportunity to introduce it to a wider audience and see it through this far. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't spare a buck, our love don't cost a thang! Feel free to spread the word through social media, word of mouth or any other creative ways you can think up! It always makes an impact to spread the word about young comedians, so your support will only help.
