Therefore, in order to be able to take advantage of these unique and incredible opportunities, we need extra funding! 2. And what do you get...? HMMM???You will receive a myriad of gifts from us if you choose to donate! From social media shout-outs, to a written scene inspired by a life story of yours, a thank-you card to a tee-shirt with one of our show's one-liners, we will DEFINITELY show you the love if you show us some! Any funds we make will go toward as much of the trip as we can. NONE of it will go to waste and will all go towards this event. The ImpactThis festival gives us an opportunity to perform a show that we feel passionate about and showcases who we are as actors and people. It played a huge role in how we view ourselves as theatre artists today, and would be an honor to have the opportunity to introduce it to a wider audience and see it through this far. Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't spare a buck, our love don't cost a thang! Feel free to spread the word through social media, word of mouth or any other creative ways you can think up! It always makes an impact to spread the word about young comedians, so your support will only help.

story:
Who we are

Hi!  We are so excited to introduce our musical theater production, Baby...We Belong Together! to you.

Our names are Chantel and John Steinreich.  We have been married for nearly 17 years, and it was a shared love of music that brought us together.  For the past 15 years, we have been working individually and as a couple in live music projects, performing for weddings, parties, and special events.

Our Indiegogo campaign means the world to us because the contributions raised here will help us to achieve an artistic dream that we shared with our friend and fellow musician, Tony Brewer, in the production of Baby...We Belong Together!

In the fall of 2011, we brainstormed with Tony about an idea to put together a new soul music project, and we decided that we would develop an R&B musical theater piece.  Although he had never written a stage play before, Tony undertook the task of writing the script.  When we read it in December 2011 we were amazed at how charming, clever, funny, and honest his script was. Set in the 60s and 70s, Baby...We Belong Together! tells the story of Leon and Shirley, who find love in the most unusual place--on stage at at the nightclub where Leon is the star performer!  We instinctively knew that there was something unique about Tony's script, and that it would both entertain and inspire audiences, so as a team we set about to cast the show right away and plan for a debut performance in 2012.

Throughout the first half of 2012, we casted, rehearsed, workshopped, practiced, and fine-tuned the show, all with the purpose of debuting it on July 8, 2012.  While we were all enjoying the success of the development process, Tony was quietly suffering an unexpected illness, which caused him to be hospitalized in mid-June 2012.  Our cast pressed on with the process, looking forward to Tony's release from the hospital to rejoin us.  It was a devastating heartbreak for us all that, despite his medical team's extraordinary efforts, Tony's illness proved incurable, and he passed away on the morning of July 8, merely hours before the opening night performance.

Even while in the hospital, Tony had expressed to his friends and family how much he wanted to see the script he had written inspire audiences everywhere.  Upon his passing, amidst the countless tears shed by family and friends, and with the blessing of his wife, we performed the show that night in his honor.  It has been our passion from that time forward to continue Tony Brewer's legacy by continuing to produce Baby...We Belong Together! as an ongoing tribute to a great man whom we loved heart and soul.  Your contribution to this project will help us foster Tony's legacy.

                                                         TONY BREWER

                                                     2/5/1962 - 7/8/2012

 

     

About the Show

Baby..We Belong Together! is a story about love, respect, and forgiveness set to a dynamic soundtrack of 14 original songs and 6 classic R&B music numbers by some of the most influential soul music artists of all time including Otis Redding, Jean Knight, and King Floyd.  The production is a full-scope musical theater adventure, with a full live backing band and a duo of dancers supporting the cast.  

CAST:
LEON TRUDEAU...Lamarr Deuce Lubin
SHIRLEY WILSON...Jania Foxworth
EDDIE WILLIAMS...John Haynes
TAMMY PARKER...Sheri Whitten-Thompson
REGINA MICHAELS...Chantel Deniese
FLIRTY MAC...Devon Bethune
BETTY...Alica Felton

Written by Tony Brewer
Directed by Pat Dade
Music Direction by John Steinreich
Songs composed by John Steinreich, Chantel Deniese, and John Haynes

How You Can Help Keep Tony's Dream Alive

Putting together a live musical theater production requires lots of effort by a team of dedicated professionals, and it is through the hard work and dedication of dozens of individuals who knew and loved Tony that his theater dream lives on after him. 

At this time, we have a unique opportunity to run Baby...We Belong Together! on six consecutive Thursday nights between 2/6/14 and 3/13/14 at Theatre Theater in Los Angeles, which is a well-respected venue where hundreds of stellar productions have been staged over the past 30 years.  When you make your contribution to our production, you will be helping us with offsetting the costs of the following:

  • Theater rental for six night performances
  • Cast
  • Musicians
  • Director
  • Production assistant
  • Stage manager
  • Set design
  • Makeup artist
  • Lighting technician
  • Sound enginer
  • Rehearsal studios
  • Wardrobe and makeup
  • Audio equipment
  • Craft services
  • Promotional materials

We are specifically hoping that contributors will help us in the amounts of $100, $500, or $1000, although we greatly appreciate any contribution of any size.  Your generosity is greatly appreciated.  We hope to see you at the show!

Other Ways You Can Help

You can definitely help us by--

  • Liking us on Facebook: www.facebook.com/babywebelongtogether
  • Bringing yourself and your friends out to one of our performances: http://babywebelongtogether.brownpapertickets.com
  • Using the Indiegogo share tools to tell your friends about our campaign

Thank you for your support!  We look forward to seeing you at the show!

story:
What we're making

Our evening length dance piece will be presented at The WhiteBox Art Center in New York City on December 6th, 2014. In collaboration with The People Movers, the piece is part of CRAWL, a unique and contemporary model for arts presentation in New York City. Taking place in four distinct venues in various neighborhoods across the city, each production features two emerging choreographers as well as a third artistic act. Enza DePalma, Christine Jeager, and Lydia Zimmer will each present their work in an evening of visual and physical art. 

BLOOM

Somewhere secluded and far from us, there is a house. A house that, even in the cold of winter, can have brightness and life.

The feeling of a home is created by what's around you. Adding furniture and personal items make a space yours. Sharing that space with others creates memories. 

The conversations and experiences had in the rooms of your house breathe life into your home. Bloom peers into a house, far away from us, and discovers the life that lives inside it. 

What We Need

It takes a lot to put a whole show together! We have a wonderful team working countless hours to get this going; with The People Movers as our co-producer and The WhiteBox Art Center as our venue, we definitely have a good foundation, but we need your help too. 

The space to create the actual dance costs money. Studio space in New York City ranges from $10 per hour to $25 per hour and we need a studio to move our bodies and explore! Part of your generous donations will go to the cost of studio rental.

Scheduling is always a conflict when 6 people are involved, we want to make sure that we are compensating our artists for their time and commitment to the project, part of your generous donations will go to supporting our dancers.

There are two major parts of this production that need your help the most. 

The first is our imaginative and large scale set pieces. As you may have seen in the video above, ENZA creates large scale light installations for many of our shows. Bloom is no different, to create the feeling of the house there will be furniture pieces lit by fluorescent lights in the space. The dancers will move and manipulate these set pieces while telling their story. The furniture can be found easily, we always enjoy the challenge of finding used pieces, however the lights that go on them are more of an investment. A large part of your generous donations will go to the cost of the beautiful lights.

And the second, we are fortunate enough to have a beautifully talented dancer in our company who also plays the piano. For Bloom, it is our goal to have a piano as part of our set on stage. Not only to add to our design but to be played and have live accompaniment to our dancers. This combination of live music, set design and multifaceted dancers is a collaboration that we could not be more excited about. We've been lucky enough to work with Beethoven Pianos in New York City and have the rental cost of the piano waved, however pianos cannot move themselves and the moving cost in and out of our venue cannot be avoided.

The majority of your generous donations will go to the moving cost of a beautiful white piano to be played throughout our performance. 

There’s another way!

We would like you to know that any contribution, of any denomination helps, we are thankful for any and all of your support. We thank you for taking the time to learn about our project and hope that you spread the word to friends and family. Also, if you have any ideas, connections, or just want to share your opinion, we’re open to it!

Thank you, and we hope to see you in December!

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/crawl-chapter-1-ti...

story:
Why YA4Ever?

We are YA4Ever and this new branch of the Young Artists Ensemble, run by alumni, for alumni and friends. We created our company to benefit the place from which we all came and loved, YAE.  Young Artists Ensemble began in 1981, and now does and annual Family Theater season as well as Teen Dramas and Teen Summer Musicals. YA4Ever will provide an outlet for alumni of the YAE to do the shows they want to do with the people with whom they want to perform them! On January 11th and 12th we will be putting on a production of Urinetown, which will be our premiere production. The performing arts is something we all hold near and dear to our hearts, and therefore we are using this production of Urinetown and this online campaign to help us raise funds to do more shows in the future. 

The Breakdown

Our goal is $500 and it will go towards future productions to help keep our company up and running. We are currently rehearsing for our January production of Urinetown, and would love to see you all there (for more information go to yaeonine.com). Even if we don't reach our entire goal, the money we raise through this campiagn will still benefit future shows, so please contribute! All funds for this campaign are run through through the non-profit Arts Council of the Conejo Valley (Tax I.D. 95-310-5047) and the funds will be used exclusively for the YA4Ever production of Urinetown. Contributions are tax-deductible to the fullest extent of the law.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute, please join us for our premiere performance of Urinetown on January 11th and 12th. For ticket information, or more information about Young Artists Ensemble, please visit yaeonline.com

story:
About Me

Hi my name’s Emily and dancing is in my blood, coming from a long line of successful dancers. It’s what I think about night and day. Even when I’m tired, I just want to dance. I love the way it feels, entertaining people and continuing a legacy of classic dance from my great-grandmother down to me.
The problem is that I live in a small fishing village on the Pacific coast where dance opportunities are minimal, dancing at a small local studio and in my bedroom which I’ve converted into a ballet studio. I recently made my way to an audition for Goh Ballet, Vancouver and they accepted me on the spot! The problem is Tuition and Lodging add up to $20,000 annually, and the fact is, if I can’t raise the money, I can’t go.

Continuing dance at Goh will open doors for me into professional dance, my passion and career of choice. With your help, I know I can make it.


What We Need & What You Get

Tuition is $7000

Lodging is $13000

Ferry costs are $1200

Shoes and uniform costs are $ 750

I will send you updated photos, YouTube videos of me dancing and updates on performances.


The Impact

This would mean the world to me if you help me reach my dream.

I have dreamed about attending a professional ballet school since I was little, now it may be a reality and I don't want it to slip away.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I know everyone may not be financially able to contribute, so I will ask for you to please share with your friends, family and social networks. You can always use the Indiegogo share options as well.

story:
Playhouse Smithville is a small community theater located in historic downtown Smithville, Texas.  We seat sixty audience members in our black box theater.  Founders john & April Daniels and their son Matt have been funding this community driven program for three years.  What was once an old BBQ restaurant has been converted into a black box theater where shows ranging from Little Shop of Horrors to 1984 to The Rocky Horror Show have entertained central Texas audiences.  Each Christmas during the annual Festival of Lights celebration the Playhouse has produced a free Christmas show for anyone to see, performed outside on Main Street after the big parade. 

The numbers in the casts have grown and grown over the past three years and the Playhouse now averages 20 people in every show.  Many of the Playhouse's performances are sold out and are attended by folks from Smithville, Bastrop and the surrounding areas as well as by people from Houston, San Antonio and Dallas who like to drive down, see a show and stay in Smithville for a fun weekend getaway. 

The Playhouse founders would like to ask their many loyal supporters to make a donation, no matter how small, toward an upgrade of the lighting and sound equipment as well as a new sign that can be mounted on the building and lit up at night.  See our website at http://www.playhousesmithville.com

story:
DON'T MESS WITH GOD . . . HE'LL WASH YOUR FEET (DMWG) is an entertaining show with a great story and awesome music. THE SHOW IS POISED TO TAKE THE WORLD BY STORM!!!   I have witnessed how this powerful show has changed lives. Many times I've been introduced to an audience member who, with tears in their eyes, would tell me how glad they were that they came to the show because within those TWO hours, the show had made such an impression on them and their lives would never be the same.  I know that is only through the power of God!

God works through people. He worked through me to pen, direct, and produce the show so we could be where we are today. Now, I believe he will work through others to help keep it going.  

This is where YOU come in!  Help us keep this dynamic, entertaining and thought provoking gospel musical on the road and ultimately in New York. Your donation will not only make a difference in lives across the country, but also in all the artists and professionals working on the show.  

NOW IS THE TIME!

                                                       

                                                         

 

The Journey

"Don't Mess With God . . . He'll Wash Your Feet" was written in 2003 as "The Last Supper", and performed in parts of Southern California, Arizona, Virginia and W. Virginia. The show was rewritten and renamed Don't Mess With God . . . He'll Wash Your Feet in 2008 and continued performing in Lancaster, Victorville, Los Angeles (California), Charleston-W. Virginia and Lynchburg-Virginia.

The Journey Continues . . .

With a couple of box office stars, new sets and costumes the show is ready for the bright lights of New York. Prior to that, some of the planned stops are: Seattle-WA, Portland- OR, Atlanta-GA, Las Vegas-NV, and then "The Big Apple."  Campaign funds will be used toward $2,000,000.00 tour/New York cost. Costs includes: theater rentals and union crew costs, marketing, production, insurance, transportation, hotel accommodations and actor & crew costs. Tentative tour schedule is: Las Vegas January 18th, Seattle Wa March 7th & 8th, Portland OR March 9th, Los Angeles March 13th - 15th, Atlanta t/b/d, New York March 28th and continuing.

               

                                                          

                                

The Story

Frat brothers to the end. . . .

Years after they have gone their separate ways, the frat brothers come back together to pay tribute to Jude, one of their own, who has committed suicide. But they are in for the surprise of their lives, as the local Preacher takes them on a journey through the story of hope.

The Brothers lives are changed forever as they meet Jesus and the men of antiquity. They witness Peter deny his Lord and they are there as Jesus communes with His Disciples on that fated night.  The Brothers are stunned at the sheer underhandedness of Judas as he looks his Savior in the face with deceit and betrayal in his heart. And later, they are dumbfounded as the Savior takes on the role of servant when he washes his Disciples’ feet.

The Brothers’ pain in losing their Jude, prepares them to relate to Mary as she sings her feeling of agony in the emotional song “Miracle Child.” And then, they all experience the magnificence of Jesus’ ascension.

This powerful story is intertwined with moving music that will stir the soul. This emotional roller coaster EVOKES feelings of joy, sadness, hope and laughter.

Delivered by powerful actors who are also believers, their love for Christ and passion for the story bring an even greater in-depth performance of the characters. 

Fresh, invigorating and entertaining are just a few words to describe this play that you'll want to experience over and over again. Don't miss "The Greatest Story Ever Told"!

 

See A Clip Of The Show

 

 

                                                          

The Creators

                                                    

Dennis Rowe (Producer, Writer, Director) began his career as an actor performing in numerous plays and musicals, studying acting, vocals and dance.  Soon he began working on the technical side of the business; stage managing, light and set design, props, choreography and eventually directing.  His first show,
“Dream World” was the beginning of the producing bug.  A year later, Rowe produced his second show “Almost Famous” under his newfound company, Dennis Rowe Productions (DRP). The results, a reputable producing name and a NAACP Theatre Image Award Nomination.  Rowe was then asked to co-produce “God’s Trying To Tell You Something,” which played at the famed Hollywood Palladium and toured over 175 cities, starring Grammy Award winners Shirley Caesar, Edwin Hawkins, nominee Douglas Miller and Dennis Edwards from The Temptations.

Dennis also wrote and directed seven other shows: “Love In All The Wrong Faces”,
“Family Heirloom”, “Forest – A Fairytale”, “The Veil”, “Toy World”, Shades” and
“Saving Grace.”   His production “Don’t Mess With God. . . He’ll Wash Your Feet” is expected to hit Broadway in 2014, while “Shades” is anticipated to make it’s Broadway debut 2014-2015.

Recently, Rowe adapted two of his shows into feature films: “Shades” & “Saving Grace”. “Saving Grace” is expected to have it’s theatrical release in early 2014 while his production of "Shades" will be shot in 2015-2016. He is also in pre-production for the film "Jonin" written by Gerard Brown of the movie "Juice", fame.

Dennis has also written three books and is the producer of the radio soap, "Trials".

 

                                                     

Stafford Floyd (Composer/MD) Hales from New York and is a child of the 60s, the most prolific generation in the history of popular music. It's no surprise that he should end up a musician. He's played trombone and keyboards in top 40s bands and toured with major acts such as Earth Wind and Fire, Anita Baker, Madonna, and Destiny's Child, and has enjoyed stints as Musical Director for John B., The Force MD., and Circle of Faith. After studying in music with world class instrumentalists he ended up in Los Angeles collaborating with renowned song writers Holland Dozier Holland of Motown fame. He is the recipient of a Billboard Music Award for his work with the Supremes and has become an accomplished composer and sound designer having worked on numerous plays at the Mark Taper Forum, Pasadena Playhouse, El Portal Theatre and Bradley Theatres in Los Angeles. Mr. Floyd's television credits includes, The Motown 25th Anniversary, The American Music Awards, Miss Teenage Black American and a host of variety, news magazines and talk shows including the Motown Cafe', Sister Sister and General Hospital. He has generated bumpers and themes for commercial clients like Coca Cola, General Motors and syndicated shows for armed forces radio, television and foreign market specials like Jazz from the City. 

Additional Music

Veronica Brown (Composer) is a product of the beautiful crescent city of New Orleans, LA. Having a father and grandfather as music mentors, she has always had strong aspirations to enter the entertainment industry. Currently she is working on her first album with plans to release it this year. Song writing has always been one of her passions and she has committed to doing more of that these days. Veronica strongly believes you can reach any goal if you try hard enough and ALWAYS keep God first.

Jonathan  Floyd's (Composer) guitar licks will grab you with a familiar lilt and an unknown seduction that makes it clear why the lead guitar is in fact the leader of the jazzy string family. But this jazzman knows funk and he has certainly flirted with R&B. Jonathan Floyd's guitar is prominent on the remix of Al B Sure's hit "Right Now." This Cum Laude graduate of the University of Albuquerque is an original member of New York's Black Rock Coalition. Jon has toured with Living Color, and he's been an executive at VAP Records, Malibu Records and Jon Ray Music Publishing company. He is the Musical Director for the group Forecast. 

 

                                                            

                               

Why Should I Care About This Show?

*It gives you another chance of revival, renewal, and a wonderful refreshing spirit!

* This show has a great mentoring program for young people to participate as stage hands, light operators, sound technicians, ushers and box office personnel. The show is also a training ground for new stage managers!

* Based on testimonials from many who have seen the show, this is a blockbuster hit. Imagine you being able to say you were a part of making it happen. Hope to see you in New York!

 

                                                         

 

Why Fund on Indiegogo?

Why not? Conventional funding is very hard to get.  Since we are doing it for the people, why not go to the people! Sometimes we think its just the corporate guys or the rich and famous that get all the opportunities and are in a position to become a producer of project. BUT, ORDINARY PEOPLE LIKE YOU AND I HAVE JUST AS MUCH POWER, IF WE ACTIVATE IT!  The bible has countless stories of God using ordinary people. So, while I first resisted the suggestions to do crowd-funding, I decided, why not take it to the people and here we are. LET'S USE OUR GOD GIVEN POWER TODAY! 

 

                                                         

 

What's In It For Me?

Besides great benefits as outlined in our "Perk" section, "BRAGGING RIGHTS"!  You helped fund a show destined for New York!  You did that!

           

                                                          

 

We Need Your Help!!!!!

My team and I can lay the ground work, but it cannot succeed without you spreading the word. Please tell your friends, your church, co-workers and family about supporting this great cause by making a donation.

                              

                                                          

                

Is This Actually Possible?

All things are possible with God who strengthens us. Will it be easy? No, but with you praying and putting action on those prayers, together we can do it.

 

                                                         

                                

Reviews And Testimonies

 

 "The show features outstanding heart thumping vocals that will stir your soul," Tolucan Times

"It is a spirit filled performance that leaves you feeling you were right there with Jesus and his disciples," San Francisco Sunday Morning News

"An experience never to be forgotten! Keeps you on the edge of your seat with song and praise," KCWG Radio

"The lead singers had the audience in the palm on their hands. A must see!" Lord B4 Us Prod.

"A wonderful experience. I would highly recommend this play to anyone. It was truly worth the price of admission and then some." Jeff Moss WV Radio Corp

"I have seen lots of plays and performances, but I have not experience one like this. The vocals, the acting and most important the message of the gospel shows current day applications." Rev Larry Ginn  CEO Alpha Covenant Inc.

"The cast are able to offer an effective and moving portrayal of the gospel. We are drawn into their experience of devastating loss, exhilarating joy, deep questioning and triumphant faith," Dr. Michael D. Woodcock, Pastor FB Church NH 

 

                                                           

 

Staff

Ronald Johnson, Vice President - Production: Ron was raised in Philadelphia, Pa.  He attended Cheyney State College and pursued a Business Administration Major.  Ron relocated to Los Angeles and became a Manager of one of California’s largest law firms (PR department).  Ron’s marketing and public relations background gave him the opportunity to become more involved with the theatrical community.  He continued his business opportunity by opening C & J publicity with co-partner Denise Cook.  Their company provided publicity for theatrical productions such as “God’s Trying to Tell You Something”, “Claim It” with Mable King and “Zetta”. Ron’s co-producing credits include: Cliff Roquemore’s off- Broadway hit comedy “Lotto Experience The Dream” and several other DRE productions.

Ida Carter – Assistant Vice President – Marketing: Ida began her career in her home town of Saint Louis, Missouri working as a marketing/promotions assistant at Magic 108 FM. Upon moving to Los Angeles, she applied her newfound knowledge at KGFJ Radio and KUTE 102 The Quiet Storm and quickly perfected and broaden that knowledge by working as a marketing specialist.  She worked closely with clients to develop successful marketing plans and campaigns for their products and brands. Ida made a move to Talented Productions Inc./Solar Radio Station as Marketing Director where she supervised selling and booking spots to recording artists. She was also responsible for promoting the station to other media (television, newspaper, music magazines).  Ida moved on to higher territory at Warner Brothers Records as a Promotions Director for the Western Region.

Patricia Colbert – Director - Multi Media and Social Network: Born and raised in Baltimore, MD, she attended Morgan State University for Music and Communication. She decided to move to Los Angeles to pursue a career in Videography and Public Relations. Patricia won The Bill and Melinda Gates scholarship and completed her Masters in Education in 2011. Patricia is currently using her experience and education in Public Relations and Videography for Dennis Rowe Productions/Entertainment.

Jennifer Clarke -  Supervisor -  Administration: Hails from Kingston Jamaica, West Indies. She originally moved to New York in 1970 where she pursued a business major which she used in her twenty five years of banking in the loan department. She relocated to Los Angeles in 2004 to work in the entertainment field. She has worked extensively in all areas of film production and is to happy to now be working with Dennis Rowe Productions/Entertainment.

Paula Montgomery - Officer - Social Network:  Is a native of Los Angeles and is currently majoring in Computer Science, and Graphic Arts. She is also working toward her Bachelor of Arts Degree in Broadcasting, Cinema Television and Radio. Over a decade she worked in public relations for several telecommunication companies in Southern California.

Kisha Johnson  - Choreographer: Is no stranger to the stage. She is a southern girl who simply loves the performing arts. Growing up in the city of New Orleans where dancing and live music was a huge part of her life, it is no surprise that her career as a professional dancer opened her eyes to choreography as well as creative directing. As a professional dancer, she has performed for audiences around the world. She danced on various award shows such as The Grammys, BET Awards, AMAs, as well as television shows such as David Letterman, So You Think You Can Dance, American Idol, and many many others. Kisha is not only a great entertainer, she’s a true charmer and a wonderful artist to work with. 

Malachi Shackelford - Stage Manager

Ryan Franks - Stage Assistant                                                                            

Ben Brown - Stage Assistant 

Oren Williams - Stage Assistant

 

Videos produced by Patricia Colbert and Greg Atkins

Videos edited by Patricia Colbert

Additional pitch video edit by Chris Messere

Photography by Terri Griffin Photography

Theme song snippet in Gallery
 

      Press Gallery Tab Above for Additional Video and Photos
story_txt:
DON'T MESS WITH GOD . . . HE'LL WASH YOUR FEET (DMWG) is an entertaining show with a great story and awesome music. THE SHOW IS POISED TO TAKE THE WORLD BY STORM!!!   I have witnessed how this powerful show has changed lives.  Many times I've been introduced to an audience member who, with tears in their eyes, would tell me how glad they were that they came to the show because within those TWO hours, the show had made such an impression on them and their lives would never be the same.  I know that is only through the power of God! 
God works through people. He worked through me to pen, direct, and produce the show so we could be where we are today. Now, I believe he will work through others to help keep it going.  
This is where YOU come in!  Help us keep this dynamic, entertaining and thought provoking gospel musical on the road and ultimately in New York.

Your donation will not only make a difference in lives across the country, but also in all the artists and professionals working on the show.  
NOW IS THE TIME!
                                                       
                                                           
The Journey
"Don't Mess With God . . . He'll Wash Your Feet" was written in 2003 as "The Last Supper", and performed in parts of Southern California, Arizona, Virginia and W. Virginia. The show was rewritten and renamed Don't Mess With God . . . He'll Wash Your Feet in 2008 and continued performing in Lancaster, Victorville, Los Angeles (California), Charleston-W. Virginia and Lynchburg-Virginia.
The Journey Continues . . .
With a couple of box office stars, new sets and costumes the show is ready for the bright lights of New York. Prior to that, some of the planned stops are: Seattle-WA, Portland- OR, Atlanta-GA, Las Vegas-NV, and then "The Big Apple."  Campaign funds will be used toward $2,000,000.00 tour/New York cost. Costs includes: theater rentals and union crew costs, marketing, production, insurance, transportation, hotel accommodations and actor & crew costs. Tentative tour schedule is: Las Vegas January 18th, Seattle Wa March 7th & 8th, Portland OR March 9th, Los Angeles March 13th - 15th, Atlanta t/b/d, New York March 28th and continuing. 
                
                                                           
                                 
The Story
Frat brothers to the end. . . . 
Years after they have gone their separate ways, the frat brothers come back together to pay tribute to Jude, one of their own, who has committed suicide. But they are in for the surprise of their lives, as the local Preacher takes them on a journey through the story of hope.
The Brothers lives are changed forever as they meet Jesus and the men of antiquity. They witness Peter deny his Lord and they are there as Jesus communes with His Disciples on that fated night.  The Brothers are stunned at the sheer underhandedness of Judas as he looks his Savior in the face with deceit and betrayal in his heart. And later, they are dumbfounded as the Savior takes on the role of servant when he washes his Disciples’ feet.
The Brothers’ pain in losing their Jude, prepares them to relate to Mary as she sings her feeling of agony in the emotional song “Miracle Child.” And then, they all experience the magnificence of Jesus’ ascension.
This powerful story is intertwined with moving music that will stir the soul. This emotional roller coaster EVOKES feelings of joy, sadness, hope and laughter.
Delivered by powerful actors who are also believers, their love for Christ and passion for the story bring an even greater in-depth performance of the characters. 
Fresh, invigorating and entertaining are just a few words to describe this play that you'll want to experience over and over again. Don't miss "The Greatest Story Ever Told"! 
 
See A Clip Of The Show
 

 
                                                           
The Creators
                                                     
Dennis Rowe (Producer, Writer, Director) began his career as an actor performing in numerous plays and musicals, studying acting, vocals and dance.  Soon he began working on the technical side of the business; stage managing, light and set design, props, choreography and eventually directing.  His first show,“Dream World” was the beginning of the producing bug.  A year later, Rowe produced his second show “Almost Famous” under his newfound company, Dennis Rowe Productions (DRP). The results, a reputable producing name and a NAACP Theatre Image Award Nomination.  Rowe was then asked to co-produce “God’s Trying To Tell You Something,” which played at the famed Hollywood Palladium and toured over 175 cities, starring Grammy Award winners Shirley Caesar, Edwin Hawkins, nominee Douglas Miller and Dennis Edwards from The Temptations.
Dennis also wrote and directed seven other shows: “Love In All The Wrong Faces”,“Family Heirloom”, “Forest – A Fairytale”, “The Veil”, “Toy World”, Shades” and“Saving Grace.”   His production “Don’t Mess With God. . . He’ll Wash Your Feet” is expected to hit Broadway in 2014, while “Shades” is anticipated to make it’s Broadway debut 2014-2015. 
Recently, Rowe adapted two of his shows into feature films: “Shades” & “Saving Grace”. “Saving Grace” is expected to have it’s theatrical release in early 2014 while his production of "Shades" will be shot in 2015-2016. He is also in pre-production for the film "Jonin" written by Gerard Brown of the movie "Juice", fame. 
Dennis has also written three books and is the producer of the radio soap, "Trials".

story:
FEED The Dancers 2014!

Free Flow Dance Theatre was founded in 1995 by Jackie Latendresse and is currently in it's 19th year. The company became a not for profit in 2008 and has since continued to grow its annual programming and to make a solid name for themselves in the Canadian Dance world.

Free Flow has worked very hard for almost two decades to take a little bit of funding and to turn it into a fabulous season of contemporary dance works! Although the company does receive some government funding, it is not always available or enough. This year we are struggling to keep several of our programs up and running as some of our grant applications have not been selected for funding. 

In the spirit of communal effort, creativity and accessibility for all we have turned to crowd sourced funding to make it happen!

Our Annual Programming

Each season Free Flow Dance presents a number of amazing events including:

  • International Dance Day Showcase - featuring multicultural dancers from across Saskatoon.
  • The Works in Progress New Dance Series - featuring up to 10 different independent dance artists in performances in June and September as well as a Gala of finished works in December.
  • Back Alley Antics - a site specific traveling show down the back alley ways of Saskatoon.
  • Free Flow Concert events - which showcase the new works by the Artistic Director and other guest choreographers.
  • Community Workshop Program - This participatory program takes dance to folks who may not otherwise experience it in from youth groups to seniors homes and special needs facilities.
  • Community Performances - Free Flow attends and performs at a number of community based events throughout Saskatchewan free of charge!
  • Special Workshops - including, Hair and Stage makeup, Special effects workshops, choreographic and dance workshops. These are all open to the general community.
You can become a patron of the arts by making a contribution to our Feed the Dancers Campaign! Every little bit helps to keep Free Flow Dance Theatre active and vibrant!!!

Your funding will directly help keep dance alive by enabling our annual event and performance programming to continue and to flourish despite the unfortunate current state of government funding of professional Canadian Arts.

Company Mandate: Endeavoring to advance dance as an accessible art that can be experienced, appreciated and enjoyed by everyone.

Why $5000?
We are attempting to crowd source the amount of money that we had asked for from the Canada Council for the Arts.  This money will be used to ensure further success of the annual programming listed above.  We are good at making a little bit of money go a long way, so $5000 will help power a lot of our programs alongside of our successful government funding bids. For instance, it will help to insure that the Works in Progress Series has the ability to hire a choreographic mentor to work with the participating artists, It will allow us to provide FREE entrance to all community members to the International Dance Day celebration and more!

All funds generated from this online crowd source adventure will be dedicated to our programming regardless of how much we raise as every bit counts!

  • NEW PERKS! You could receive a hand made cupcake bath bomb, a Rosebud Burlesque Club Cook Book, or an invite to the Feed the Dancers Dinner Party!

Why Help?

Feed The Dancers 2014

In 2013 the Feed the dancers campaign successfully raised $1735 during our first campaign! This year we have substantially improved our perks and added a spectacular dinner party!

In 2014 our campaign is more important than ever as we have had some fairly major government funding cutbacks to deal with. Our track record with raising funds and generating income however is great! Not only have we overcome any financial hardships in the past and turned them around but we can now use our considerable experience to take the funds raised from this campaign and help our current programming continue to grow and flourish!

  • We can't do it without you! The arts sometimes have to rely on financial support from the public. We all know that art continues to increase the quality of people lives despite government cutbacks as it is created for the people!
  • Free Flow Dance Theatre creates a fun and exciting venue for dance in Canada. It supports Canadian artists and performers and by supporting the company so do you!
  • Every little bit helps keep dancers moving! Yes no matter how big or small your contribution it makes a difference! We thank you for all you do to support dance!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word for us about this campaign! It is as easy as pie! MMMmm pie! Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help: Share this on your social media and use the handy tools included on Indiegogo to help spread the word! The further the reach, the more people can hear about how they can help! We appreciate your time and energy letting folks know about us!

story:
Who We Are

Pilvax Productions is an independent, international company with a mainly Eastern-European background located in New York (USA). We strive to bring an infinitely open variety of productions to an international audience. Our goal is to consciously tackle projects with innovative, sometimes contrasting mind-sets to extract and combine its essential elements, thus bringing artists and audiences into a collective creative harmony. With themes ranging from the classics to today’s most contemporary works, the company aims to create a bridge between, and a fusion of, the standard and the avant-garde.

More information about us: www.pilvaxproductions.com


Winter Under The Table

“WINTER UNDER THE TABLE” by Roland Topor is returning to the New York stage after 12 years. With a new translation by Eniko Imre, Pilvax Productions is reintroducing this lesser known, delightful French comedy with an international cast.

Roland Topor was a jack-of-all-trades in the field of creative art. With notable works as an illustrator, graphic designer, author, playwright, film maker, song writer, actor and creator of innovative television programming, he was well known and much loved all throughout Europe. His most famous novel, “The Tenant” (1976), was adapted into a film by Roman Polanski. Somewhat revisiting the subject of that movie, “WINTER UNDER THE TABLE” was written in 1994 for the National Theatre in Mannheim, Germany.

Pilvax Productions, who has brought Zsolt Pozsgai’s “Liselotte in May” to the New York stage last year at the Dream Up Festival, is presenting this rare piece of European theatre. With directions by Timea Zsedely, it promises to entertain a wide array of theatre goers. Next to the thought provoking concept and subject matter, the play surly will provide ample entertainment with humorous situations, dialogues and physical comedy.

The play revolves around five characters from different social backgrounds. The story begins with Florence (Lisa Hufnagel), a middle class translator of foreign literature. For an extra boost to help her pay the rent, she sublets the underside of her dining table to an illegal immigrant. Her tenant is the attentive eastern European shoemaker, Dragomir (Roland Udvari), who’s previous addresses include a boiler room, a hollowed out tree trunk and even a family crypt. Their growing camaraderie is slightly sat back and complicated by the arrival of Dragomir’s free-spirited cousin Gritzka (Miklos Solyom). The three quickly begin to discover “trom” in each others company. However, this undefinable element to happiness, is disturbed by Florence’s friend, an upper-class divorcée, Raymond (Eszter Kovacs) and an overachieving, white-collar suitor, Marc (Christopher Kardos), who happens to be Florance’s publisher.

What happens to these people as their world of social and economic situations collide? Come and find out.

“WINTER UNDER THE TABLE” will be performed at The Gene Frankel Theater (24 Bond St New York, NY 10012) from September 11th through the 14th.


We Need Your Help.

As with many creative projects the most difficult thing in independent theater is to provide the necessary funding along with a strong creative energy.

Crowd funding is a great way to get the public involved in the production of quality projects.

Your contribution will help us with technical rehearsal and performance space rental, light and sound equipment, publicity, marketing expenses and some last minute additions to set design, props and costumes.

What We Need & What You Get

For this campaign, we are raising at least $5000 or more to cover our $10,000 expenses.

- Your contribution will help us pay for creative fees, Artistic and Technical teams salaries,  and all the other costs a high quality production requires.

- For your contribution you will be a member of our community of supporters and receive multiple benefits depending on your level of support.

- If you donate, you'll get some totally excellent perks! We’ve got special invitation to our tech rehearsal, autographed posters, Pilvax Productions T-shirts, mugs, ticket packages. Moreover... you can get Honorary EXECUTIVE PRODUCER credit in our programs. 

We are excited to invite you to enjoy this artistic adventure as much as we do, and to be connected through the support of a sensitive audience and the generosity of your time and donation.


The Impact

Our Hungarian based theater company called Pilvax Productions located in New York prefers European plays related to American topics as immigration, integration or solidarity. As enthusiastic theater lovers we like the classic, humanistic and naturally dramatized problems on stage as love, friendship, jealousy or poverty. This play is about all of these exciting human conditions and current economical issues. This delightful absurdist piece explores the themes of immigration, difference, integration, friendship and mostly the charm of love with great warmth and humor.
We would like to give a memorable, joyful and valued piece of art to our audience.  Your help certainly will create a wonderful international theater event in New York.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone is in a position to help out financially. If you are in this category, we still love you. We hope you'll take a second to help us spread the word.

  • Forward our email blast to people you think might be interested.
  • Let your friends and family know and "like" us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/PilvaxPlayers.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Come out and see the show! You can get tickets here: http://www.pilvaxproductions.com/events/upcoming/
  • If you are not able to support us financially but are interested in offering goods and services (legal, marketing, set, costume or prop support, etc) or are interested in advertising via our social media pages and/or print program, we'd love to hear from you. Contact us: pilvaxplayers@gmail.com

Thank you for your support and WELCOME to Winter Under The Table!

Tickets and more Info: http://www.pilvaxproductions.com/events/upcoming/

Thanks again! We won't let you down. We promise.

Who We Are

Pilvax Productions is an independent, international company with a mainly 
Eastern-European background located in New York (USA). We strive to bring an infinitely open 
variety of productions to an international audience. Our goal is to 
consciously tackle projects with innovative, sometimes contrasting 
mind-sets to extract and combine its essential elements, thus bringing 
artists and audiences into a collective creative harmony. With themes 
ranging from the classics to today’s most contemporary works, the 
company aims to create a bridge between, and a fusion of, the standard 
and the avant-garde.
More information about us: www.pilvaxproductions.com

story:
Welcome to the Cinderelleigh Pantomime Indiegogo campaign!  

I am a freelance film and theatre producer who has 15 years experience and have worked on many films and theatre including Calendar Girls, Made in Dagenham and Jane Eyre.  I also helped produce a panto that was seen at the Edinburgh Fringe at The Gilded Balloon.  I am putting on a family, fun, alternative panto in Leigh on Sea in Essex this year.  It is affordable for all, as a good community project should be, and all proceeds are going to three great local charities HARP (for homeless people), YMCA (16-25 homeless people) and Sunflower Trust (families of disabled children). The show will utilise all the amazing local talent we have here and raise some money for good causes.  I also hope it be a legacy project and be done for years to benefit the community.  Leigh Town Council is providing the rooms for rehearsals and show but there is no other money and everyone involved is working for free.   

The £2000 I am hoping to raise is for one reason only - to make the show look AMAZING! Production Design, Costume Design, Lighting and Printing costs. Although this is a community project we really want it to have high production values and for that we need a bit of a cash injection.  We have so much talent onboard already: professional costume designer Pip Hazell, professional production designer Jo McLoughlin who has over twenty years experience and theatre director Jo Melville who has a huge amount of stage experience. The script has been written by published local writer Samantha Lierens. We also already have some fantastic cast members onboard including Elisa Adams as our eponymous Cinderelleigh. Elisa is a well known local jazz singer who recently performed in a successful play at The Yard Theatre in East London and hosts her own nights locally and Ami Anders a singer and actor who recently performed at The Hippodrome, as Fairy Godmother.  The cast and crew are all giving up their precious time for weeks before Christmas to make the show come alive so it would be nice to feed them occasionally.

We've got some fun incentives to help with your generosity including being name checked in the show and front row seats. Take a look! Let me make it clear though ANY AMOUNT WILL MAKE A DIFFERENCE SO PLEASE GET INVOLVED. 

Any money raised will help the show, £2000 is the ideal, anything will help with costs and ultimately we will work with what we have.  We have an amazing crew all working for free who could create something magical with a bit of cash behind them.

This project will be so important for the community of Leigh on Sea.  Not just for the money it is raising for the three charities but also raising awareness of the arts for all pockets and using the amazing space that is the community centre.  Young, old, professional and beginners are all being given the opportunity to take part. The cast are all local and all extremely talented.  It's going to be a great show! 

We are also asking local businesses for help and looking for a main sponsor.

story:
LOVE MACHINE

What do a small town girl flirting with a satellite, a robot giving a lecture about transhumanism, and a man uploading his consciousness into the digital ether all have in common? Love.  

 

Premiering at

THE INCUBATOR ARTS PROJECT

May 10-19, 2013

at 8pm

(no shows 5/13 or 5/15)

 

Purchse tickets to the performance HERE!

 

What is LOVE MACHINE?

Love Machine is a story in 3 parts. Each part takes us further and further into the future as technology gets closer and closer to the human experience. The show looks at patterns in the way we use technology today and imagines some of the possible situations that may arise in artificial intelligence and the increase of virtual interactions. 

Continuing a long collaboration between theater and technology, the Love Machine team uses interactive, commercially available technologies, combined with improvisation and character-based writing techniques, to create a live experience blasting forward into the future and asking the questions of tomorrow.

 

Part 1, explores the 1974 launch and abandonment of the space station Skylab through the loving eyes of Cindy, a lonely girl with no date to prom.  Enter Skylab: a man-made satellite, strangely reminiscent of Fred Astaire.  Together they embark on a musical journey through outer space. 

Part 2 takes us to the year 2050 for a guest lecture on Transhumanism, a movement focused on furthering the human condition by means of science and technology. The talk is led by the robotically preserved consciousness of a transgender scientist and is followed by an audience Q & A.

Part 3 is an interactive dance piece that asks the simple question: how does a disembodied consciousness find love?  

 ** Part 4 is currently in development and will be shown only on May 10 & 11. It will feature the appearance of Bina48, one of the worlds most advanced social robots. She was created based on a composite of information from several people including, Bina Aspen, co-founder of the Terasem Movement.**

For more information about Bina48 and the Terasem Movement visit: https://www.lifenaut.com/bina48/

You may attend PART 4 by donating to one of the perks on the right of the screen.

 

Why technology in theater?

Love Machine belongs to a new wave of work dedicated to broadening the medium’s relevance and engaging the shifting tastes and expanding expectations of a modern day theater-going audience. We hope to create a 21st century toolbox, by utilizing the capabilities of today’s technology in unexpected ways. This will allow us to better imagine the stories of tomorrow. 

 

Who is the team?

Director: Andrew Scoville
Producing Manager: Karina Martins
Produced in association with Imaginary Media Artists and Fresh Ground Pepper NYC
Interactive Development: Dave Tennent, IMA
Projection Design: Kate Freer, IMA & Alex Koch, IMA
Original Score and Sound Design: James Harrison Monaco and Jerome Ellis
Costume Design: Emily Peterson
Lighting Design: Joe Cantalupo
Choreographer: Sam Pinkleton
Performers: Nikki Calonge, James Harrison Monaco, Sean Roshman, Lynne Rosenberg*
Written and developed by the cast and creative team.

*Appearing courtesy of Actor's Equity Association

 

What do we need?

Your donations will be used to help fund a portion of the following aspects of our production at the Incubator Arts Project this May. Any size donation helps! 

Building a set
Costumes 
Interactive video and sound technologies
Space rental
Research expenses
Insurance
Stipends for the cast and crew
Travel expenses for Bina48

 

Where have you seen us?

Love Machine has been in development since January 2011. We have utilized three opportunities for developmental showings, thusfar.

Part 1 was shown at Ars Nova's ANT Fest in July 2012.
Part 1 & 2 were shown at Playwrights Horizons Theater School (NYU) as part of the alumni festival, The Cookery, in September 2012.
A reworking of Part 2 was presented at Fresh Ground Pepper in January 2013. 

Past Prodcutions:

In 2009 we mounted The Office and The Metal Blob at The Cherry Lane. The show employed sound responsive video to realize our first digital character.

Our system of collaboration and aesthetic was refined in early 2011 with John Faustus and The Overclocked Death Drive at The Tank.  The production, a modern adaptation of Christopher Marlowe’s DoctorFaustus that materialized the devil via YouTube and a cross-dressing, iPad-wielding Mephistopheles, birthed our creative team’s unique working method based on the possibilities of implemented technology.  

This approach was taken a step further in late 2011 at 3LD Art & Technology Center, with All The Rats and Rags , a re-imagining of Charles Dickens' Oliver Twist set to the music of Brooklyn-based Tim Fite. The play brought to life a futuristic landscape of energy as well as a humanoid robot, both of which were made responsive through the successful integration of interactive iPad-based display techniques and a hacked Xbox Kinect. 

 

For further questions or press inquiries, please email futureactionsciencetheater@gmail.com

or visit

http://lovemachine123.weebly.com

story:
Greetings! 

We are Tremor Theater Collective, a group of performance artists devoted to making visual theater that reacts to the current political, economic, and social moment. We provide a space for ourselves and our audiences to remain conscientious and vulnerable in trying times.

Exciting News!

Thanks to YOUR support last winter, ‘The Rub’ was an acclaimed success in Brooklyn's Magic Futurebox warehouse, bringing Tremor’s unique brand of theatre to new audiences and enthusiastic reviewers. The Huffington post called The Rub "the most innovative, gripping and intriguing version of Hamlet that I've seen to date". Due to the tremendous response, The Rub was extended...

 ...It doesn't stop there:

Out of 131 applicants from around the world, The Rub has been selected to perform in the New Orleans Fringe Festival! We are thrilled to participate in a week of innovative theatre and spectacle from around the country. 

For those of you who were not present for our New York premier, The Rub is a site specific theatrical experiment. Its first home was a 20,000 sq. ft. warehouse in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. We used the entirety of this epic space to create a uniquely immersive adaptation of Hamlet.

The Rub is an exploration of the passion, complacency, delusion, anxiety, and desire that come with being the heir to a state rotting from the inside out. Hamlet's in the think of it and so are we. We reinterpret Shakespeare's tragedy through an absurd style and use references from pop-culture and contemporary politics, transforming the classic into an uncanny reflection of our present reality.

The Challenge:

The play will be readapted by a new cast for the Den of Muses, a warehouse space where colorful and off-color parade floats are stored for Mardi Gras. Come November, the collective piles into a van with our set and costumes. We travel two days to perform in a city and a space that will be completely new to us.

Why THIS adventure?

By revisiting The Rub, we deepen our exploration and strengthen our artistic voice. With a new cast and design team our collective has expanded. This is an opportunity to bring our growing community and our vision to the national stage!

Only with your help, do we have the ability to transport the cast and crew to the festival to represent New York's emerging artists with an unforgettable theatrical experience.

Your role:

The devotion and hard work of our actors and designers is essentially dependent on the support of our community. Last year your generosity got us to over 75% of our goal. This year our challenges are much greater.

In order to provide transport and accommodation in New Orleans, and to stay true our vision with new sets, costumes and lighting, we need to raise $7,000 through Indiegogo. The cast and design team are professionals who generously volunteer their time because they believe in the work the collective is producing. You can make your contribution to support emerging artists here OR:

To make a tax-deductible donation through The Field:

Check: Make checks out to The Field. In the memo section, please write Nessa Norich/Tremor Collective to ensure it gets to us!  Mail checks to: Tremor Collective c/o Helena Martel, Apt. 12, 243 Henry Street, New York, NY

Credit Card: Go to the Contribute To A Sponsored Artist page. Select Nessa Norich from the list. Click "Contribute" and follow the prompts.

The bigger picture: 

Tremor was founded by Lecoq and Barnard College alumna Nessa Norich. Norich created the collective not only as a platform for her own imaginings but to foster an ideal creative environment where actors are encouraged to play and create. We focus on nourishing the artist through a research and development process that is as intellectually stimulating as it is physically engaging. The product is a richly immersive experience for our audience. 

We cannot do this without you and everyone you know! After you've made your contribution, please share this page with everyone in your address book. We hope to reach art enthusiasts around the world!

"This is a truly inspiring and thought-provoking piece of experimental theater" -The Huffingon Post

"Contemporaneous and electrifyingly involving" - The Hooded Utilitarian 

Thank you for your continued support,

Tremor Theater Collective

Tremor Theatre Collective is a Sponsored Artist of The Field, a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the New York City performing arts community. Contributions made to The Field and earmarked for Tremor Theatre Collective here are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 161 6th Avenue, New York NY 10013, (212)691-6969, fax: (212)255-2053,www.testing.thefield.org. A copy of The Field's latest annual report may be obtained, upon request, from The Field or from the Office of the Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

 

**** SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT: 

10/26 FUNDRAISER LOCATION: 20 Goodwin Place, Brooklyn (off the Gates J Stop)

Exciting News!
Thanks to YOUR support last winter, ‘The Rub’ was an acclaimed success in Brooklyn's Magic Futurebox warehouse, bringing Tremor’s unique brand of theatre to new audiences and enthusiastic reviewers. The Huffington post called The Rub "the most innovative, gripping and intriguing version of Hamlet that I've seen to date". Due to the tremendous response, The Rub was extended...
 ...It doesn't stop there:
Out of 131 applicants from around the world, The Rub has been selected to perform in the New Orleans Fringe Festival! We are thrilled to participate in a week of innovative theatre and spectacle from around the country. 
For those of you who were not present for our New York premier, The Rub is a site specific theatrical experiment. Its first home was a 20,000 sq. ft. warehouse in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. We used the entirety of this epic space to create a uniquely immersive adaptation of Hamlet.
The Rub is an exploration of the passion, complacency, delusion, anxiety, and desire that come with being the heir to a state rotting from the inside out. Hamlet's in the think of it and so are we. We reinterpret Shakespeare's tragedy through an absurd style and use references from pop-culture and contemporary politics, transforming the classic into an uncanny reflection of our present reality.
The Challenge:
The play will be readapted by a new cast for the Den of Muses, a warehouse space where colorful and off-color parade floats are stored for Mardi Gras. Come November, the collective piles into a van with our set and costumes. We travel two days to perform in a city and a space that will be completely new to us.
Why THIS adventure?
By revisiting The Rub, we deepen our exploration and strengthen our artistic voice. With a new cast and design team our collective has expanded. This is an opportunity to bring our growing community and our vision to the national stage!
Only with your help, do we have the ability to transport the cast and crew to the festival to represent New York's emerging artists with an unforgettable theatrical experience.
Your role:
The devotion and hard work of our actors and designers is essentially dependent on the support of our community. Last year your generosity got us to over 75% of our goal. This year our challenges are much greater.
In order to provide transport and accommodation in New Orleans, and to stay true our vision with new sets, costumes and lighting, we need to raise $7,000 through Indiegogo. The cast and design team are professionals who generously volunteer their time because they believe in the work the collective is producing. You can make your contribution to support emerging artists here OR:
To make a tax-deductible donation through The Field:

Check: Make checks out to The Field. In the memo section, please write Nessa Norich/Tremor Collective to ensure it gets to us!  Mail checks to: Tremor Collective c/o Helena Martel, Apt. 12, 243 Henry Street, New York, NY
Credit Card: Go to the Contribute To A Sponsored Artist page. Select Nessa Norich from the list. Click "Contribute" and follow the prompts.

The bigger picture: 
Tremor was founded by Lecoq and Barnard College alumna Nessa Norich. Norich created the collective not only as a platform for her own imaginings but to foster an ideal creative environment where actors are encouraged to play and create. We focus on nourishing the artist through a research and development process that is as intellectually stimulating as it is physically engaging. The product is a richly immersive experience for our audience. 
We cannot do this without you and everyone you know! After you've made your contribution, please share this page with everyone in your address book. We hope to reach art enthusiasts around the world!
"This is a truly inspiring and thought-provoking piece of experimental theater" -The Huffingon Post

"Contemporaneous and electrifyingly involving" - The Hooded Utilitarian 
Thank you for your continued support,
Tremor Theater Collective

Tremor Theatre Collective is a Sponsored Artist of The Field, a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the New York City performing arts community. Contributions made to The Field and earmarked for Tremor Theatre Collective here are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 161 6th Avenue, New York NY 10013, (212)691-6969, fax: (212)255-2053,www.testing.thefield.org. A copy of The Field's latest annual report may be obtained, upon request, from The Field or from the Office of the Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.
 
**** SPECIAL ANNOUNCEMENT: 
10/26 FUNDRAISER LOCATION: 20 Goodwin Place, Brooklyn (off the Gates J Stop)

story:
For decades, Westville’s silent movie theatre and vaudeville stage built in 1913, languished in disrepair, forgotten amid the bustle of different businesses that would inhabit the structure for the better part of a century. 
 
In 2006, the forlorn, wood-framed structure, now listed in the National Registry of Historic Places, was purchased by antiques conservator John Cavaliere of New Haven and renamed Lyric Hall. John had been searching for a new home for his antiques and arts restoration business, and despite the building’s myriad issues, set forth on a mission of discovery and restoration that was in keeping with his chosen profession - that of breathing new life in to old, special objects.
 
As he continued to develop his primary restoration business, John would discover an additional calling after researching, and then restoring the building’s main stage and entertainment hall.  Almost immediately, artists and performers were drawn to the special spirit embodied in the old bones and new appointments at Lyric Hall. John found himself in a new and unanticipated role; that of “accidental impresario,” playing host to musical and performance art events, circus acts, poetry readings, book signings, cabaret and magic acts, celebratory events, and even the occasional silent movie with live musical scores by Lyric Hall’s own “Lyric Hall Theater Orchestra.” 
 
Presently, Lyric Hall serves as a kind of incubator - a home for original acts and plays, experimental music, theater, comedy, and creative “happenings” that the public can view and enjoy at nominal fees or for free. It is a place where ideas flourish and the community comes together to celebrate the arts. 
 
In bringing the building’s destiny full circle, John has transformed the cultural landscape of a neighborhood.  Today, Lyric Hallhttp://www.lyrichallnewhaven.com/ again resonates with the heartbeat of the creative community, but it desperately needs your help.  In 2011, a major flood filled Lyric Hall’s basement and storage area causing much damage and hampering Lyric Hall’s ability to host events in the historic hall above.  John had thought the flooding problem fixed because of work done on roadway drainage systems throughout the year.  
 
Recently however, after a severe rainstorm that caused flash flooding across the city and beyond, Lyric Hall was again damaged by flooding that temporarily closed the Hall, destroying mechanical systems, restoration projects and tools-of-the-trade that help augment Lyric Hall operations. (http://www.newhavenindependent.org/index.php/archives/entry/lyric_hall_flooding/ )The flood’s aftermath, which was covered in media reports on television and in newspapers, illustrated the scope of damage and the need for action.
 
 After a review by structural and site engineers, it was determined that many remedial improvements to the Hall are necessary. Infrastructure improvements will help address recurring flooding issues that threaten the future of Lyric Hall, and provide the essential upgrades that will allow the spectrum of creative shows and performances to continue unimpeded.
 
Though recently honored as Property Owner of the Year by Connecticut Mainstreet, a non-profit organization concerned with promoting revitalization of Connecticut’s central districts, John’s work is far from complete. As the building’s steward, he is committed to building on past successes, overcoming today’s obstacles, and ensuring Lyric Hall’s legacy for future generations. 
 
In just a few months, Lyric Hall and its community of friends and neighbors will gather to celebrate the building's one hundredth anniversary. Our collective birthday wish for Lyric Hall is for its continued health and viability.  With your help and support, creative projects, musical and performing arts will continue to flourish in the nurturing and magical space of this historic building for the next hundred years.

story:
2Cents Theatre Group, in residence at the Hudson Theatres, is thrilled to be producing our first official Mainstage Production!

 

We are a new theater company in Los Angeles, and have decided to start off with a bang by doing RENT, by Jonathan Larson. This piece won a Tony Award for Best Musical in 1996, and was groundbreaking and "the first of its kind", when it hit the stage. We decided to make RENT our first official Mainstage Production, because it has had a massive and personal impact on so many people. The late Jonathan Larson wrote it to bring light to the AIDS epidemic that was so prominent in New York in the 80's, and to tell the stories of struggling yet passionate artists, many of whom were outcasts in one way or another. Most people who see this show, see a version of themselves in at least one of the very colorful characters in this ensemble piece. Everyone in our company and cast is passionate about this piece, and we hope you will be too!

We have also established partnerships with AIDS Project LA (APLA), Being Alive, and AIDS Research Alliance (ARA), which are all local organizations that provide AIDS research and support, and we are working on a few more local partnerships, and some proceeds from our ticket sales will go towards supporting these causes. RENT is a massive undertaking because it demands high quality in sound equipment, set design and construction, costumes and props, lighting design and equipment, music, etc., and we are determined to bring Jonathan Larson's story to life thoroughly and completely!

We are also putting up a second production that will run simultaneously, twice a week, during the run of RENT. That production is going to be Steven Dietz's PRIVATE EYES. This is a very intelligent, hilarious, dark comedy that will run on Thursday nights and Saturday matinees, every week that RENT is running, as a sister-production.

Therefore, we are doing a three-part indiegogo campaign, and there are special perks for donating to all three campaigns. WE EXCEEDED OUR GOAL OF $2000 DURING PART ONE!! This is the second leg, and we are looking to raise $5000 as we launch into rehearsals, and are hiring our whole technical/production team. But let's try and surpass that, and get our next campaign going before it even starts! Any and all contributions are much appreciated, and there will be perks like free tickets to the shows, and some to our opening night reception and gala, free refreshments at the theater, posters and programs signed by the cast, tickets to our fall show and sister production, and even getting your name spray painted on our set!

If we do not make our goal, a larger portion of what we do raise is witheld from us, so it's very important that we reach it! If it is not possible for you to contribute, you can still help us by spreading the word. Sharing this event on Facebook, twitter, and telling your community about us in whatever way you can, helps out too! 

Plese check out our website at www.kboulepictures.com to read reviews of our last show, The Last Five Years, and to find out more about our company. And help us bring these powerful pieces of theater to life.

No day but today.

 

STAY TUNED FOR OUR "ONE-MINUTE NON-MUSICAL LA BOHEME" VIDEO COMING SOON.....

story:
Hi! My name is Louis Schermerhorn, and I'm the Business Producer for the 71st Annual Dolphin Show. Thank you for taking a moment to read a little bit about our organization, its legacy, and how important its success is to hundreds of students every year at Northwestern University.

The Dolphin Show

The Dolphin Show dates back to the 1940s, when the men’s swim team put on an underwater musical as the group fundraiser. Since its inception in 1942, the show has moved from the pool to Cahn Auditorium—the space it now calls home.  Over the decades, Northwestern’s student theatre community has grown into a vibrant world for those interested in the arts, with the Dolphin Show remaining the centerpiece: the largest student-produced musical in the country.

This year, we are especially proud to present My Fair Lady, with book and lyrics by Alan Jay Lerner and music by Frederick Loewe. With timeless themes and its roots going back to Greek mythology, we feel that My Fair Lady provides enjoyment matched by few other musicals. We are so excited to be able to present a show loved by audiences around the world!

What We Need

As an entirely student-run production, we rely solely on the generosity of our donors and our independent fundraising efforts. Initiatives like this one and others will all combine to provide our young artists with a budget deserving of a nationally recognized theatre tradition. Here are some of the things that are usually major expenses:

  • SET: Our show is produced in Cahn Auditorium, which is a gigantic theatrical space that seats almost 1000 audience members. Building a theatrical set that fills the stage and provides space for our forty performers is no small feat. Your donation can help us execute this massive design element.
  • COSTUMES: Did we mention that there are forty performers? The average cast member in our show has 3 costumes, which is already a lot before you consider that many of these costumes (for My Fair Lady) are designed to evoke the early 20th Century British upper class. Your donation allows the clothes on our performers' back to match the grandiose artistry of the scenery.
  • MARKETING: As part of the fulfillment of Dolphin's tradition, we aim to attract the widest demographic of audience available to us in the Northwestern area. This includes every student from every community on campus, Evanston residents and Chicago theatre enthusiasts. In a busy theatre city, this is a massive undertaking, and one our Marketing Team can succeed at with your support!
  • MUCH MORE: Lights, props, sound, equipment, events, the list goes on and on. Every cent you can contribute will benefit a facet of what it takes to put on a production of this magnitude!

Attend the Show!

We sincerely hope you will come watch this incredible show come to life from January 25-February 2nd in Northwestern’s Cahn Auditorium.  Purchase your ticket in advance at www.nudolphinshow.org to ensure you see this groundbreaking production. Also, follow us on Facebook for more updates as our project surges forward.

 

Thank you for your generosity and support of the Dolphin Show!

Sincerely,

Louis Schermerhorn

Business Producer
