story:
WHO WE ARE
Hello everyone, my name is Alessandra Belloni, I was born in Rome, Italy and live in New York City. For the last 30 years I have been the artistic director of the only professional Italian music, dance and theatre company in the United States I GIULLARI DI PIAZZA (the Players of the Square) a non -profit organization with whom I won several awards. We have been artists in residence at the Cathedral of St John the Divine in New York City since 1993 where we have performed many shows.

WHO I AM

In addition to my performances I often work as a teacher and healer, mostly for women, through my special drumming and dance workshops. This summer, French film maker Manex Ibar made a documentary about me and my work as healer/artist which will be released on BBC television entitled LIVING SHAMANISM. The Russian TV Travel Channel also filmed my workshop in Tuscany, Italy  focusing on the tarantella trance dance .

I have healed many people from depression and other emotional/physical problem through the tarantella trance dance and I have written a musical based on this story, which derives from an ancient women's ritual. I feel this powerful women tradition must be brought into the world and more commercial main stream theatre.

THE HEALING POWER OF OUR SHOW

 For the last 5 years I have been performing and evolving this powerful production entitled TARANTELLA SPIDER DANCE with my wonderful company which includes a cast of 20 performers, including acrobats, an amazing stilt dancer, an aerial dancer, fire dancers, and musicians, actors, dancers and vocalists specializing in traditional Southern Italian folk music, dance, ritual theatre.

This unique production is one of kind. It is a sensual, mystical show about the healing power of the Tarantella trance dance based on the myth of the tarantula, the ecstatic rites of Dionysus and the need of women today to heal their depression through drumming and dance.

When and where will our project take place

The current version of the show has evolved since its award-winning 1996 premiere at Alice Tully Hall/Lincoln Center. The revised 2007 version has been performed several times to sold out audiences at New York City’s Theatre for the New City and Theatre at Riverside Church and at venues in Lerici (Italy) and Spain.

We are getting closer to the goal of making Spider Dance into an open ended off-Broadway show. To do this we need to present a showcase to possible investors and producers. We urgently do need your support to complete this project as our funding from the State has been cut and has not been released.

  We have scheduled a new and exciting version of “TARANTELLA SPIDER DANCE” for the week of January 18, 2013 for 3 performances - Jan 18,19 & 20 at Theatre for the New City where the show has been presented to sold out audiences.

What we need funding for

Through this campaign you can make a  tax deductible contribution to our non-profit organization before the end of the year, a gift for the Holiday Season, or in January as we get closer to opening night to cover our production expenses :

Publicity: $ 2,000 – Newspaper and Radio Ads /Web/email/ Flyers/Cards


PRODUCTION :  $ 3,000 dance floor, rigging for aerial dancer, costumes/props, et, lights, sound equipment/engineer

Rehearsals /production$ 2,000 creative team : Alessandra Belloni , Joe Deninzon  James Karcher, Artistc & Music directors, writer, plus choreographer, studio rental

Artists fees : cast of 16 performers $ 11,000 - 5 musicians, 2 lead performers singers/dancers, 1 aerial dancer, 1 stilt dancer, 1 fire dancer, 5 dancers including hip-hop.

Guest artist from Italy  Massimo Cusato, percussionist, drummer , folk dancer from Italy

Total production $ 18,000

funds to be raised to meet expenses $ 8,000 matching the estimated $ 7,000 grant plus  ticket revenue
– If we do not reach our goal, all the funds will go to pay for the Artists’ Fees.

If we raise more than the funds of our goal we can continue moving forward with the off-Broadway development of the show.

     What We Need & What You Get

A donation of $15-50-100 supports design & printing of flyers email blast

$ 150 to $ 200 –studio rental –

A donation of 250 to $500 internet marketing, ad,

A donation of $600-$1000 supports dance floor, rigging, publicity

A donation of $1000-$5000 supports artists' fees and theatre rental.

You contribution will help pay adequate fees to an amazing cast of devoted artists who have believed in my project from the very beginning and work very hard for its success. Depending on your contribution you will receive wonderful gifts:

** Our CD of the powerful music of TARANTELLA SPIDER DANCE featuring the techno tarantella beat,

** My instructional book and DVD Rhythm is the Cure about the Southern Italian tambourine and Tarantella rhythms,

**My very special signature series tambourines that I design with REMO (largest percussion industry in the world),

** 4 of you can attend my summer healing dance and percussion workshop in Tuscany August 19th to the 26th. You will experience the tarantella power with each perk!

    Why  we are  raising funds, my  passion and  impact of our project

I have dedicated my artistic life to the research and revival of this rich and powerful culture from Southern Italy and after 30 years of hard work I feel that this musical can contribute to the heritage of the Italians in American . My show also tells the story of many women who have suffered abuse and depression, and it is dedicated to the healing power of the Tarantella and other trance dances around the world. A musical that empowers women through drumming and dance has never been done before.

TARANTELLA SPIDER DANCE tells the compelling ancient story of SPIDER WOMAN, who is an amazing aerial dancer, the mystical power of the tarantella mixed with the eroticism and sensuality of this women's healing trance dance of liberation, played by me on my magical tambourine, the uniqueness of this untold woman's story and the many surprises (fire dancer, stilt dancers) make SPIDER DANCE a possible off-Broadway hit that a could run for many years. It also has great possibility for touring in the US, Italy Brazil and perhaps a long run in Las Vegas. It could become the "Italian" River Dance, centered on the Italian dance of the Tarantella, a musical, enchanting, powerful, erotic, and healing dance from Puglia.

  Why our project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.

SPIDER DANCE is  a spectacular show (in the vein of FELA, ObaOba, Riverdance) that could become a successful long Off-Broadway run in a New York theatre of at least [299 ] seats and at most [499 ] seats. We are facing a challenging time in the world and in times like this the public needs the positive energy and healing experience that this production brings through this collective ritual of liberation .  In our previous performances the audience always left the theatre mesmerized and you can see it on our presentation video.

 The show also : showcases Greek and Italian mythology, traditional and modern music instrumentation and choreography.  Displays the curative and transformative powers of “trance” dance.  Appeals to a wide and diverse audience.  Has  educational opportunities: classes and workshops on trance dance & drumming.

     WHAT WE HAVE DONE IN THE PAST

 Our Company I GIULLARI DI PIAZZA, funded in 1980 has performed at Lincoln Center, Carnegie Hall, Madison Square Garden, Cleveland Museum of Art, Getty Center, Epcot center and many more.

I have written and directed many folk Operas. Our first TARANTATA DANCE OF THE ANCIENT SPIDER was commissioned by Lincoln Center and presented to a sold out audience at Alice Tully hall in 1996. We have also presented other powerful productions at the Cathedral of St John the Divine , as STABAT MATER DONNA DE PARADISO, THE VOYAGE OF THE BLACK MADONNA, “LA LUPA” , THE SHEPHERDS’ SONG, always receiving wide audience and critical acclaim, many favorable reviews from the New York and Los Angeles Times.

As a singer and a percussionist, I have done great shows around the world, (Italy, England, Poland, France, Spain, Brazil, Australia, Israel, Egypt, Korea) with great reviews and awards also from Modern Drummer and DRUM Magazine and television coverage. I aslo design my signature series tambourines with REMO and wrote the  book/DVD on the tarantella rhtythms, RHYTHM IS THE CURE with Mel Bay Publications. You can see these links & enjoy ! 

 "Spider Sex documentary " on National Geographic http://youtu.be/vp8dE3jJnq0

Live Appearance on ABC-TV7 Chicagohttp://youtu.be/3J9ZlzKLzPw

CNN Worldbeat http://youtu.be/IkOqBrpcB9Q

Russian TV “ “The Dancing Planet”http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Iktp2PIhKWw

www.alessandrabelloni.com www.facebook.com/alessandrabelloni www.yotube.com/alessandrabelloni

We have been artists in residence at the Cathedral of St John the Divine in New York City since 1993 where we have performed many shows.
WHO I AM
In addition to my performances I often work as a teacher and healer, mostly for women, through my special drumming and dance workshops. This summer, French film maker Manex Ibar made a documentary about me and my work as healer/artist which will be released on BBC television entitled LIVING SHAMANISM. The Russian TV Travel Channel also filmed my workshop in Tuscany, Italy  focusing on the tarantella trance dance .
I have healed many people from depression and other emotional/physical problem through the tarantella trance dance and I have written a musical based on this story, which derives from an ancient women's ritual. I feel this powerful women tradition must be brought into the world and more commercial main stream theatre.
THE HEALING POWER OF OUR SHOW
 For the last 5 years I have been performing and evolving this powerful production entitled TARANTELLA SPIDER DANCE with my wonderful company which includes a cast of 20 performers, including acrobats, an amazing stilt dancer, an aerial dancer, fire dancers, and musicians, actors, dancers and vocalists specializing in traditional Southern Italian folk music, dance, ritual theatre.
This unique production is one of kind. It is a sensual, mystical show about the healing power of the Tarantella trance dance based on the myth of the tarantula, the ecstatic rites of Dionysus and the need of women today to heal their depression through drumming and dance.
When and where will our project take place 
The current version of the show has evolved since its award-winning 1996 premiere at Alice Tully Hall/Lincoln Center. The revised 2007 version has been performed several times to sold out audiences at New York City’s Theatre for the New City and Theatre at Riverside Church and at venues in Lerici (Italy) and Spain.
We are getting closer to the goal of making Spider Dance into an open ended off-Broadway show. To do this we need to present a showcase to possible investors and producers. We urgently do need your support to complete this project as our funding from the State has been cut and has not been released.
  We have scheduled a new and exciting version of “TARANTELLA SPIDER DANCE” for the week of January 18, 2013 for 3 performances - Jan 18,19 & 20 at Theatre for the New City where the show has been presented to sold out audiences.
What we need funding for
Through this campaign you can make a  tax deductible contribution to our non-profit organization before the end of the year, a gift for the Holiday Season, or in January as we get closer to opening night to cover our production expenses :
Publicity: $ 2,000 – Newspaper and Radio Ads /Web/email/ Flyers/Cards
PRODUCTION :  $ 3,000 dance floor, rigging for aerial dancer, costumes/props, et, lights, sound equipment/engineer
Rehearsals /production$ 2,000 creative team : Alessandra Belloni , Joe Deninzon  James Karcher, Artistc & Music directors, writer, plus choreographer, studio rental
Artists fees : cast of 16 performers $ 11,000 - 5 musicians, 2 lead performers singers/dancers, 1 aerial dancer, 1 stilt dancer, 1 fire dancer, 5 dancers including hip-hop.
Guest artist from Italy  Massimo Cusato, percussionist, drummer , folk dancer from Italy
Total production $ 18,000 
funds to be raised to meet expenses $ 8,000 matching the estimated $ 7,000 grant plus  ticket revenue– If we do not reach our goal, all the funds will go to pay for the Artists’ Fees.
If we raise more than the funds of our goal we can continue moving forward with the off-Broadway development of the show.
     What We Need & What You Get
A donation of $15-50-100 supports design & printing of flyers email blast
$ 150 to $ 200 –studio rental –
A donation of 250 to $500 internet marketing, ad,
A donation of $600-$1000 supports dance floor, rigging, publicity
A donation of $1000-$5000 supports artists' fees and theatre rental.
You contribution will help pay adequate fees to an amazing cast of devoted artists who have believed in my project from the very beginning and work very hard for its success. Depending on your contribution you will receive wonderful gifts:
** Our CD of the powerful music of TARANTELLA SPIDER DANCE featuring the techno tarantella beat,
** My instructional book and DVD Rhythm is the Cure about the Southern Italian tambourine and Tarantella rhythms,
**My very special signature series tambourines that I design with REMO (largest percussion industry in the world),
** 4 of you can attend my summer healing dance and percussion workshop in Tuscany August 19th to the 26th. You will experience the tarantella power with each perk!
    Why  we are  raising funds, my  passion and  impact of our project 
I have dedicated my artistic life to the research and revival of this rich and powerful culture from Southern Italy and after 30 years of hard work I feel that this musical can contribute to the heritage of the Italians in American . My show also tells the story of many women who have suffered abuse and depression, and it is dedicated to the healing power of the Tarantella and other trance dances around the world. A musical that empowers women through drumming and dance has never been done before.
TARANTELLA SPIDER DANCE tells the compelling ancient story of SPIDER WOMAN, who is an amazing aerial dancer, the mystical power of the tarantella mixed with the eroticism and sensuality of this women's healing trance dance of liberation, played by me on my magical tambourine, the uniqueness of this untold woman's story and the many surprises (fire dancer, stilt dancers) make SPIDER DANCE a possible off-Broadway hit that a could run for many years. It also has great possibility for touring in the US, Italy Brazil and perhaps a long run in Las Vegas. It could become the "Italian" River Dance, centered on the Italian dance of the Tarantella, a musical, enchanting, powerful, erotic, and healing dance from Puglia.
  Why our project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
SPIDER DANCE is  a spectacular show (in the vein of FELA, ObaOba, Riverdance) that could become a successful long Off-Broadway run in a New York theatre of at least [299 ] seats and at most [499 ] seats. We are facing a challenging time in the world and in times like this the public needs the positive energy and healing experience that this production brings through this collective ritual of liberation .  In our previous performances the audience always left the theatre mesmerized and you can see it on our presentation video.
 The show also : showcases Greek and Italian mythology, traditional and modern music instrumentation and choreography.  Displays the curative and transformative powers of “trance” dance.  Appeals to a wide and diverse audience.  Has  educational opportunities: classes and workshops on trance dance & drumming.
     WHAT WE HAVE DONE IN THE PAST
 Our Company I GIULLARI DI PIAZZA, funded in 1980 has performed at Lincoln Center, Carnegie Hall, Madison Square Garden, Cleveland Museum of Art, Getty Center, Epcot center and many more.
I have written and directed many folk Operas. Our first TARANTATA DANCE OF THE ANCIENT SPIDER was commissioned by Lincoln Center and presented to a sold out audience at Alice Tully hall in 1996. We have also presented other powerful productions at the Cathedral of St John the Divine , as STABAT MATER DONNA DE PARADISO, THE VOYAGE OF THE BLACK MADONNA, “LA LUPA” , THE SHEPHERDS’ SONG, always receiving wide audience and critical acclaim, many favorable reviews from the New York and Los Angeles Times.
As a singer and a percussionist, I have done great shows around the world, (Italy, England, Poland, France, Spain, Brazil, Australia, Israel, Egypt, Korea) with great reviews and awards also from Modern Drummer and DRUM Magazine and television coverage. I aslo design my signature series tambourines with REMO and wrote the  book/DVD on the tarantella rhtythms, RHYTHM IS THE CURE with Mel Bay Publications. You can see these links & enjoy ! 
 "Spider Sex documentary " on National Geographic http://youtu.be/vp8dE3jJnq0
Live Appearance on ABC-TV7 Chicagohttp://youtu.be/3J9ZlzKLzPw
CNN Worldbeat http://youtu.be/IkOqBrpcB9Q
Russian TV “ “The Dancing Planet”http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Iktp2PIhKWw
www.alessandrabelloni.com www.facebook.com/alessandrabelloni www.yotube.com/alessandrabelloni

story:
USC’s Musical Theatre Repertory has been preparing for our fall production of Little Shop of Horrors. Our show is all ready to go, but now we need some support from you! We want to take you all into the wonderful world of Mushnik’s Skid Row Florist, but recreating an intricate setting can be expensive. All money donated will go directly to all production costs for Little Shop of Horrors, including costumes, our set, and performance space. The show opens on October 4th and runs through the 7th in the Massman Theater on the USC campus. We can’t wait to show you all what we’ve been working so hard on. Thank you all so much in advance for your support, and we will see you all in October! 

Musical Theatre Repertory at the University of Southern California was established in 2005 and is dedicated to enriching students’ lives through the production of quality musical theatre. Our goal is to provide students with the opportunity to participate in musical theatre pieces supplementary to those produced by USC. Explore our website [www.uscmtr.com] for general info about the company, ticketing details, upcoming events, production stills, and even a few production videos!  Thank you for supporting the arts and we can't wait to see you at our upcoming shows!

story:
DATE CHANGE! DOG SEES GOD WILL BE PERFORMING ON APRIL 4, 5, 6 INSTEAD OF MARCH!

 

Short Summary

We are a group of college students in Arizona starting a production company. We want to produce plays that raise 21st century issues and cause our audiences to think when they leave our shows.  

We are producing Bert V. Royal's DOG SEES GOD: CONFESSIONS OF A TEENAGE BLOCKHEAD as our premeire production because we believe it shows how bullying a teen can effect his or her life. It is a cautionary tale as to what can happen when a group of kids in high school do not show empathy for their life long friend. This show follows CB as he has lost his dog and searches for answers to life and finds them in his lost friend. Then follows CB though more loss because his friends cannot cope with CB and Beethoven's differences from themselves.

Studio Now wants to bring this issue to the Valley community and raise awareness for teenagers and kids who go through similar situations in their own lives. 

What We Need & What You Get

Any play comes with costs for the set, costumes, lighting, space, etc. We are trying to keep it minimal but still give our actors and designers the tools they need to put on a great show for our audience.

We are looking to raise:

  • Costumes and makeup - $500
  • Set - $350
  • Lights - $100
  • Props - $75
  • Sound - $50
  • Script - $225
  • Space - $1000
  • Advertising and programs - $350

Perks 

    • $3 - Fan
      • Our undying love and graditude!!
    • $10 - Friend
      • A shout out on our personal facebooks and tumblrs of our undying thanks and gratitude!!
    • $20 - Stage Hand
      • Everything above!
      • A signed picture of our beautiful cast with a personal message written by our founders!!
    • $30 - Actor
      • Everything above!
      • 2 tickets to one of our perfomances of DOG SEES GOD!
    • $50 - Director
      • Everything above!
      • 2 tickets to DOG SEES GOD
      • A meet and greet with our cast and crew!
      • Your name in our program as a contributor!
    • $100
      • Everything above!
      • Season tickets for our 3 2013 productions (Spring, Summer, Fall)
    • $250
      • Everything above!
      • A walk on role for one of our performances!

The Impact

Every little bit will help!! A show can be expensive but as a collaborative art we love when more people help on productions! We cannot do a production without being financed and as college students we are nickel and diming it as it is!

Please help us fund our art!!!

Other Ways You Can Help

As college students (and theatre artists!) we understand not being able to help financially! We ask that if you cannot help us financially then please share our Indiegogo on your facebooks and tumblrs or any other platform that you may use and get our name out to your friends!

If you want to know other ways you can help us in our ventures please feel free to email us at studionowtheatre@gmail.com

story:
The Washington Rogues and CulturalDC proudly present:

WE'RE FUNDED! 

MUCH LOVE TO EVERYONE WHO SUPPORTED AND SPREAD THE WORD ABOUT THIS CAMPAIGN! WE'LL SEE YOU ALL AT FLASHPOINT! 


October 10 - November 3, 2013 at The Flashpoint Mead Theatre Lab

directed by Ryan S. Taylor

Featuring: Megan Graves, Jenny Donovan, Luke Cieslewicz, Jane Petkofsky, Natalie Cutcher, Anna Lathrop and Megan Behm.

This fall.... Lucy goes hunting.

Lucy is the forgotten girl at her high school, unnoticed except when she's being mocked and tormented. She figures her life is over before it's begun. But that was before she met Jenny, the new girl at school everyone is infatuated with. Before she found something in the dark forest--something that fills her dreams with teeth and claws. Rising DC playwright Stephen Spotswood's bloody deconstruction of Little Red Riding Hood takes the familiar elements of werewolves, teen lust, and high school bullies and puts them through a blender in a tale of passion, horror and revenge.

The first reviews are in!

"...a rich mingling of worlds..." "...smart, unsettling, darkly poetic new play..." - Washington Post


"Spotswood’s language is lyrical and poetic, and manages to delicately balance the tough and relevant subject matter of bullying with priceless comedic timing and moments of levity." - DC Metro Theatre Arts (*****)

Check out our trailer, created by Ali Walton and Aaron Fisher:


Help Us Scare the Crap out of You:

Thanks to the generosity of CulturalDC we already have the most important and most expensive cost of producing a show covered: a place to put on a great show. In The Forest, She Grew Fangs will be presented as part of CulturalDC's Flashpoint Mead Theatre Lab 2013-2014 season. Flashpoint is one of the best equipped venues for young companies in the DC region, and one with which the Rogues have a history. Our very first production, 2008's Busted Jesus Comix was staged at Flashpoint as part of that year's Capital Fringe Festival. We could not be more excited to return to our original artistic home. 

Your contributions will go directly to concrete production needs. Lumber and paint for our set. Costumes and PR and artist fees. All the not-so-glamourous materials that talent artists use to make a great show. 

Where your money is going:

  • $50 - Weapon Rental - We're renting a kick ass sword from master fight choreographer Casey Kaleba. Renting a quality weapon serves two important purposes: well designed weapons are (1) safer for our actors, and (2) look really awesome. 
  • $100 - Bloooooooooood. We're getting the good stuff: Ben Nye (yeah, THAT Ben Nye) brand stage blood. As realistic as it gets, with the bonus of being totally washable which will save both laundry money and our costume designer's sanity.
  •  $150 - PR costs - What's a show without an audience? We'll be doing a run of postcards and flyers. We tend to keep our advertising budget small by taking advantage of social media and other free means of spreading the word. (But no advertising beats word of mouth, so tell your friends!)
  • $450 - Props and Costumes: Our costume designer Jesse Shipley is taking on her biggest project for the Rogues yet. On top of realistic contemporary clothing for our high school student characters, we've also got a whole blood Halloween Dance to costume. And oh yeah, we've got a werewolf. Maybe more than one. 
  • $500 - Set. The Rogues are all about immersive environments. For In The Forest, She Grew Fangs, set designer Chris Holland will plunge the audience into one of the most nightmarish environments known: a high school locker room. 
  • $750 - Artists Fees - The big one. Specifically your donations will go towards paying our talent team of set, light and sound designers. 

No matter the outcome of this campaign, the show WILL go on. We see this campaign and all our perks as a way to offer our audience and fans unique and special ways to engage with the company and show. That's why all contributions of $20 or above come with two tickets.  Be a Rogue and bring a friend! Your contributions will help us make In The Forest, She Grew Fangs an even scarier and more exciting experience. 

Thank you so much for your help! 

- Ryan S. Taylor, Artistic Director of The Washington Rogues


But wait! There's more! 

NEVER BE DARK: THE ROGUES ARE

 PAYING IT FORWARD!

By supporting In The Forest, She Grew Fangs, you'll also be supporting our mission to provide opportunities for other emerging artists making the kind of shows we want to see.  We consider ourselves very lucky to be part of the Flashpoint Mead Theatre Lab season. Being part of CulturalDC's amazing program allows us affordable access to one of the premiere performance venues in the city. 

We want to share that access. We're holding true to the national Never Be Dark movement meant to keep the country's theatrical spaces open and operating whenever possible.  As part of our residency we are proud to host two powerful solo performances by two amazing women. These performances will be entirely pay-what-you-can, and we are proud to announce that as part of our agreement with CulturalDC, 90 percent of tickets sales will go directly to these two great emerging playwright/performers. Help us keep Flashpoint hopping all through October.

OCTOBER 14th: A GUIDE TO DANCING NAKED

Written and Performed by Brynn Tucker

Directed by Hunter Styles. Choreography by Brynn Tucker.

Turn the world into your dance floor! Join DC actor Brynn Tucker for a pop-movement confessional, set to this summer's spunkiest mixtape. On the road to self-acceptance, all you need is a mirror, music and your naked self! GUIDE TO DANCING NAKED won Best Dance/Physical Theater at this year's Capital Fringe Festival. This performance will feature new material as she gets ready for this year's Fall Fringe! (Despite the title, this show is totally okay for younger audiences!)

October 28: THEY CALL ME Q!

Written and Performed by Qurrat Kadwani

Award-winning actress Qurrat Ann Kadwani plays 13 characters and searches for identity in a coming-of-age tale that entertains with tremendous humor and compelling emotion. Qurrat will be stopping by DC for one day only as she continues a national tour of the award-winning THEY CALL ME Q! Catch her while you can! 


ROGUE HISTORY:

Who are we?

The Washington Rogues daring young performing arts group with a proven record of putting some of the boldest, wildest shows in Washington, DC. Founded in 2008 we are committed to finding, commissioning and nurturing new works by the region's best emerging playwrights and creative artists. For more information about the Rogues and In The Forest, She Grew Fangs please visit our website!



ABOUT CULTURALDC:

CulturalDC makes space for art. Each year CulturalDC serves over 1,000 artists and arts groups and 30,000 audience members through the activation of art space and presentation of contemporary visual and performing arts at our two spaces, Flashpoint and Source, and in nontraditional venues across the city. Through our programs and services we work with artists and arts organizations to build the creative infrastructure that fuels the arts and builds community in Washington, DC.

The Mead Theatre Lab Program at Flashpoint, a CulturalDC project, is generously sponsored by the late Jaylee Mead. Additional support is provided by The Dallas Morse Coors Foundation for the Performing Arts, the Max & Victoria Dreyfus Foundation, the Mary & Daniel Loughran Foundation, The Washington Post Company and The Weissberg Foundation.

Funding for CulturalDC is generously provided by The Morris & Gwendolyn Cafritz Foundation, DC Commission on the Arts & Humanities, The Community Foundation for the National Capital Region, The Kresge Foundation, the MARPAT Foundation, the Eugene & Agnes E. Meyer Foundation, the National Endowment for the Arts, Prince Charitable Trusts, The Share Fund of the Community Foundation for the National Capital Region and many other generous partners. Marvin is CulturalDC’s 2013-14 Wine Partner.

story:
Short Summary

If You Knew You Were Going to Go Blind, What Would You Take with You?

Award winning theatres, the cell - a 21st century salon and theatre and San Francisco's Custom Made Theatre Company join forces to bring this multi art form "feast for the senses" to life.

"Sightlines," by Emmy Award nominee Mark Eisman, is an intimate two-person play about finding connection in an ever-blurring world.

Starring Daytime Emmy Award winning Darnell Williams (All My Children's Jesse Hubbard) as Davis, and Tamara Scott as Ruth, "Sightlines" takes us on a journey with two strangers who come together in the oddest of places, grasping in the dark for a human connection that will guide them out of the “rabbit hole.”  Out of the darkness and into the light. Out of the light and into the darkness, they smash their way “through the looking-glass” into a Lewis Carroll world and a love story defying conventional perceptions.

Walk into the cell and be transported into Eisman's Wonderland with Naomi Olson's photographs of the blind community in Hawaii, featuring tactile imagery and sound clips. Round the corner and you're in a dark room of work by the Seeing With Photography Collective, a local collective of sighted, visually-impaired, and blind photographers.  The Collective's process creates luminous distortions, blurred or glowing forms resulting entirely from their photo technique, provoking the viewer or perceiver to ask, "What is seeing?  What does one choose to see?"

Leading you in an out of the rabbit hole is an original score by ASCAP Fnd/Max Dreyfus Scholarship recipient Rona Siddiqui, fresh off her NYC solo concert debut and featured songwriter stint in Bill Finn's Cabaret at Barrington Stage and Lincoln Center's "Broadway's Future" concert series.   

On select Sundays, the Collective will offer portrait sessions - watch the process! Portraits, as well as the photographs making up the set, will be on sale throughout the run of the production.

What We Need & What You Get

It takes dedicated funding to support the artists, materials, and various costs associated with making the kind of intimate theatre that entertains us while challenging our perceptions of ourselves and the world around us.  

The cell has generously donated the space for Custom Made to bring its SF award-winning theatre to NYC, and their founding artistic director Nancy Manocherian has donated the funds for our gorgeous, innovative set; now, we need your support to raise the rest!

  • $1,500 gets the word out
  • $500 supports an artist 
  • $350 funds unsupported materials

Other Ways You Can Help

We mean it when we say every little bit helps - and you'll see your donation put to use on the stage just a few feet in front of you!

If you're a fan of Custom Made, please help us spread the word at no cost at all by:

  •  Sharing this campaign with your friends, colleageues, relatives, etc.
  • Using the Indiegogo tools for easy sharing via Facebook, Twitter and other social media platform faves

Thank you for all you do to support your local theatre community!  We look forward to seeing you at "Sightlines"!

story:
We're Eureka Suitcase, a production company dedicated to the idea that art is best served by focusing on great stories, exceptional story-telling, a reverence for the imagination of the actors and audience, and an entrepreneurial spirit in how we bring it to the people and the next great story that we'll be tackeling is our new adaptation of Shakespeare's THE TEMPEST.

While we've produced other projects before, THE TEMPEST is our first NYC production.   We've set the show in the NYC subway system and our signiture minimalist style will be a great fit inside THE TANK NYC's theatre space in Midtown Manhattan. It will be a really innovative production and we know that people will connect to it. We'll be posting designer art and other special things on the campaign wall as well as our facebook page, www.facebook.com/eurekasuitcase and our website www.eurekasuitcase.org. So keep checking in as you tell other people about it.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $6,000 to pay the actors and designers for the work and time they've put in and for minimalist design elements such as props and costumes. It's a BIG show and even though we're a minimalist company, it takes top notch talent to tell the story in a simple way. We believe that professionals of all kinds deserve something for their expertise.

And because we're working in collaboration with The Tank NYC, a 501c(3) organization, you're gift will be tax-dedictible!

So, take a look at our tiers, decide on what you'd like to share with us, and then look at the tier above it. Chances are you'll love that gift more! And since it's tax-deductible you can give more!

Who wouldn't want a drunk dial voicemail from the two drunken characters in the show? I know I would. Or you can make Aaron Vega's hand cramp from writing 50 personalized sonnets. Or better yet, have your name trumpeted out as a major patron of the arts before every show! But whatever tier you choose know that this production is funded by you and for you. Art for the people, baby.

The Impact

By helping us with our goal you'll be directly affecting the lives of 12 stellar actors in the NYC area, designers galore, not to mention providing affordable live entertainment options to the people in Midtown Manhattan since our 62 seat theatre will be mere blocks from the mammoth specticle of Broadway.

Most artists believe in the power of the Shakespeare's words. They are timeless and can be just as indicative of the modern world as they were when they were written but, we have to win back the trust of the people by making it accessible to their situation.

Our last show, A MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM (see production photos on www.eurekasuitcase.org), was a great success and the people that came out to see it were blown away by what we were able to achieve outside, on the side of mountain in Snowmass, CO. This time we get to bring our style to Midtown Manhattan and we couldn't be more excited.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have $1 to give then please spread the word about the campaign. The only way we will succeed is if people want to see this production. The share tools are a great resource and taking 30 seconds means that even more people have the opportunity to make this vision of THE TEMPEST a reality.

story:
What's going on?

Boutique Theatre is a relatively young Melbourne independent theatre company passionate about producing innovative, honest and accessible theatre of the highest standard. We're also big on nurturing emerging artists - both on stage and in creative roles. 

We've just embarked on a crazy journey with Craig Wright's beautiful play The Pavilion and have managed to secure the gorgeous Industrial School at the Abbotsford Convent for our show. 

(If you'd like to buy tickets to see the show, you can do that here.)


What We Need & What You Get

By helping us reach our $5,300 target, you will be helping us to perform in the iconic and unique Industrial School at the Abbotsford Convent which greatly contributes to the look & feel of our show. Every little bit counts and the more we can raise to pay our venue hire, the more we can invest in developing our creatives and actors and producing a spectacular show.

And to say thank you for your support  we have some beautiful gifts on offer that range from shout outs on social media, personalised thank you cards (courtesy of Bearded Iris Studios), tickets to opening night of The Pavilion or a Boutique Theatre 2014-5 season ticket.


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that sometimes you just don't have the cash to contribute right now, so here's a few things you can do to help out in other ways:

  • Share this campaign with friends and family - the more people the better!
  • Volunteer to usher a performance of The Pavilion (email emma.caldwell@boutiquetheatre.com.au to apply)
  • 'Like' us on Facebook (www.facebook.com/boutiquetheatre) or follow us on Twitter (@BoutiqueTC)
  • Tell everyone you know about Boutique Theatre - the power of word of mouth is HUGE!

story:
Hello, good people!  Thank you for reading this plea.

Being an adult suffering from Chronic Virginity isn't easy, especially in New York City.  So, I did what any good comedian would do to deal with the stress: I wrote a show about it!  For the last three years, I have been performing my show, “The Alexis Lambright Tell-A-Thon: Combating Adult Virginity” in New York City.  Since 2011, the show has developed into an hour-long piece that has gone on to the 17th Annual New York International Fringe Festival (2013), and is headed the 2014 Hollywood Fringe Festival, taking place from June 5 to June 29. But, before I bring awareness of this grave condition to the other coast, I need your help!

Through stories, songs, and videos, this comedy tell-a-thon/live telethon (yes, operators ARE standing by) chronicles my life, presents very-officially-done research via my non-profit organization the New York Center for Adult Virginity Research (NYCAVR), shares interviews with other sufferers of Chronic Virginity (also known as CV), and pulls you into awkward moments from my dating life as an adult virgin.

While my main goal has always been primarily to find a “curer” for my CV, it is now that I need to turn to you for financial support as well.   All jokes aside, taking a show from one side of the country to the other is not a cheap prospect, and every penny donated will help greatly.  In addition to myself, I would like to be able to take one or two company members with me (my lovely director John Kenneth Kelly to start), and would like to take as much of the pressure off of travel and lodging costs as possible, since this is not a short trip.  I plan to use local talent wherever possible, as far as technical assistance and other necessary staff, but everyone connected with this production deserves to paid adequately for their time and expertise.  As well, producing a show in a city that isn’t my own requires a different marketing strategy than producing a show in one’s own backyard, and your contributions will help offset those costs, allowing me to take out ads in local papers and publications, increase my supply of marketing materials, and make sure that as many people as possible get to see the show I’ve worked so hard to create.  Smaller but no less important places your money will go towards are rehearsal spaces, program fees, some snazzy new costumes, and perhaps a meal or two for the people helping to make my dream come true.

Any amount will be welcomed and appreciated, and please, if you can't contribute, just help spread the word! Tell your friends, family, coworkers, enemies, and even pets about this campaign.  Thank you so much in advance!!

story:
About Find the Floor Dance Collective 

The collective was formed between Jillian Peever and Shannon Roberts, two emerging choreographers who share a common history and a common desire to make thought-provoking work. The Collective's first production allows the two creators to step out on to the contemporary dance scene with passion and determination with a group of dance artists who inspire their work. It is important that we produce work that inspires our audience physically and promotes intellectual discussion.

Read more about our collaborators by visiting our website

The Main Event...

The evening will explore and challenge perceptions and self-definitions. A Way of Seeing follows two women in their search for identity within the confines of society, while four women in What We Do expose human suffering and it's role in the individual. 

A Year of Preparations...    

We have embraced the demands of self-production this year and one of the ever-present challenges is fundraising. We have already received great support from friends and colleagues throughout the year in many ways. Your continued financial assistance will help make this a lasting endeavor. 


Where Will Your Donations Go? 

        Funds raised from our campaign will go to our collaborators; our dance artists, lighting designer, stage manager, assistant stage manager and other administrative staff. We are intent on providing fair wages to our collaborators as these artists truly deserve it! The creative forces of these artists make our world a better place and their dedication to their art form should be commended. 

 

Your Impact

By supporting our campaign, the artists involved with the project will gain valuable experience and exposure. Your donation to this production will bring positive energy to our creativity, allowing us to focus our attention on our art making. The effect will therefore enhance the audience's experience and our goals of making lasting artwork may be realized. Art is an important part of our society. Please help us maintain the integrity of our energized group of Toronto contemporary dance artists! 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate at this time there are still ways you can help!

Share our campaign- Spread the word about our upcoming show on July 18th and 19th at Dancemakers Centre for Creation 

Be a volunteer- We could use your help in a number of different ways! Please contact us if you are interested in finding out more about volunteering: findthefloordance@gmail.com

Come see our show (and bring a friend!)- We could not have a show without an audience and we would love to see you there!

Want to donate, but need a tax receipt? If you would like to donate but would like receive a tax receipt, we accept cheques by mail for over $50. Please email us for more info: findthefloordance@gmail.com

story:
Mission Statement

My intentions are to become the most complete artist I can achieve.  Art is in the way you ride the bumps while standing on the bus, or how you extend your arm to receive your morning coffee.  I strive to close the gap between everyday activity and art making. The world is a playground and every moment is a chance to heighten your awareness of movement and the space around you.  In my eyes, being an artist is putting your soul on display and uncovering every truth about it. There is no illusion.  We must be superheroes and superhuman in the risks we take to shed and release all excess layers of ourselves. To be completely pure but never barren.  That is how I wish to inspire. To revel in individuality and share exactly who I am in hopes for others to see the beauty in acceptance. 

I am hungry to have greater experiences with the world around me. I want to be lost: in the moment, in space, and in the unknown.  Emerging from that, I believe, is the next step for my growth as an artist.  This festival is the missing link.  It is the largest contemporary dance festival in Europe, and going there with an open heart and mind would allow a plethora of opportunities. 

Video credits: 

Stage choreography- Alexandria Diaz De Fato

Outdoor footage- Theo Thompson



The Breakdown 

Tuition: 8,553 Includes:

  •  BIBLIOTECA DO CORPO workshops  • 4 ImPulsTanz workshops  • 1 ImPulsTanz field project • 20 tickets for ImPulsTanz performances • Choreography project by Ismael Ivo • Accommodation in Vienna • Per diem • Public transport or ImPulsTanz bike in Vienna • Presentation of the final work in Vienna • Presentation of the final work in São Paulo  (incl. airfare Vienna – São Paulo – Vienna,  per diem and accommodation) 
  • Estimated plane ticket: 2,000

story:
"Talibam! and Sam Kulik Discover AtlantASS" marks a significant new step in Talibam!'s discography as we expand our focus to include the visual arts, an album-long narrative structure, and live presentation as a work of theater.

Yep, we decided to go big with this one.

It makes sense in a couple of ways.  So much music is available right now that sometimes it takes a little gumption to just get noticed (like, say, producing a concept album with a comic book attached and performing it for two weeks in a landmarked theater!).  And when your aim is to respond to an environmental crisis like the 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico (an atrocious, despicable and fatal crisis), why go halfway?

Our Atlantis owes as much to Sun Ra and Frank Zappa as it does to SpongeBob.  At the center of the story are Franklin and his magic pillow, brought down to Atlantis to combat a terrible oil spill that is being exploited by corrupt politicians at the expense of Atlantis' poetic and musical free-loving peacenik community.  The three of us play all the music and about a dozen characters in the show, throwing in ramshackle costume changes and puppeteering to add to the finely-tuned insanity that is evident right out of the gate.  Far from single-minded in his quest to quash the oil spill, Franklin meets a ghost, a spy, some revolutionary jazz fish, and a salacious squid along the way, getting his education in jazz and whatever the undersea equivalent is to the birds and the bees.  The record took almost two years to make as characters and scenes were added and the sonic landscape delicately crafted with homemade sound effects.
 
To our knowledge we are the only performance group to address the implications of the BP Oil Spill in the Gulf of Mexico in an artistic context. We believe that 'corporate environmental catastrophies' are the world's slow death, and we wanted to hammer home that point in a creative way.

We shot an epic album cover with mermaid models and collaborated with British artist James Clapham to produce a comic book (www.bellykids.co.uk) that details the story told on the record.  In June of last year and March of this year we toured Europe with the traveling version of the show, eliciting responses such as this from joyous audiences: 
"...antics are counter-balanced by a thoroughly mind-blowing proficiency, a maze-like collection of tunes drawn from free jazz, hip-hop, psychedelia, and novelty records, seemingly, performed with pinpoint accuracy and frightening ability that literally slackens the jaw, a serious counterpoint to the antics that somehow accentuates the absurdity of the whole bloody enterprise." 
- www.drop-d.ie

Doing the show properly on our home turf of New York City is what we've had in mind all along.  The arts producers at Incubator Arts at the historic St. Mark's Church are very excited to have us and we are excited to be there (Martha Graham, Harry Houdini, William Carlos Williams, Sam Shepard, Patti Smith, and Richard Foreman being among our artistic forebears in the space).  We have the opportunity to put ourselves in front of a theater audience for the first time as well as show off something new to the musical community that has nurtured Talibam! since 2003.

Theater sure introduces some new costs to our enterprise, though!  Use of the theater for two weeks runs us $5,000, a gamble we're willing to take because of the opportunity it gives us to step up our game and give the project new exposure.  Friends of ours who have performed at Incubator in the past couple of years have gone on to see their productions picked up by other major theaters around the country, giving credence to the "Incubator" name.  So it's worth it for us to stick our necks out a bit, but we're doing this fundraising campaign to defray the costs we've absorbed making the album, designing the show, staffing the theater for two weeks, and paying the outstanding artists we've invited to perform with us during the run.  Plus we get to sell the amazing album (and related goodies!) directly to our fans.

Help yourself to some Talibam! swag, and help us pull off this madness!  Thank you!
 
Our brilliant guest performers during the run will include: Christy & Emily, Ugly Duckling Presse, Guardian Alien, David Linton, Cooper-Moore, Peter Glanz, Christopher Meeders, and Marisa Perel.
 
The full schedule of our performances and what guests are performing on which nights is listed at www.discoveratlantass.blogspot.com
 
If you wish to reach the theater box office for tickets or other schedule information, visit www.incubatorarts.org, see them in person at 131 E. 10th St, NYC, or call 212.352.3101
story_txt:
"Talibam! and Sam Kulik Discover AtlantASS" marks a significant new step in Talibam!'s discography as we expand our focus to include the visual arts, an album-long narrative structure, and live presentation as a work of theater.Yep, we decided to go big with this one.It makes sense in a couple of ways.  So much music is available right now that sometimes it takes a little gumption to just get noticed (like, say, producing a concept album with a comic book attached and performing it for two weeks in a landmarked theater!).  And when your aim is to respond to an environmental crisis like the 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico (an atrocious, despicable and fatal crisis), why go halfway?Our Atlantis owes as much to Sun Ra and Frank Zappa as it does to SpongeBob.  At the center of the story are Franklin and his magic pillow, brought down to Atlantis to combat a terrible oil spill that is being exploited by corrupt politicians at the expense of Atlantis' poetic and musical free-loving peacenik community.  The three of us play all the music and about a dozen characters in the show, throwing in ramshackle costume changes and puppeteering to add to the finely-tuned insanity that is evident right out of the gate.  Far from single-minded in his quest to quash the oil spill, Franklin meets a ghost, a spy, some revolutionary jazz fish, and a salacious squid along the way, getting his education in jazz and whatever the undersea equivalent is to the birds and the bees.  The record took almost two years to make as characters and scenes were added and the sonic landscape delicately crafted with homemade sound effects. 
To our knowledge we are the only performance group to address the implications of the BP Oil Spill in the Gulf of Mexico in an artistic context. We believe that 'corporate environmental catastrophies' are the world's slow death, and we wanted to hammer home that point in a creative way.

We shot an epic album cover with mermaid models and collaborated with British artist James Clapham to produce a comic book (www.bellykids.co.uk) that details the story told on the record.  In June of last year and March of this year we toured Europe with the traveling version of the show, eliciting responses such as this from joyous audiences: "...antics are counter-balanced by a thoroughly mind-blowing proficiency, a maze-like collection of tunes drawn from free jazz, hip-hop, psychedelia, and novelty records, seemingly, performed with pinpoint accuracy and frightening ability that literally slackens the jaw, a serious counterpoint to the antics that somehow accentuates the absurdity of the whole bloody enterprise."

Our brilliant guest performers during the run will include: Christy & Emily, Ugly Duckling Presse, Guardian Alien, David Linton, Cooper-Moore, Peter Glanz, Christopher Meeders, and Marisa Perel.
 
The full schedule of our performances and what guests are performing on which nights is listed at www.discoveratlantass.blogspot.com

 
If you wish to reach the theater box office for tickets or other schedule information, visit www.incubatorarts.org, see them in person at 131 E. 10th St, NYC, or call 212.352.3101

story:
Control Group Productions creates fascinating, singular, dynamically innovative dance/performance works that reach across mediums, approaches, and aesthetic boundaries. Fiercely contemporary, the company is driving a growing progressive performance community in Colorado, with CGP’s black-box venue work|space Denver at the center of the movement.

            This summer Control Group has the amazing opportunity to perform at American Dance Festival as part of the festival’s MFA performance series. The largest congregation of professional dancers, companies, teachers, and students in the country, ADF will provide an unbeatable platform for expanding CGP’s visibility, network, and activities. The company’s performances of its newest work, Salon Romantik, opus 1: Wanderers in the Sea of Fog, will contribute a unique physical theatre voice to ADF’s 2012 performance series, providing audiences a rare glimpse of work originating from outside of the standard cultural centers of New York and Europe.

            Your help couldn’t come at a better time. We’re already in the planning stages for the tour, including a generous donation from local Durham-ites of accommodations for our four-person company. Company activities from the spring will provide for modest artist fees for the dancers, who are donating their time to represent Control Group at the festival for a 10-day period. Your donations will get us the rest of the way there, paying for travel costs and materials for the performances.

            In return for your contributions, we’ve lined up an array of special gifts for you, our donors – everything from CGP T-shirts (new design!), DVDs of our performance work, even prints from our photo shoot with renowned Denver photographers Mark Sink and Kristen Hatgi. For business donors, we have an array of sponsorship opportunities that can highlight your business to our audiences (please inquire directly).

            This opportunity really is incredible! During the company’s 10 days at ADF, we’ll perform 3-4 shows at two different venues, participate in the ADF school, and network with presenters, colleagues, and other companies. The results will be far-reaching – further performance opportunities, new companies for CGP to present at our Denver theater, broader visibility for Control Group nationally and internationally, and, of course, the opportunity to share our unique and exciting work with Durham and ADF audiences.

            We believe strongly that the arts are a precious cultural commodity. Support for the arts is an investment in our community’s vibrancy, richness, intelligence, and character. The first donations have already come in! Please, join in this community effort to move our local culture forward with excellent new works, exciting opportunities for artists and audiences alike, and expanded participation in the 21st century global arts dialog.

NOTE: For more details about the donor gifts, visit www.controlgroupproductions.org/donate/.

ANOTHER NOTE (6/9/12): We're receiving donations through other channels as well as this fine IndieGoGo campaign. All together, we've received over half of our total goal.

story:
Vertigo Productions is proud to present its first production of the 2012-2013 school year! The Derby County Derby is an ensemble comedy that explores the thrilling world of high stakes horseracing in the fictional Derby County, Kentucky. Over the course of 24 hours, the town’s colorful denizens – from Victorian beggars to eccentric billionaires to Matthew McConaughey – converge for the biggest race of all. It’s a story of love, triumph, and performance-enhancing horse drugs.

But we need your help!

story:
Empowering local and global artists, we provide opportunities for national and international artists to work together in an environment for growth, creativity and transformation.

DAIPANbutoh Collective is devoted to strengthening the presence of Butoh in Seattle and the Northwest, both by producing the work of its members and by bringing in international artists for performances and workshops. In doing so, we aim to deeply influence our community’s evolution.

DAIPAN Butoh Collective is five female dancers with furious vitality, offering world class quality butoh dance to the Northwest. We don’t have the backing of a large arts organization like On The Boards and STG yet we bring the same high quality art at extremely accessible pricing to our growing community. Through our volunteer energies we have brought the finest international performers and teachers to Seattle in our annual international butoh festival.  This is our eighth year producing the Seattle Butoh Festival, which always features performances by international butoh artists and DAIPAN members. We need your help to pull this off. It costs money to fly in artists, house them and pay for them to teach and perform, not to mention the technical and production expenses.  We are grateful to have received a sustaining art grant from 4Culture, but this grant only covers a fraction of our total expenses.  This festival is our most ambitious undertaking so far - with a full gallery show, 6 gallery performance days and 3 mainstage performances involving 8 international guest artists from Chile and Helsinki.  Please help us keep Seattle the vital sanctuary of global artistry and humanity that it is!

DAIPANbutoh Collective’s current community includes the DAIPANbutoh ACTIVE members Sheri Brown, Joan Laage, Helen Thorsen, Diana García-Snyder, Kaoru Okumura in addition to DAIPANpartners and DAIPANfriends. We continually enlarge our community by interfacing with artists of various disciplines. Co-promoting, producing, and performing, we are a vehicle for cross-cultural exchange with artists internationally. We are reaching out as individual artists and as a group to become an integral, intelligent international presence in the evolving butoh aesthetic inside a global boom of butoh-inspired art.

story:
My name is Roderick (Ricky) Woodruff. I was born and raised on the eastside of Detroit. I am a recent graduate with a Bachelors of Fine Arts in Acting from Southern Methodist University, where I was awarded the engaged learning fellowship. At SMU, I was taught to be a world changer and today, I invite you to join my revolution: the New York and international premier of “A Boy’s Room.”

A Boy’s Room is a multimedia memory play that follows little Ricky in his bedroom, attempting to put on a one-of-a-kind performance inspired by  Beyoncé’s Formation World Tour. During his flamboyant pop performance, he is steadily interrupted by his inner demons, who constantly beg him to conform. At its core, A Boy’s Room is meant to disrupt, deconstruct, and ultimately dismantle toxic-masculinity that is generationally imposed on black boys. Through the use of a short film, creative storytelling, original music and choreography, A Boy’s Room serves as my call to action- educating the world [particularly black men] on the importance of embracing one’s whole self.

As a poor, black and gay man I have experienced public humiliation, doubt and self hate. I have spent most of my life in search of wholeness and self worth. More often than not, I had found myself resenting the circumstances of which I’d been placed. More so, I resented those whom I felt had placed me there. I had become insecure, to say the least. I quickly learned to wear masks to conceal the shame I felt in everyday things; my mom’s beat up 1990’s Subaru, the ebonics I grew up speaking and the Beyonce song lumped in my throat. Being a poor, black and gay boy from Detroit was a Death sentence to me. I worked hard to prove myself to my community by excelling artistically at the internationally acclaimed Mosaic Youth Theatre of Detroit, academically at Cass Technical High School and even beyond Detroit at Southern Methodist University and Dallas Theatre Center. I truly believed the only way to escape my circumstances was through assimilation. I yearned to be seen as a distinguished man, though it would amount to a complete loss of self identity. By senior year at SMU, I had realized that my acting techniques were great, but my work was lacking the brutal honesty that is required to make real art. It was lacking my truth. It was lacking the poor, black, gay boy I tried to erase. I began to question myself and my work. How could I be this revolutionary, transformative and inspirational artist who influences the next generation, while living a lie? The answer was simple: I couldn’t.

So, I wrote A Boy’s Room, not only to reconcile my relationship with self, but to also ensure that no little black boy ever thinks that assimilation is his only way out.

After realizing its potential, I workshopped and staged the first production in April of 2019. Despite the conservative culture at SMU, the production was well received. Each night, the show’s occupancy was at maximum capacity. The audience members were transcended. It was as if we had experienced a spiritual gathering together. It was here that I understood the potential for truly engaging, transforming and inspiring the world. I then teamed up with producer Kaylyn Buckley (SMU ‘17) and director Brandi Jaray Mcleain (SMU ‘19) to begin laying the ground work for both a New York and 2020 Edinburgh Fringe Festival debut.

By staging A Boy’s Room in New York City and in Scotland, our message will spread like wild fire. The New York production will help to continue building our following and will gain attraction for the Edinburgh Fringe Festival debut, where we’ll perform 28 consecutive days for thousands of individuals at the world’s largest arts festival. During each production, we will broadcast the performance and encourage the audience to post, tweet and/or live record the show to assist us in promoting our narrative,  so that the show’s targeted audience may have easy access to the performance.

Today, I ask you to join our movement.  A Boy's Room is a lifestyle; a relationship to a truth that is greater than just a play. It is a voice for countless young black men who cannot (or refuse) to speak his truth. It is my way of protecting, engaging, inspiring and transforming the generation that succeeds me. It is a safe space where theatre meets community and vice versa. With your help, A Boy’s Room can change lives. I am asking you to join our movement and to partner with us in saving the little black gay boy who feels inadequate and ashamed. To produce A Boy’s Room successfully, we need to raise at least $50,000. This money will be used for flights, housing, set construction, pay for our invaluable creatives, costumes, venue fees, and other crucial production expenses. Donations between $1,000 and $5,000 will be rewarded with producer credit. In addition, donations of $5,000 or more will be rewarded with an executive producer credit on the show. If you’d like to make a substantial donation that is tax-deductible, please follow this link so you can donate through our fiscal sponsorship and receive your tax write-off:  https://fundraising.fracturedatlas.org/a-boy-s-... 

Together we can protect, engage, inspire and transform the culture.

story:
UNFOLD 

An intimate and immersive dance-theater work by Samantha Spriggs in collaboration with performing artists Laura Briggs, Susanna Green, Anna Love, Maria McNiece, Emma Morris, and Carly Wynans. Presented in a small venue, with audience on three-sides and up close, UNFOLD will invite the audience into the memories, identities and perspectives of the performing artists. An excerpt of this process-based work was presented in the 2019 Modern Atlanta Dance Festival in May. The full production will premier September 28 & 29, 2019 at Dance Foundry. 

...

Samantha Spriggs (she/her/hers) is an Atlanta-based independent dance-artist whose work has been presented in Chicago, New York, Dallas, and Atlanta. This will be her first self-produced work in Atlanta. In addition to her choreographic work, Spriggs has presented research at the joint Society of Dance History Scholars/Congress On Research in Dance conference and worked in technical theater as a lighting designer, stage manager, and sound designer for dance and theater. Her choreography and teaching work emphasizes the intersections between live performance and social justice.  

...

Self-producing work as an independent artist can be incredibly daunting. Sources of funding are scarce, and the upfront costs of renting rehearsal space to begin exploring an idea often keeps artists from delving into the work they are driven to make. We need help to offset those upfront costs and to be able to pay the incredible cast of collaborators who have committed themselves to the creation of this work. We have been in process for this production since February, and cannot wait to share it with you. Each of us has embedded our voice, our experiences, and ourselves in this work. 

...

By contributing to this project, you are directly impacting the lives of the artists involved, and making the creation of new work an accessible and attainable goal. I am committed to paying my collaborators for their immeasurable contributions to the creation and content of this work, and I cannot reasonably do that without your support. 

Thank you!

What We Need & What You Get

  • We're hoping to raise $3000 with this campaign. These funds will first and foremost supplement our other funding sources to PAY THE ARTISTS. Any additional funds will be used to rent the needed lighting and production equipment, pay for space rental for rehearsal and performances, and offset the upfront costs of making work.
  • Every donor will receive our heartfelt thanks, a mention in our program and a coveted social media shout-out. Larger donations will receive handwritten notes, tickets to the show, and even a small handmade gift for the highest level donors!
  • If we don't fully reach our funding goal, first priority goes to performer pay, so no matter what, the artists will be compensated for their time. The more we raise, even exceeding our goal, the more performer pay will increase, but no matter what, they will receive a competitive stipend for their work.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to make a financial contribution right now (we're artists, we absolutely get it!), here are other ways in which you can help us reach our goal:

  • SHARE this campaign! Increase our reach by telling your network about our project!
  • Come take move with us! If you're in Atlanta, come to open classes every Sunday Morning in August at Dance Foundry! (Pay-What-You-Can)
  • Buy a ticket! Bring a friend! Tickets will be available to pre-purchase starting September 1. The greatest way to support the work is to be a part of our audience. Join us for one of our performances September 28 & 29!

Thank You!!!
